book.info: The apostle Paul ([link]1:1[/link]; [link]9:1-2[/link]), twenty-five years after he was called ([link]Acts 9:3-6[/link], [link]15-16[/link]) and fourteen years after he was sent to the Gentiles ([link]Acts 13:1-4[/link], [link]8[/link]).
Approximately A.D. 59, near the end of Paul's three-year stay in Ephesus ([link]Acts 20:31[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 16:8[/link]).
The saints — the church — in Corinth and all who call upon the name of our Lord Jesus Christ in every place ([link]1:2[/link]).

verse.text: Paul, a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]called apostle of Christ Jesus through the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]will of God, and [note]3[/note]Sosthenes the brother,
verse.note: An apostle is a sent one. Paul was such a one, not self-appointed but called by the Lord. His apostleship was authentic ([link]9:1-5[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 12:11-12[/link]; cf. [link]2 Cor. 11:13[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:2[/link]), having the authority of God's New Testament administration ([link]2 Cor. 10:8[/link]; [link]13:10[/link]). Based on this position with this authority the apostle wrote this Epistle, not only to nourish and build up the saints in Corinth but also to regulate and adjust the church there.

The will of God is His determination for the carrying out of His purpose. Through this will Paul was called to be an apostle of Christ. Paul's assertion here strengthened his apostolic position and authority.

Sosthenes here was probably not the same Sosthenes as in [link]Acts 18:17[/link], because this Epistle was written in Ephesus ([link]16:8[/link]) not long after the apostle left Corinth, where the other Sosthenes was a ruler of the synagogue when Paul was persecuted there. This Sosthenes, as a brother in the Lord, must have gone out together with the apostle for the ministry. The mentioning of him here strengthened Paul's apostleship and points out the principle of the Body.

verse.text: To the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]church of God which is [note]2[/note]in [xref]b[/xref]Corinth, [note]3[/note]to those who have been [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]sanctified [note]5[/note]in Christ Jesus, the [note]6[/note][xref]d[/xref]called saints, [note]7[/note]with all those who [note]8[/note][xref]e[/xref]call upon the name of our Lord Jesus Christ in every place, [i]who is[/i] [note]9[/note][xref]f[/xref]theirs and ours:
verse.note: The church of God! Not the church of Cephas, of Apollos, of Paul, or of any practice or doctrine, but of God. In spite of all the division, sin, confusion, abusing of gifts, and heretical teaching in the church in Corinth, the apostle still called it "the church of God" because the divine and spiritual essence which makes the assembled believers the church of God was actually there. Such a spiritual address by the apostle was based on his spiritual view in looking upon the church in Christ. Such a simple address alone should have eliminated all the division and confusion in both practice and doctrine.

The church is constituted of the universal God, but it exists on earth in many localities, one of which was Corinth. In nature the church is universal in God, but in practice the church is local in a definite place. Hence, the church has two aspects: the universal and the local. Without the universal aspect, the church is void of content; without the local aspect, it is impossible for the church to have any expression and practice. Hence, the New Testament stresses the local aspect of the church also ([link]Acts 8:1[/link]; [link]13:1[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:11[/link]; etc.).

[i]To the church of God[/i] equals [i]to those who have been sanctified in Christ Jesus.[/i] This strongly indicates that the church is a composition of the saints and that the saints are the constituents of the church. The two should not be considered separate entities. Individually, we are the saints; corporately, we are the church.
I.e., made holy, separated unto God for the fulfillment of His purpose. See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link].

[i]In Christ[/i] means in the element and sphere of Christ. Christ is the element and sphere that separated us, made us holy, unto God when we believed into Him, that is, when we were brought into an organic union with Him through our faith in Him.

The believers in Christ are the called saints, not called [i]to be[/i] saints. This is a positional matter, a sanctification in position with a view to sanctification in disposition. See note [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 6[/link].

Not [i]and[/i] but [i]with[/i] all those who call upon the name of our Lord Jesus Christ in every place. This indicates (1) that a local church, such as the church in Corinth, is composed only of those believers in that locality, not of all believers in every place, and (2) that this Epistle was intended not only for the believers in that one church in Corinth but for all believers in every place. This Epistle is for all believers of whatever place or time.

To call upon the name of the Lord implies to believe into Him ([link]Rom. 10:14[/link]). All believers in the Lord should be His callers ([link]Acts 9:14[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]22:16[/link]). We have been called to call, called by God to call upon the name of the Lord Jesus.

Christ as the all-inclusive One belongs to all believers. He is our allotted portion given to us by God ([link]Col. 1:12[/link]). The apostle added this special phrase at the end of this verse to stress the crucial fact that Christ is the unique center of all believers in whatever place or situation. In this Epistle the apostle's intention was to solve the problems among the saints in Corinth. For all the problems, especially the matter of division, the only solution is the all-inclusive Christ. We have all been called into the fellowship of, the participation in, Him ([link]v. 9[/link]). All believers should be focused on Him, not being distracted by any gifted person, any overstressed doctrine, or any particular practice.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
I [xref]a[/xref]thank my God always concerning you [note]1[/note]based upon the [xref]b[/xref]grace of God which was given to you in Christ Jesus,
verse.note: The apostle's giving of thanks to God for the Corinthian believers was based on the grace of God given to them in Christ, not on their condition in themselves.

verse.text: That in everything you were [xref]a[/xref]enriched in Him, in all [note]1[/note]utterance and all [xref]b[/xref]knowledge,
verse.note: Gk. [i]logos,[/i] i.e., word; the word that gives utterance to the thought formed in the mind. The word of the gospel preached by the apostle conveys the thought of God to our understanding. Hence, the word is the expression, the utterance, of the divine thought. Knowledge is the apprehension, the realization, of what is conveyed and uttered in the word. The Corinthian believers were enriched by the grace of God in all utterance of the divine thought concerning Christ and in all apprehension and realization in knowing Christ.

verse.text: Even as the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]testimony of Christ was confirmed [note]2[/note]in you,
verse.note: This was the preaching of Christ by the apostle, not merely with objective doctrines but with subjective experiences, as a witness bearing a living testimony of Christ. Such a testimony of Christ was confirmed within and among the Corinthian believers by their being enriched in Christ, as mentioned in [link]vv. 4[/link] and [link]5[/link].
Or, among.

verse.text: So that you do not lack in any [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gift, eagerly awaiting the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ,
verse.note: [i]Gift[/i] here refers to the inward gifts issuing from grace, such as the free gift of eternal life ([link]Rom. 6:23[/link]) and the gift of the Holy Spirit ([link]Acts 2:38[/link]) as the heavenly gift ([link]Heb. 6:4[/link]). It does not refer to the outward, miraculous gifts, such as healing, speaking in tongues, etc., mentioned in [link book="1 Cor."]chs. 12[/link] and [link book="1 Cor."]14[/link]. All the inward gifts are constituents of grace. They are the initial things of the divine life that are received of grace. All these need to grow ([link]3:6-7[/link]) to their full development and maturity. The Corinthian believers were not lacking in the initial gifts in life, but they were desperately short of the growth in life. Hence, however much they had been initially enriched in grace, they were still infants in Christ, soulish, fleshly, and even fleshy ([link]2:14[/link]; [link]3:1[/link], [link]3[/link]).
Referring to the Lord's second coming. To await the appearing of the Lord is a normal sign of true believers.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Who will also [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]confirm you until the end [xref]b[/xref]unreprovable in the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]day of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: Referring to God in [link]v. 4[/link]. The very God who has initially given us grace will also confirm us until the end.
This indicates that after the initial receiving of grace, we the believers need to grow in life.
See note [link]16[sup]4[/sup] in Phil. 2[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]God is [xref]a[/xref]faithful, through whom you were [xref]b[/xref]called [note]2[/note]into the [xref]c[/xref]fellowship of His Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.
verse.note: This word is a continuation of [link]v. 8[/link], strengthening the thought with the assurance of God's faithfulness. In His faithfulness God will confirm the believers until the end, making them unreprovable in the day of the Lord's return.

I.e., to partake of the fellowship of the union with God's Son, Jesus Christ, and of the participation in Him. God has called us into such a fellowship that we may enjoy Christ as our God-given portion. This word, like the word in [link]v. 2[/link] concerning Christ's being theirs and ours, stresses again the crucial fact that Christ is the unique center of the believers for the solving of the problems among them, especially the problem of division.[br][br]This book unveils to us that the very Christ, into whom we all have been called, is all-inclusive. He is the portion given to us by God ([link]v. 2[/link]). He is God's power and God's wisdom as righteousness, sanctification, and redemption to us ([link]vv. 24[/link], [link]30[/link]). He is the Lord of glory ([link]2:8[/link]) for our glorification ([link]2:7[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:30[/link]). He is the depths (deep things) of God ([link]2:10[/link]). He is the unique foundation of God's building ([link]3:11[/link]). He is our Passover ([link]5:7[/link]), the unleavened bread ([link]5:8[/link]), the spiritual food, the spiritual drink, and the spiritual rock ([link]10:3-4[/link]). He is the Head ([link]11:3[/link]) and the Body ([link]12:12[/link]). He is the firstfruits ([link]15:20[/link], [link]23[/link]), the second man ([link]15:47[/link]), and the last Adam ([link]15:45[/link]); and as such He became the life-giving Spirit ([link]15:45[/link]) that we may receive Him into us as our everything. This all-inclusive One, with the riches of at least twenty items, God has given to us as our portion for our enjoyment. We should concentrate on Him, not on any persons, things, or matters other than Him. We should focus on Him as our unique center appointed by God, that all the problems among the believers may be solved. It is into the fellowship of such a One that we have been called by God. This fellowship of God's Son became the fellowship that the apostles shared with the believers ([link]Acts 2:42[/link]; [link]1 John 1:3[/link]) in His Body, the church, and should be the fellowship that we enjoy in partaking of His blood and His body at His table ([link]10:16[/link], [link]21[/link]). Such a fellowship, which is carried out by the Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]), must be unique because He is unique; it forbids any division among the members of His unique Body.

verse.text: Now I beseech you, brothers, through the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you all [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]speak the same thing and [i]that[/i] there be no [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]divisions among you, but [i]that[/i] you be [note]4[/note]attuned in the [xref]d[/xref]same mind and in the same [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]opinion.
verse.note: With this verse the apostle began to deal with the divisions among the Corinthians. First, he besought them through the name of our Lord, which is the name above all names ([link]Phil. 2:9[/link]) and should be the unique name among all His believers. However, the divisive Corinthians ranked the names of Paul, Apollos, and Cephas with the name of Christ, just as Peter on the mount of transfiguration ranked Moses and Elijah with Christ ([link]Matt. 17:1-8[/link]). To keep the oneness in the Lord and to avoid divisions, we need to uplift and exalt the unique name of our Lord by dropping all names other than this highest name.
Because of their different speakings in their strife, which were condemned by the apostle in [link]vv. 11-12[/link].

In this Epistle the apostle dealt with eleven problems among the believers in Corinth. The first was the matter of division. Division is nearly always the leading problem, bringing in all other problems among believers. It may be considered the root of the problems among believers. Hence, in dealing with all the problems in the church at Corinth, the apostle's axe first touched the root, that is, the divisions among the believers there. The first virtue of the believers' walk that is worthy of God's calling is the keeping of the oneness of the Spirit in the Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 4:1-6[/link]).

The same word in Greek that is translated [i]mending[/i] in [link]Matt. 4:21[/link]. It means [i]to repair, to restore, to adjust, to mend, making a broken thing thoroughly complete, joined perfectly together.[/i] The Corinthian believers as a whole were divided, broken. They needed to be mended in order to be joined perfectly together that they might be in harmony, having the same mind and the same opinion to speak the same thing, that is, Christ and His cross ([link]vv. 17-18[/link], [link]22-24[/link]; [link]2:2[/link]).
Or, judgment.

verse.text: For it has been made clear to me concerning you, my brothers, by those of [i]the household of[/i] [note]1[/note]Chloe, that there are [xref]a[/xref]strifes among you.
verse.note: A female name; hence, a sister in the Lord.

verse.text: Now I mean this, that each of you says, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]I am of [xref]b[/xref]Paul, and I of [xref]c[/xref]Apollos, and I of [xref]d[/xref]Cephas, and I of [note]2[/note]Christ.
verse.note: This is exactly the same as saying "I am a Lutheran," "I am a Wesleyan," "I am a Presbyterian," "I am an Episcopalian," "I am a Baptist," etc. All such designations should be condemned and rejected. They can be eliminated and terminated only by taking Christ as the unique center among all the believers.
To say "I am of Christ" in the way of excluding the apostles and their teachings or of excluding other believers is as divisive as to say "I am of" this or that.

verse.text: Is [note]1[/note]Christ [xref]a[/xref]divided? Was Paul [note]2[/note]crucified for you? Or were you [xref]b[/xref]baptized into the name of Paul?
verse.note: Christ is unique and is not divided. This unique and undivided Christ, taken as the unique center among all the believers, should be the termination of all divisions.

The One who was crucified for us should be the One to whom all the believers belong. This surely is Christ, not anyone else. All believers were baptized into the name, that is, into the person, of the crucified and resurrected Christ, issuing in an organic union with Him. His unique name and unique person cannot be replaced by the name and person of any of His servants.

verse.text: I thank God that I baptized none of you except [xref]a[/xref]Crispus and [xref]b[/xref]Gaius,
That no one may say that you were baptized into my name.
And I did baptize the household of [xref]a[/xref]Stephanas also; beyond that I do not know if I baptized any other.

For Christ did not [note]1[/note]send me to baptize but to announce the gospel, not in [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]wisdom of speech that the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]cross of Christ may not be made void.
verse.note: The apostle Paul was sent not to baptize people in a formal way but to preach the gospel, ministering Christ to others for the producing of the church as an expression of Christ to be the fullness of God ([link]Eph. 1:23[/link]; [link]3:19[/link]).
Referring to philosophical speculations.

The cross of Christ is the center in the accomplishment of God's New Testament economy, which is to have a church produced through the redemption of Christ. Paul preached Christ crucified ([link]v. 23[/link]; [link]2:2[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:1[/link]) and boasted in the cross of Christ ([link]Gal. 6:14[/link]). He did not preach the law with circumcision, which the Jews and some of the Jewish believers fought for ([link]Gal. 3:11[/link]; [link]5:11[/link]; [link]6:12-13[/link]), nor the philosophy that was promoted by the Greeks and some of the Gentile believers ([link]Col. 2:8[/link], [link]20[/link]). The cross of Christ abolished the ordinances of the law ([link]Eph. 2:15[/link]; [link]Col. 2:14[/link]), and we the believers have died to philosophy, an element of the world ([link]Col. 2:20[/link]). But Satan instigated the Judaizers and the Greek philosophers to preach their "isms" of worldly wisdom that the cross of Christ might be made void. The apostle Paul was alert in this matter. In dealing with the divisions among the Corinthian believers, which came mainly from the background of Jewish religion and Greek philosophy, the apostle stressed Christ and His cross. When Christ is taken to replace religious opinions and philosophical wisdom, and when His cross is working to deal with the flesh attached to any background, divisions will be terminated. The exaltation of natural preference and human wisdom cannot stand before Christ and His cross.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]word of the cross is to those who are [xref]b[/xref]perishing [xref]c[/xref]foolishness, but to us who are being [xref]d[/xref]saved it is the [xref]e[/xref]power of God.
verse.note: The same word in Greek that is translated [i]utterance[/i] in [link]v. 5[/link] (see note there). The word of the cross is the utterance, the speaking, the preaching, of the cross. Such preaching is despised and considered foolishness by those who are perishing, but it is honored and received as the power of God by us who are being saved. In his ministry Paul stressed the cross as the center of God's salvation ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]3:1[/link]; [link]5:11[/link], [link]24[/link]; [link]6:14[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:16[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:8[/link]; [link]3:18[/link]; [link]Col. 2:14[/link]).

verse.text: For it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"I will destroy the wisdom of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]wise, and the understanding of those who understand I will set aside."
verse.note: Referring in particular to the philosophical Greeks in Corinth, who considered themselves wise and prudent in holding to their philosophical wisdom. The apostle desired that they leave their philosophy and take the crucified Christ instead.

verse.text: Where is the [xref]a[/xref]wise? Where is the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]scribe? Where is the disputer of [xref]c[/xref]this age? Has not God made the wisdom of the world [xref]d[/xref]foolish?
verse.note: Like the wisdom of the scribes in [link]Isa. 33:18[/link], the wisdom of the Jewish scribes, who rejected the word of the cross, was considered futile by Paul.

verse.text: For since in the wisdom of God the world through its wisdom did not know God, God [note]1[/note]was well pleased through the [xref]a[/xref]foolishness of the [note]2[/note]preaching to [xref]b[/xref]save those who believe.
verse.note: Or, thought well.
I.e., the thing preached.

verse.text: For indeed Jews require [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]signs and Greeks seek wisdom,
verse.note: A sign is a miraculous token ([link]Matt. 12:38-39[/link]) given to substantiate what is preached. Religion needs signs, and the Jews continually required them. Wisdom pertains to philosophy and was constantly sought by the Greeks.

verse.text: But we [xref]a[/xref]preach [note]1[/note]Christ [xref]b[/xref]crucified, to Jews a [xref]c[/xref]stumbling block, and to Gentiles [xref]d[/xref]foolishness,
verse.note: Christ crucified — weak, despised, and rejected — was a stumbling block to the miracle-seeking religious Jews and foolishness to the wisdom-seeking philosophical Greeks, yet this Christ was just the One they both needed to solve all their problems dealt with in this book.

verse.text: But to [note]1[/note]those who are [xref]a[/xref]called, both [xref]b[/xref]Jews and Greeks, Christ the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]power of God and the [xref]d[/xref]wisdom of God.
verse.note: Referring to those who were chosen by God in eternity ([link]Eph. 1:4[/link]) and who believed in Christ in time ([link]Acts 13:48[/link]).

The crucified Christ preached by the apostles is the power of God and the wisdom of God. Wisdom is for planning, purposing; power is for carrying out, accomplishing, what is planned and purposed. In God's economy Christ is both.

verse.text: Because the [xref]a[/xref]foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men.
For consider your calling, brothers, that there are not many [xref]a[/xref]wise according to flesh, not many powerful, not many [note]1[/note]wellborn.
verse.note: Or, highborn, noble; i.e., born of a noble or royal family. The church of God is composed not mainly of the upper class but of the lowborn of the world and the despised. To appreciate the upper class is against God's mind and is a shame to the church.

verse.text: But God has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]chosen the foolish things of the [xref]b[/xref]world that He might shame those [i]who are[/i] wise, and God has chosen the weak things of the [xref]b[/xref]world that He might shame the things that are strong,
verse.note: God's calling ([link]vv. 24-26[/link]) is based on God's choosing, God's selection. Both are according to His purpose ([link]Rom. 9:11[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:9[/link]). God's choosing was ordained before the foundation of the world ([link]Eph. 1:4[/link]); His calling is accomplished in time, to carry out His choosing. God's calling and choosing are the initiation of the salvation of His predestinated people. We did not choose Him; He chose us. We did not call upon Him until He called us. He is the Initiator. All the glory should be to Him!

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]lowborn things of the world and the [note]2[/note]despised things God has chosen, things which [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]are not, that He might [xref]b[/xref]bring to nought the [note]4[/note]things which are,
verse.note: I.e., born of common people; in contrast to the wellborn in [link]v. 26[/link].
Or, contemptible. The Greek word is of the same root as the word for [i]counted as nothing[/i] in [link]Mark 9:12[/link].
I.e., are as if they have no existence. The lowborn and the despised are of no account in the world.

The repetition of [i]God has chosen[/i] three times in [link]vv. 27[/link] and [link]28[/link] unveils to us God's sovereign dealing with the three kinds of people of the world mentioned in [link]v. 26[/link] — the wise, the strong (the powerful), and the wellborn. The wellborn, "things which are," are counted much in the world but are brought to nought by God in His economy.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]So that no flesh may [xref]a[/xref]boast before God.
verse.note: This declares the reason for God's particular favor in His choosing us, that is, that no flesh, no human being, may have any boast, any glory, before Him.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]of Him you are [xref]b[/xref]in Christ Jesus, who became [xref]c[/xref]wisdom to us from God: both [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]righteousness and [xref]e[/xref]sanctification and [xref]f[/xref]redemption,
verse.note: What we believers, as the new creation, are and have in Christ is of God, not of ourselves. It is God who put us in Christ, transferring us from Adam into Christ. It is God who made Christ wisdom to us.

Christ became wisdom to us from God as three vital things in God's salvation: (1) righteousness (for our past), by which we have been justified by God, that we might be reborn in our spirit to receive the divine life ([link]Rom. 5:18[/link]); (2) sanctification (for our present), by which we are being sanctified in our soul, i.e., transformed in our mind, emotion, and will, with His divine life ([link]Rom. 6:19[/link], [link]22[/link]); and (3) redemption (for our future), i.e., the redemption of our body ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]), by which we will be transfigured in our body with His divine life to have His glorious likeness ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]). It is of God that we participate in such a complete and perfect salvation, which makes our entire being — spirit, soul, and body — organically one with Christ and makes Christ everything to us. This is altogether of God, not of ourselves, that we may boast and glory in Him, not in ourselves.

verse.text: That as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"He who boasts, let him [xref]b[/xref]boast in the Lord."

And I, when I [xref]a[/xref]came to you, brothers, came not according to [note]1[/note]excellence of [xref]b[/xref]speech or of wisdom, announcing to you the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]mystery of God.
verse.note: Or, superiority. Paul came to Corinth not to display his excellent, superior speech or philosophical wisdom in announcing the mystery of God.

Some ancient authorities read, testimony. What the apostle testified was the mystery of God, which is Christ as the embodiment of God and the church as the expression of Christ ([link]Rom. 16:25-26[/link]; [link]Col. 1:26-27[/link]; [link]2:2[/link]; [link]4:3[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:4-6[/link], [link]9[/link]).

verse.text: For I did [note]1[/note]not determine to know anything among you except [note]2[/note]Jesus [xref]a[/xref]Christ, and [note]2[/note]this One [xref]b[/xref]crucified.
verse.note: The crucified Christ was the unique subject, the center, the content, and the substance of the apostle's ministry. For this he did not determine to know anything but the all-inclusive Christ, and this One crucified, when he was going to minister the word of the testimony of God to the excellent-speech-exalting and wisdom-worshipping Greeks. What a determination! It should be a pattern to us all.

[i]Jesus Christ[/i] denotes the Lord's person. [i]This One crucified[/i] speaks of the example of the Lord's living, action, work, and way, indicating His humiliation and abasement. In order to overturn the pride of the Greeks in their elevated wisdom, Paul did not refer here to the Lord's resurrection in glory ([link]Luke 24:26[/link]) and His ascension in exaltation ([link]Acts 2:33[/link], [link]36[/link]).

verse.text: And I was with you in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]weakness and in [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fear and in much trembling;
verse.note: Referring to the apostle's physical weakness, which was due, perhaps, to his physical sufferings in his persecutions for the gospel. He did not display himself as a physically strong man while among the Greeks, who sought to be strong not only psychologically in their philosophies but also physically in their gymnastics.

Fear is the inward feeling; trembling is the outward appearance. The apostle was inwardly in fear of missing Christ in his ministry to the wisdom-seeking Greeks, and outwardly in trembling lest he be influenced by their prevailing aspiration for wisdom. By such fear and trembling he stood faithfully and steadfastly in his God-appointed ministry, according to the heavenly vision, avoiding any deviation. The religious Jews were proud of their traditional religion, and the philosophical Greeks were haughty in their worldly wisdom. In ministering Christ to both, the apostle was in fear and in much trembling. What a contrast between him and them!

verse.text: And my [xref]a[/xref]speech and my proclamation were not in [note]1[/note]persuasive words of wisdom but in demonstration of the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit and of [xref]c[/xref]power,
verse.note: Persuasive words of wisdom issue from the human mind; demonstration of the Spirit comes forth from the spirit. The apostle's speech and preaching were not from his mind with words of speculation but from his spirit with the release and exhibition of the Spirit and, hence, of power.

verse.text: In order that your faith would not [note]1[/note]stand in the [note]2[/note]wisdom of men but in the [xref]a[/xref]power of God.
verse.note: Lit., be.
The wisdom of men is the elementary philosophy; the power of God is the all-inclusive Christ ([link]1:24[/link]).

verse.text: But we do speak wisdom among those who are [xref]a[/xref]full-grown, yet a [xref]b[/xref]wisdom not of this age nor of the rulers of this age, who are being [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]brought to nought;
verse.note: I.e., destroyed (the same word as in [link]1:28[/link]).

verse.text: But we speak [note]1[/note]God's wisdom in a [xref]a[/xref]mystery, the [i]wisdom[/i] which has been hidden, which God [xref]b[/xref]predestined [note]2[/note]before the [xref]c[/xref]ages for our [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]glory,
verse.note: God's wisdom is Christ ([link]1:24[/link]), who is the hidden mystery ([link]Col. 1:26-27[/link]), predestined, predesignated, and foreordained before the ages for our glory.
I.e., in eternity.

Christ, who is the Lord of glory ([link]v. 8[/link]). Christ is our life today ([link]Col. 3:4[/link]) and our glory in the future ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]). To this glory God has called us ([link]1 Pet. 5:10[/link]), and into it He will bring us ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]). This is the goal of God's salvation.

verse.text: Which none of the [xref]a[/xref]rulers of this age have known; for if they had known, they would not have [xref]b[/xref]crucified the [xref]c[/xref]Lord of glory;

But as it is written, [xref]a[/xref]"Things which [note]1[/note]eye has not seen and ear has not heard and [i]which[/i] have not [xref]b[/xref]come up [note]2[/note]in man's heart; things which God has [xref]c[/xref]prepared for those who [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]love Him."
verse.note: The sphere of what the eye can see is narrow; the sphere of what the ear can hear is broader; and the sphere of what the heart can realize is without limitation. God in His wisdom (that is, in Christ) has ordained and prepared for us many deep and hidden things, such as justification, sanctification, and glorification. All these the human eye has never seen, the human ear has never heard, and the human heart has never realized.
Lit., on, or upon.

To realize and participate in the deep and hidden things God has ordained and prepared for us requires us not only to believe in Him but also to love Him. To fear God, to worship God, and to believe in God (that is, to receive God) are all inadequate; to love Him is the indispensable requirement. To love God means to set our entire being — spirit, soul, and body, with the heart, soul, mind, and strength ([link]Mark 12:30[/link]) — absolutely on Him, that is, to let our entire being be occupied by Him and lost in Him, so that He becomes everything to us and we are one with Him practically in our daily life. In this way we have the closest and most intimate fellowship with God, and we are able to enter into His heart and apprehend all its secrets ([link]Psa. 73:25[/link]; [link]25:14[/link]). Thus, we not only realize but also experience, enjoy, and fully participate in these deep and hidden things of God.

verse.text: But to us God has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]revealed [i]them[/i] through the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit, for the Spirit [note]2[/note]searches all things, even the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]depths of God.
verse.note: Different from [i]taught.[/i] To be taught is related to our mind; to have something revealed to us is related to our spirit. To realize the deep and hidden things God has prepared for us, our spirit is more necessary than our mind. When our entire being becomes one with God through loving Him in intimate fellowship, He shows us, in our spirit through His Spirit, all the secrets of Christ as our portion. This is to reveal the hidden things planned by His wisdom concerning Christ, which have never come up in man's heart.

The Greek word is used in reference to active research, implying accurate knowledge gained not by discovering but by exploring. The Spirit of God explores the depths of God concerning Christ and shows them to us in our spirit for our realization and participation.

Referring to the deep things of God, which are Christ in many aspects as our eternal portion, foreordained, prepared, and given to us freely by God. These have never arisen in man's heart but are revealed to us in our spirit by God's Spirit. Hence, in order to partake of them, we must be spiritual. We must move, act, and live in our spirit that we may enjoy Christ as everything to us.

verse.text: For who among men knows the things of man, except the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit of man which is in him? In the same way, the things of God also no one has known except the Spirit of God.
verse.note: The spirit of man is the deepest part of man's being. It has the faculty to penetrate the innermost region of the things of man, whereas the mind of man is capable of knowing only superficial things. So also, only the Spirit of God can know the deep things of God. The Corinthian believers had neglected the spirit of man and the Spirit of God, having turned instead to live in their mind by philosophy. Hence, this book shows that the proper experience of these two spirits is essential for the practice of the church life.

verse.text: But we have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]received not the spirit of the [xref]b[/xref]world but the [xref]c[/xref]Spirit which is from God, that we may [xref]d[/xref]know the [xref]e[/xref]things which have been graciously given to us by God;
verse.note: Praise the Lord that we, those who have been born of God by His Spirit, have received the Spirit of God. Hence, we are well able to know the deep things of God, which He has graciously given to us for our enjoyment.

verse.text: Which things also we speak, not in [xref]a[/xref]words taught by human wisdom but in words [xref]b[/xref]taught by the Spirit, [note]1[/note]interpreting spiritual things [note]2[/note]with spiritual [i]words.[/i]
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]mixing[/i] or [i]putting together,[/i] as in interpreting or expounding. It is common in the Septuagint: [link]Gen. 40:8[/link]; [link]41:12[/link], [link]15[/link].

The thought here is to speak spiritual things with spiritual words. The stress is not on the person to whom the speaking is done but on the means by which the spiritual things are spoken. The apostle spoke the spiritual things, which are the deep things of God concerning Christ, with spiritual words, which are the spiritual words taught by the Spirit.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]soulish man does [xref]b[/xref]not receive the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]things of the Spirit of God, for they are [xref]d[/xref]foolishness to him and he is [note]4[/note]not able to know [i]them[/i] because they are [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]discerned [note]6[/note]spiritually.
verse.note: [link]Verse 13[/link] stresses the spiritual means, that is, the spiritual words with which the spiritual things are spoken. [link]Verses 14[/link] and [link]15[/link] stress the spiritual object, that is, a spiritual man (not a soulish man), who is able to discern the spiritual things. Both the means and the object need to be spiritual. The spiritual things must be spoken with spiritual words to the spiritual man.

A soulish man is a natural man, one who allows his soul (including the mind, the emotion, and the will) to dominate his entire being and who lives by his soul, ignoring his spirit, not using his spirit, and even behaving as if he did not have a spirit ([link]Jude 19[/link]). Such a man does not receive the things of the Spirit of God, and he is not able to know them. Rather, he rejects them. The religious Jews, who required signs, and the philosophical Greeks, who sought wisdom ([link]1:22[/link]), were such natural men, to whom the things of the Spirit of God were foolishness ([link]1:23[/link]).
Referring to the deep things of God concerning Christ as our portion.
A soulish man does not have the constitutional capacity for spiritual perception. Hence, he is not able to know spiritual things.
Or, examined, investigated; and thus made clear as to the truth of the matter.

[i]Spiritually[/i] here refers to the spirit of man that is moved by the Spirit of God to fully exercise its function and thereby replace the human soul's rule and control over man. It is only by such a spirit that man can discern the things of the Spirit of God. A man who is ruled and controlled by his spirit is a spiritual man, as mentioned in the next verse. Since God is Spirit, all the things of the Spirit of God are spiritual. Therefore, to discern, to know, the things of the Spirit of God, man must use the human spirit ([link]John 4:24[/link]).

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spiritual man discerns all things, but he himself is discerned by no one.
verse.note: A spiritual man is one who denies his soul and does not live by his soul but allows his spirit, that is, his regenerated spirit, which is occupied and energized by the Spirit of God, to dominate his entire being. Furthermore, he lives by such a spirit, moving and acting according to it ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]). Such a spiritual person is able to discern the things of the Spirit of God because his constitutional capacity for spiritual perception is able to manifest its function.

verse.text: For who has known the [xref]a[/xref]mind of the Lord and will [xref]b[/xref]instruct Him? But we [note]1[/note]have the [xref]c[/xref]mind of Christ.
verse.note: Because we are organically one with Christ, we have all the faculties that He has. The mind is the faculty of intelligence, the understanding organ. We have such an organ, the mind of Christ; hence, we can know what He knows. We have not only the life of Christ but also the mind of Christ. Christ must saturate our mind from our spirit, making our mind one with His.

verse.text: And I, brothers, was not able to speak to you as to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spiritual men, but as to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fleshy, as to [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]infants in Christ.
verse.note: A spiritual man is one who does not behave according to the flesh or act according to the soulish life but lives according to the spirit, that is, his spirit mingled with the Spirit of God. Such a man is dominated, governed, directed, moved, and led by such a mingled spirit.

This is a stronger and more gross expression than [i]fleshly[/i] in [link]v. 3[/link]. [i]Fleshy[/i] denotes being made of flesh; [i]fleshly[/i] denotes being influenced by the nature of the flesh and partaking of the character of the flesh. In this verse the apostle considered the Corinthian believers to be totally of the flesh, to be made of the flesh, and to be just the flesh. What a strong word! Then in [link]v. 3[/link] the apostle condemned their behaving in jealousy and strife as fleshly, as being under the influence of their fleshly nature and partaking of the character of the flesh.[br][br]This book reveals clearly that a believer may be one of three kinds of men: (1) a spiritual man, living in his spirit under the anointing of the Holy Spirit ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:25[/link]); (2) a soulish man, living in his soul under the direction of the soul, the natural life ([link]2:14[/link]); or (3) a fleshy and fleshly man, being of the flesh and living in the flesh under the influence of the nature of the flesh. The Lord desires that all His believers take His grace to be the first kind of man — a spiritual man. This was the goal of this book: to motivate the Corinthian believers who were soulish, fleshy, and fleshly to aspire to the growth in life that they might become spiritual ([link]2:15[/link]; [link]3:1[/link]; [link]14:37[/link]). As we have been called by God into the fellowship of Christ ([link]1:9[/link]), who is now the life-giving Spirit ([link]15:45[/link]), and as we are one spirit with Him ([link]6:17[/link]), we can experience and enjoy Him only when we live in our spirit under the leading of the Holy Spirit. When we live in the soul or in the flesh, we cannot participate in Him or enjoy Him.

Although the Corinthian believers had received all the initial gifts in life and were lacking in none of them ([link]1:7[/link]), they did not grow in life after receiving them but remained infants in Christ, those who were not spiritual but fleshy. The apostle here pointed out their deficiency and their need, which was to grow in life to maturity, to be full-grown ([link]2:6[/link]; [link]Col. 1:28[/link]).

verse.text: I [note]1[/note]gave you [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]milk to drink, not [note]2[/note]solid [xref]b[/xref]food, for you were [xref]c[/xref]not yet able [i]to receive it.[/i] But [note]3[/note]neither yet now are you able,
verse.note: To give milk to drink or food to eat is to feed others. Feeding is a matter of life; it differs from teaching, which is a matter of knowledge. What the apostle ministered to the Corinthian believers seemed to be knowledge; actually, it was milk (not yet solid food), and it should have nourished them.
Milk is mainly for infants; solid food is for the mature. See notes [link book="Heb." chapter="5"]12[sup]3[/sup][/link] and [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 5[/link].
This indicates that the Corinthian believers were not growing in life; they were still not able to receive solid food.

verse.text: For you are still [xref]a[/xref]fleshly. For if there is [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]jealousy and [xref]c[/xref]strife among you, are you not fleshly and do you not walk [note]2[/note]according to [i]the manner of[/i] man?
verse.note: Jealousy and strife are expressions, characteristics, of the nature of the flesh. Hence, they show that those who are in the flesh are fleshly and that they walk according to the manner of man.

Every fallen man is just the flesh ([link]Rom. 3:20[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:16[/link] and note 2). Hence, to be according to the manner of man is to be according to the flesh. The jealousy and strife among the Corinthian believers show that they walked according to the flesh of the fallen man and not according to the human spirit regenerated by God. Hence, they were not spiritual but fleshly, and they walked not according to God but according to the manner of man.

verse.text: For when someone says, [xref]a[/xref]I am of Paul, and another, I of Apollos, are you not men [i]of flesh?[/i]
What then is Apollos? And what is Paul? [xref]a[/xref]Ministers through whom you believed, even as the Lord gave to [xref]b[/xref]each one [i]of them.[/i]
[xref]a[/xref]I [note]1[/note]planted, [xref]b[/xref]Apollos watered, but [xref]c[/xref]God caused the growth.
verse.note: To plant, to water, and to cause to grow are all related to the matter of life. This indicates that the believers are God's cultivated land ([link]v. 9[/link]) to grow Christ. The ministers of Christ can only plant and water. Only God can cause the growth. The Corinthian believers overesteemed the planter and the waterer and neglected the One who causes the growth. Hence, they did not grow in Christ as their life.[br][br]The Corinthian believers, under the prevailing influence of Greek philosophical wisdom, paid too much attention to knowledge, neglecting life. In this chapter Paul's intention was to turn their attention from knowledge to life, pointing out that to them he was a feeder and a planter; Apollos, a waterer; and God, the One who causes the growth. In [link]4:15[/link] he even told them that he was their spiritual father, who begot them in Christ through the gospel. From the view of life, the divine view, they were God's cultivated land to grow Christ. This was entirely a matter of life, a matter utterly missed by believers who are dominated by their soulish, natural life under the influence of their natural wisdom.

verse.text: So then [note]1[/note]neither is he who plants [xref]a[/xref]anything nor he who waters, but God who causes the growth.
verse.note: As far as the growth in life is concerned, all the ministers of Christ, whether planters or waterers, are nothing; God is everything. We must turn our eyes from them to God alone. This delivers us from the divisiveness that results from appreciating one minister of Christ above another.

verse.text: Now he who plants and he who waters are one, but [xref]a[/xref]each will receive his own [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]reward according to his own [xref]c[/xref]labor.
verse.note: The reward is an incentive to the ministers of Christ who labor by planting or watering on God's cultivated land.

verse.text: For we are [note]1[/note]God's [xref]a[/xref]fellow workers; you are God's [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]cultivated land, God's [xref]c[/xref]building.
verse.note: God too is a worker. While the ministers of Christ, His fellow workers, are working on His cultivated land, He too is working. What a privilege and glory that men can be God's fellow workers, working together with God on His cultivated land to grow Christ!

I.e., farm. The believers, who have been regenerated in Christ with God's life, are God's cultivated land, a farm in God's new creation to grow Christ that precious materials may be produced for God's building. Hence, we are not only God's cultivated land but also God's building. Corporately, we as the church of God have Christ planted in us. Christ must grow in us and, in the sense of this chapter, produce out of us not fruit but the precious materials of gold, silver, and precious stones for the building of God's habitation on earth. Thus, the building of God, the house of God, the church, is the increase of Christ, the enlargement of Christ in His unlimitedness.

verse.text: According to the [xref]a[/xref]grace of God given to me, as a wise [note]1[/note]master builder I have [xref]b[/xref]laid a [xref]c[/xref]foundation, and [xref]d[/xref]another [xref]e[/xref]builds upon [i]it.[/i] But let each man [note]2[/note]take heed how he [xref]f[/xref]builds upon [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]chief craftsman.[/i] In [link]Matt. 16:18[/link] the Lord said that He would build His church; yet here the apostle said that he was a builder, even a wise master builder. This indicates that the Lord builds the church not directly but through His ministers, even through every member of His Body, as revealed in [link]Eph. 4:16[/link]. Although in [link]vv. 5-7[/link] the apostle admitted that he was nothing, here he frankly and faithfully made clear that by the grace of God he was a wise master builder who had laid the unique foundation, Christ, for others to build upon.

The church, the house of God, must be built with gold, silver, and precious stones, precious materials produced from Christ's growing in us. Yet there is a great possibility that we may build with wood, grass, and stubble produced by us in the flesh. Hence, each of us, every member of the Body, must take heed how he builds, that is, with what material he builds.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]another foundation no one is able to lay besides [xref]b[/xref]that which is laid, which is Jesus [xref]c[/xref]Christ.
verse.note: As the Christ and the Son of the living God, the Lord Jesus is the unique foundation laid by God for the building of the church ([link]Matt. 16:16-18[/link]). No one can lay another foundation.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But if anyone builds upon the foundation [note]2[/note]gold, silver, precious stones, [note]3[/note]wood, grass, stubble,
verse.note: The foundation is unique, but the building may differ because different builders may use different materials. All the Corinthian believers had accepted Christ as the foundation. However, some Jewish believers among them attempted to build the church with their Judaistic attainments, and some Greek believers attempted to use their philosophical wisdom. They were not like the apostles, who built with their excellent knowledge and rich experiences of Christ. The intention of the apostle in this Epistle was to warn the believers not to build the church with the things of their natural background. They must learn to build with Christ, both in objective knowledge and in subjective experience, as Paul did.

Gold, silver, and precious stones signify the various experiences of Christ in the virtues and attributes of the Triune God. It is with these that the apostles and all spiritual believers build the church on the unique foundation of Christ. Gold may signify the divine nature of the Father with all its attributes, silver may signify the redeeming Christ with all the virtues and attributes of His person and work, and precious stones may signify the transforming work of the Spirit with all its attributes. All these precious materials are the products of our participation in and enjoyment of Christ in our spirit through the Holy Spirit. Only these are good for God's building.[br][br]As God's cultivated land with planting, watering, and growing, the church should produce plants; but the proper materials for the building of the church are gold, silver, and precious stones, all of which are minerals. Hence, the thought of transformation is implied here. We need not only to grow in life but also to be transformed in life, as revealed in [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link] and [link]Rom. 12:2[/link]. This corresponds with the thought in the Lord's parables in [link]Matt. 13[/link] concerning wheat, mustard seed, and meal (all of which are botanical) and the treasure hidden in the earth — gold and precious stones (minerals). See notes [link book="Matt." chapter="13"]31[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]33[sup]3[/sup][/link], and [link]44[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 13[/link].

Wood, grass, and stubble signify the knowledge, realization, and attainments that come from the believers' natural background (such as Judaism or other religions, philosophy, or culture) and the natural way of living (which is mainly in the soul and is the natural life). Wood, in contrast to gold, signifies the nature of the natural man; grass, in contrast to silver, signifies the fallen man, the man of the flesh ([link]1 Pet. 1:24[/link]), who has not been redeemed or regenerated by Christ; and stubble, in contrast to precious stones, signifies the work and living that issue from an earthen source and have not been transformed by the Holy Spirit. All these worthless materials are the product of the believers' natural man together with what they have collected from their background. In God's economy these materials are fit only to be burned ([link]v. 13[/link]).

verse.text: The work of each will become [xref]a[/xref]manifest; for [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]the day will declare [i]it,[/i] because it is revealed by [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]fire, and the fire itself will [xref]d[/xref]prove each one's work, of what sort it is.
verse.note: The day of Christ's second coming, when He will judge all His believers ([link]4:5[/link]; [link]Matt. 25:19-30[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:12[/link]).

The fire of the Lord's judgment ([link]Mal. 3:2[/link]; [link]4:1[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 1:7b-8[/link]; [link]Heb. 6:8[/link]), which will cause each believer's work to be manifest and will try and test his work. All the work of wood, grass, and stubble will be unable to stand that test and will be burned.

verse.text: If anyone's [note]1[/note]work which he has built upon [i]the foundation[/i] remains, he will receive a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]reward;
verse.note: The work that remains must be of gold, silver, and precious stones, the product of faithful ministers of Christ. Such a work will be rewarded by the coming and judging Lord.
The reward is based on the believer's work after he is saved. It differs from salvation, which is based on faith in the Lord and His redemptive work. See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link].

verse.text: If anyone's [note]1[/note]work is consumed, he will suffer [note]2[/note]loss, but he himself will be [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]saved, yet so as [note]4[/note]through [xref]b[/xref]fire.
verse.note: The work of wood, grass, and stubble, which is fit only to be burned.
Loss of reward, not of salvation. To suffer loss here does not mean to perish.

The salvation that we have received in Christ is not by our works ([link]Titus 3:5[/link]) and is eternal, unchangeable in nature ([link]Heb. 5:9[/link]; [link]John 10:28-29[/link]). Hence, those believers whose Christian works are not approved by the judging Lord and who suffer the loss of reward will still be saved. God's salvation as a free gift to all believers is for eternity, whereas the Lord's reward to those (not all) believers whose Christian works are approved by Him is for the kingdom age. The reward is an incentive for their Christian work. See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].

Although those believers whose Christian works are not approved by the Lord at His coming back will be saved, they will be saved so as through fire. [i]Through fire[/i] surely indicates punishment. However, this is altogether not the purgatory heretically taught by Catholicism in its superstitious twisting of this verse. Nevertheless, this word should be a solemn warning to us today concerning our Christian works.

verse.text: Do you not know that you are the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]temple of God, and [i]that[/i] the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit of God dwells in you?
verse.note: The Greek word denotes the inner temple. The temple of God here refers to the believers collectively in a certain locality, such as Corinth, whereas the temple of God in [link]v. 17[/link] refers to all the believers universally. The unique spiritual temple of God in the universe has its expression in many localities on earth. Each expression is the temple of God in that locality.[br][br]The temple of God is the explanation of God's building in [link]v. 9[/link]. God's building is not an ordinary building; it is the sanctuary of the holy God, the temple in which the Spirit of God dwells. We, the builders of such a holy temple, should realize this, that we may be careful to build not with the worthless materials of wood, grass, and stubble but with the precious materials of gold, silver, and precious stones, which correspond with God's nature and economy.

verse.text: If anyone [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]destroys the temple of God, God will [note]2[/note]destroy him; for the temple of God is [note]3[/note]holy, [i]and[/i] [note]4[/note]such are you.
verse.note: Or, ruins, corrupts, defiles, mars. To destroy the temple of God is to build with the worthless materials of wood, grass, and stubble, as described in [link]v. 12[/link]. This refers to certain Jewish believers who attempted to build the church with elements of Judaism, and to certain Greek believers who endeavored to bring philosophical elements into the building. All this tended to corrupt, ruin, defile, and mar the temple of God, that is, to destroy it. Using any doctrine that differs from the fundamental teachings of the apostles ([link]Acts 2:42[/link]) or any ways and efforts that contradict God's nature, Christ's redemptive work, and the Spirit's transforming work is to corrupt, ruin, defile, mar, and destroy the church of God.

This implies at least the punishment unveiled in [link]v. 15[/link]. All those who have corrupted, ruined, defiled, and marred the church of God by their heretical doctrines, divisive teachings, worldly ways, and natural efforts in building will suffer God's punishment.

Since the temple of God, the church, is holy, the materials, the ways, and the efforts by which we build it also must be holy, corresponding with God's nature, Christ's redemption, and the Spirit's transformation.

[i]Such[/i] refers to the holy temple. The emphasis here is on [i]holy,[/i] not on [i]temple.[/i] [link]Verse 16[/link] stresses the temple, whereas [link]v. 17[/link] emphasizes the holy characteristic of the temple, as a reminder to the common Corinthian believers that they should be holy, having the holy characteristic of the temple of God.

verse.text: Let no one [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]deceive himself; if anyone [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]thinks that he is [xref]c[/xref]wise among you in this age, let him [note]3[/note]become foolish that he may [note]4[/note]become wise.
verse.note: Both the Judaizing believers and the philosophizing Greek believers deceived themselves by bringing the elements of Judaism and Greek philosophy into the building up of the church.
The apostle's thought here centered mainly on those Greek believers who highly esteemed the wisdom of their philosophy ([link]1:22[/link]).
To become foolish here is to forsake the wisdom of philosophy and receive the simple word concerning Christ and His cross ([link]1:21[/link], [link]23[/link]).
To become wise here is to take the wisdom of God in making Christ everything to us ([link]1:24[/link], [link]30[/link]; [link]2:6-8[/link]).

verse.text: For the wisdom of this world is [xref]a[/xref]foolishness with God; for it is written, [xref]b[/xref]"He grasps the wise in their craftiness";
And again, [xref]a[/xref]"The Lord knows the reasonings of the wise, that they are [note]1[/note]vain."
verse.note: Meaning [i]aimless.[/i]

verse.text: So then let no one [xref]a[/xref]boast in men, for [xref]b[/xref]all things are yours,
Whether Paul or Apollos or Cephas or the world or [xref]a[/xref]life or death or things present or things to come; [note]1[/note]all are yours,
verse.note: All things, including the world and death, are ours and work for good to us ([link]Rom. 8:28[/link]). The Corinthian believers said that they were of Paul or Apollos or Cephas ([link]1:12[/link]), but Paul said that he, Apollos, and Cephas were of them; all were theirs. They were the church, and all these things are for the church. The church is for Christ, and Christ is for God.

verse.text: But you are [xref]a[/xref]Christ's, and Christ is [xref]b[/xref]God's.
A man should [note]1[/note]account us [note]2[/note]in this way, as [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]servants of Christ and [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]stewards of the [xref]c[/xref]mysteries of God.
verse.note: Or, reckon, measure, and classify.
The way described in [link]3:21-23[/link].
An attendant or appointed servant, an official servant appointed specifically for a certain purpose ([link]Acts 26:16[/link]).

The Greek word is of the same root as the word for [i]economy[/i] in [link]1 Tim. 1:4[/link] and [link]Eph. 1:10[/link]. It means [i]a dispensing[/i] steward, a household administrator, who dispenses the household supply to its members. The apostles were appointed by the Lord to be such stewards, dispensing God's mysteries, which are Christ as the mystery of God and the church as the mystery of Christ ([link]Col. 2:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:4[/link]), to the believers. This dispensing service, the stewardship, is the ministry of the apostles.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Here, furthermore, it is sought in stewards that one be found [xref]a[/xref]faithful.
verse.note: I.e., in the stewardship, the dispensing ministry.

verse.text: But to me it is a very small thing that I should be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]examined by you or by [note]2[/note]man's day; rather I do not even examine myself.
verse.note: Examined for judgment or in judgment.

Man's day of judgment is the present age, in which man judges (this judgment refers to man's examination). It is in contrast to the Lord's day ([link]3:13[/link]), which is the coming age, the kingdom age, in which the Lord will judge and in which the judgment will be the Lord's judgment.

verse.text: For I am conscious of nothing against myself; but I am not justified in this, but He who examines me is the Lord.

So then do not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]judge anything [note]2[/note]before the time, until the Lord [xref]b[/xref]comes, who will both bring to light the [xref]c[/xref]hidden things of darkness and make [xref]d[/xref]manifest the counsels of the hearts, and then there will be [xref]e[/xref]praise to each from God.
verse.note: Or, condemn.
I.e., before the Lord's day ([link]3:13[/link]).

verse.text: Now [note]1[/note]these things, brothers, I have [note]2[/note]transferred in figure to myself and [xref]a[/xref]Apollos for your sakes, that you may learn in us the matter of not [i]going[/i] beyond [note]3[/note]what has been written, that none of you may be [xref]b[/xref]puffed up on behalf of [xref]c[/xref]one, against the other.
verse.note: Referring to the things mentioned in the preceding passage, from [link]ch. 1[/link] to this chapter.

A term used for metaphoric expressions. The things written by the apostle in the preceding chapters, [link]chs. 1-3[/link], were applicable to all those who served the Lord, especially to the proud and divisive Corinthians. But for their sake, that is, according to their condition and for their benefit, Paul transferred these things to himself and Apollos, using himself and Apollos as figures, as he had said in [link]3:5-8[/link]. By doing so, he expected the puffed up Corinthians to understand and apply to themselves the comparison that he made.

This must refer to what had been written in the preceding chapters, such as "Was Paul crucified for you?" ([link]1:13[/link]) and "What then is Apollos? And what is Paul?" ([link]3:5[/link]). They were simply ministers of Christ, a planter and a waterer ([link]3:5-7[/link]). They were not Christ, who was crucified for the believers. They were not God, who causes the believers to grow. They should not be appraised beyond what they were. Otherwise, their appraisers, like the fleshly Corinthian believers, might be puffed up on behalf of one, against the other.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]who distinguishes you? And what do you have that you did not [xref]a[/xref]receive? And if you did receive [i]it,[/i] why do you boast as though not having received [i]it?[/i]
verse.note: It is God who distinguishes us from others. And what we have we received from God. Hence, all the glory should be ascribed to God, and we should boast in Him, not in ourselves or in any servants, such as Paul or Apollos, whom He has used.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Already you are filled; already you have become [xref]a[/xref]rich; you have reigned without us. And I would have it indeed that you did reign, that we also might reign with you.
verse.note: The Corinthian believers, proud of what they had obtained, became satisfied with what they had. They became self-sufficient and reigned independently of the apostles. This was altogether in themselves and in their flesh.

verse.text: For, I think, God has set forth us the apostles [note]1[/note]last [i]of all[/i] as [note]2[/note]doomed to [xref]a[/xref]death, because we have become a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]spectacle to the world, both to angels and to men.
verse.note: In Paul's time, when criminals fought with wild beasts in the amphitheater for the entertainment of the populace, they were exhibited last of all. Paul applied this figure to the apostles, who were set forth by God as last of all in His spectacle.
The apostles considered themselves criminals doomed to death before the world, unlike the Corinthians, who considered themselves kings destined to reign.

A metaphor, referring to the fights between criminals and wild beasts in the Roman amphitheater. The apostles became such a spectacle to the world, seen not only by men but also by angels. See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link].

verse.text: We are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fools because of Christ, but you are [xref]b[/xref]prudent in Christ; we are [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]weak, but you are strong; you are [note]3[/note]glorious, but we are [xref]d[/xref]dishonored.
verse.note: The apostles were willing to be foolish by forsaking their human wisdom for the sake of Christ. But the fleshly Corinthian believers remained prudent in their natural wisdom, while claiming that they were in Christ.

The apostles, while ministering Christ, appeared to be weak, for they used no strength or power of their natural being ([link]2:3[/link]). But the fleshly Corinthian believers were strong, seeking to be recognized as prominent among the believers by exercising their natural ability.
The Corinthian believers were glorious, or honorable, in a display of splendor. But the apostles were dishonored and despised by the glory-seeking Corinthians.

verse.text: Until the present hour we both [xref]a[/xref]hunger and thirst, and are naked and [xref]b[/xref]buffeted and wander without a home;
And we labor, [xref]a[/xref]working with our own [xref]b[/xref]hands. Reviled we [xref]c[/xref]bless; [xref]d[/xref]persecuted we endure;
[note]1[/note]Defamed we [note]2[/note]exhort. We have become as the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]offscouring of the world, the [note]3[/note]scum of all things, until now.
verse.note: Or, insulted, spoken to injuriously.
I.e., entreat with exhortation, consolation, and encouragement in order to appease.

[i]Offscouring[/i] and [i]scum[/i] are synonyms. Offscouring denotes that which is thrown away in cleansing; hence, refuse, filth. [i]Scum[/i] denotes that which is wiped off; hence, rubbish, refuse. Both terms are used metaphorically, especially regarding condemned criminals of the lowest class, who were cast into the sea or to the wild beasts in the amphitheater.

verse.text: It is not to [xref]a[/xref]shame you [i]that[/i] I write these things but to admonish [i]you[/i] as my beloved [xref]b[/xref]children.

For though you have ten thousand [note]1[/note]guides in Christ, yet [i]you do[/i] not [i]have[/i] many [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]fathers; for [xref]b[/xref]in Christ Jesus I have [xref]c[/xref]begotten you through the [xref]d[/xref]gospel.
verse.note: Lit., child-conductors; as in [link]Gal. 3:24-25[/link].

Guides, child-conductors, give instructions and directions to the children who are under their guardianship; fathers impart life to their children whom they beget. The apostle was such a father; he had begotten the Corinthian believers in Christ through the gospel, imparting the divine life into them so that they became children of God and members of Christ.

verse.text: I [note]1[/note]exhort you therefore, Become [xref]a[/xref]imitators of me.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Because of this I have sent [xref]a[/xref]Timothy to you, who is my beloved and faithful [xref]b[/xref]child in the Lord, who will remind you of my [note]1[/note]ways which are in Christ, even as I teach [note]2[/note]everywhere in every [xref]c[/xref]church.
verse.note: These were the ways in which the apostle conducted himself as he taught the saints in every church.

This expression indicates two things: (1) that the apostle's teaching was the same universally, not varying from place to place; and (2) that [i]everywhere[/i] equals [i]every church,[/i] and [i]every church, everywhere.[/i]

verse.text: Now some have become [xref]a[/xref]puffed up as though I were not coming to you.
But I will [xref]a[/xref]come to you shortly, if the Lord [xref]b[/xref]wills, and I will ascertain not the speech of those who are puffed up but the power.
For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of God is not in speech but in [xref]b[/xref]power.
verse.note: This refers to the church life, implying that in the sense of authority the church in this age is the kingdom of God.

verse.text: What do you want? Should I [xref]a[/xref]come to you with a [note]1[/note]rod or in love and a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]spirit of [xref]c[/xref]meekness?
verse.note: This word was spoken to the Corinthian believers on the basis of the consideration that the apostle was their spiritual father. As such, he had the position and responsibility to chastise his children.

The apostle's regenerated spirit indwelt by and mingled with the Holy Spirit. The spirit of meekness is one that is saturated with the meekness of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 10:1[/link]) and, hence, expresses the virtue of Christ.

verse.text: It is actually reported that there is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fornication among you, and such fornication that [i]does[/i] not even [i]occur[/i] among the Gentiles, that someone has his [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]stepmother.
verse.note: The first problem, dealt with in [link]chs. 1-4[/link], is the matter of division, which is related mainly to the natural life of the soul. The second problem, dealt with in [link]ch. 5[/link], the second section of the book, is the sin of fornication, which is related to the lust of the flesh. This problem, involving incest with one's stepmother, is morally more gross than the former. The former pertains to the strife that comes from pride; the latter is a gross sin that comes from lust.
Lit., father's wife.

verse.text: And you are [xref]a[/xref]puffed up? And have you not rather [xref]b[/xref]mourned, that the one who has done this deed might be [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]removed from your midst?
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For I, on my part, though being absent in the body but present [note]1[/note]in the [xref]a[/xref]spirit, have already judged, as if being present, him who has thus done this,
verse.note: The apostle, as a spiritual person, behaved in his spirit, in contrast to the Corinthians, who behaved either in the soul or in the flesh. Although he was absent from them in the body, he was still present with them in the spirit, exercising his spirit to judge the evil person among them.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]In the [xref]a[/xref]name of our Lord Jesus, when you and [note]2[/note]my [xref]b[/xref]spirit have been assembled, [note]1[/note]with the [xref]c[/xref]power of our Lord Jesus,
verse.note: Both [i]in the name of our Lord Jesus[/i] and [i]with the power of our Lord Jesus[/i] modify [i]deliver[/i] in [link]v. 5[/link]. The apostle, in his spirit, applied the mighty name of the Lord with His power to deliver the evil person to Satan.
The apostle's spirit was so strong that it attended the meeting of the Corinthian believers. His spirit was assembled with them to carry out his judgment upon the evil person.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]To [xref]a[/xref]deliver such a one to [xref]b[/xref]Satan for the [note]2[/note]destruction of his [note]3[/note]flesh, [note]4[/note]that his spirit may be saved in the [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]day of the Lord.
verse.note: To deliver a sinful person to Satan is for discipline.
This refers mainly to the affliction of a certain disease ([link]2 Cor. 12:7[/link]; [link]Luke 13:16[/link]).
[i]Flesh[/i] here refers to the lustful body, which should be destroyed.

This sinful one among the Corinthian believers was a brother who had been saved once for eternity ([link]John 10:28-29[/link]). He could never perish because of any sin. However, because of his sinfulness he needed to be disciplined by the destruction of his sinful flesh, that he might be kept in a condition in which his spirit could be saved in the day of the Lord.
See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: Your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]boasting is not good. Do you not know that a [note]2[/note]little [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]leaven leavens the whole lump?
verse.note: Or, glorying. In spite of the confusion and the presence of the gross sin of incest among them, the Corinthian believers were boasting and glorying. The apostle's Epistle should have humbled them by pointing out the sinful things among them, thus making them realize that their boasting was not good.

The apostle's thought here might have been that there was no need to have a sin as gross as that which existed among them; just a little leaven, a little sin, leavens and corrupts the whole lump, the whole church.
See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 13[/link].

verse.text: Purge out the old leaven that you may be a [note]1[/note]new lump, even as you are unleavened; for our [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Passover, Christ, also has been sacrificed.
verse.note: Lit., young, new in time. See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in Col. 3[/link]. The new lump refers to the church, composed of the believers in their new nature.

This indicates that the apostle considered the believers God's chosen people, who have had their Passover, as typified by the one in [link]Exo. 12[/link]. In this Passover, Christ is not only the Passover lamb but also the entire Passover. To be our Passover, He was sacrificed on the cross that we might be redeemed and reconciled to God. Thus, we may enjoy Him as a feast before God. In this feast no leaven is allowed to be present. Sin and the redeeming Christ cannot go together.

verse.text: So then let us [xref]a[/xref]keep the [note]1[/note]feast, not with old [xref]b[/xref]leaven, neither with the leaven of [xref]c[/xref]malice and evil, but with the [xref]d[/xref]unleavened [i]bread[/i] of sincerity and truth.
verse.note: The feast here refers to the Feast of Unleavened Bread as the continuation of the Passover ([link]Exo. 12:15-20[/link]). It lasted for seven days, a period of completion, signifying the entire period of our Christian life, from the day of our conversion to the day of rapture. This is a long feast, which we must keep not with the sin of our old nature, the old leaven, but with unleavened bread, which is the Christ of our new nature as our nourishment and enjoyment. Only He is the life supply of sincerity and truth, absolutely pure, without mixture, and full of reality. The feast is a time for the enjoyment of the banquet. The entire Christian life should be such a feast, such an enjoyment of Christ as our banquet, the rich supply of life.

verse.text: I wrote to you in my letter [xref]a[/xref]not to [note]1[/note]mingle with fornicators,
verse.note: Or, mix, associate. So also in [link]v. 11[/link].

verse.text: [i]But[/i] not altogether with the [xref]a[/xref]fornicators of this world, or with the covetous and rapacious, or idolaters, since then you would have to go [xref]b[/xref]out of the world.

But now I have written to you not to mingle with anyone who is called a [xref]a[/xref]brother, if he is a [note]1[/note]fornicator or a covetous man or an [xref]b[/xref]idolater or a reviler or a drunkard or a rapacious man, with such a one [xref]c[/xref]not even to eat.
verse.note: The evil persons mentioned in this verse are not those who have simply committed a certain sin, but those who live in that sin and remain in it, refusing to repent. To remove such a one is not just to remove a sin from the church but to judge and remove a sinful person so that the church will not be leavened by his presence.

verse.text: For what have I to do with judging those who are [xref]a[/xref]outside [i]the church?[/i] Do you not [xref]b[/xref]judge those who are within [i]the church?[/i]
But those who are outside, God will judge. [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Remove the evil man from among yourselves.
verse.note: I.e., cut him off from the fellowship of the church, as typified by the separating of a leper from the people of God ([link]Lev. 13:45-46[/link]).

verse.text: Does any one of you who has a [note]1[/note]case against another dare to be judged before the [note]2[/note]unrighteous and not before the saints?
verse.note: The third problem dealt with by this Epistle is the matter of one brother going to law against another ([link]vv. 1-11[/link]). This is not a sin like division, initiated by the soul, nor a gross sin like incest, carried out by the lustful body. This is a case of one claiming his legal rights, being unwilling to suffer wrong, unwilling to learn the lesson of the cross.
The unbelievers, who are unrighteous, unjust, before God.

verse.text: Or do you not know that the saints will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]judge the world? And if the world is judged by you, are you unworthy of the [note]2[/note]smallest [note]3[/note]judgments?
verse.note: In the coming kingdom age the overcoming saints will rule over the nations of the world ([link]Heb. 2:5-6[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link]).
Judgments carried out by a number of saints who judge cases among themselves. The judging of such cases is trifling compared to the ruling of the world.
Lit., tribunals.

verse.text: Do you not know that we will [note]1[/note]judge angels, not to mention things of this life?
verse.note: [i]Things of this life[/i] indicates that judgment over the angels by the saints will be in the future, not in this age. This probably refers to the judgment over the angels that is revealed in [link]2 Pet. 2:4[/link] and [link]Jude 6[/link]. The angels mentioned in these verses and those referred to in [link]Eph. 2:2[/link]; [link]6:12[/link]; and [link]Matt. 25:41[/link] must be the evil angels. Thus, in the future we, the believers of Christ, will judge not only the human world but also the angelic world.

verse.text: If then you hold [xref]a[/xref]judgments over things of this life, do you seat [i]as judges[/i] [note]1[/note]those who are of no account in the church?
verse.note: The unbelievers, who are of no account in the church.

verse.text: I say [i]this[/i] to your [xref]a[/xref]shame. So there is no one wise among you, who will be able to discern between his [xref]b[/xref]brothers?
But brother [note]1[/note]goes to court with brother, and this before [xref]a[/xref]unbelievers.
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]goes to court[/i] is the same as the word for [i]to be judged[/i] in [link]v. 1[/link].

verse.text: Already then it is altogether a [note]1[/note]defeat to you that you have [note]2[/note]lawsuits with one another. Why not [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]rather be wronged? Why not [note]3[/note]rather be defrauded?
verse.note: Implying a defect, fault, loss, falling short (in the inheriting of the kingdom of God — [link]v. 9[/link]).
The Greek word has the same root as the word for [i]goes to court[/i] in the preceding verse.
Willingness to be wronged or defrauded is willingness to suffer loss, to learn the lesson of the cross, to keep the virtue of Christ at some cost.

verse.text: But you wrong and [xref]a[/xref]defraud, and this [i]your[/i] brothers.

Or do you not know that the unrighteous will not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be [xref]b[/xref]led astray; neither [xref]c[/xref]fornicators nor idolaters nor adulterers nor effeminate nor [xref]d[/xref]homosexuals
verse.note: To inherit the kingdom in the next age is a reward to the saints who seek righteousness ([link]Matt. 5:10[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]6:33[/link]). See notes [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link], [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 5[/link], [link]5[sup]3[/sup] in Eph. 5[/link], and [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].

verse.text: Nor thieves nor the covetous, not drunkards, not revilers, not the rapacious will inherit the kingdom of God.
