And these things were some of you; but you were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]washed, but you were [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sanctified, but you were [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]justified in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ and in the Spirit of our God.
verse.note: In contrast to the washing, sanctifying, and justifying in [link]1 John 1:7[/link], [link]Heb. 10:29[/link], and [link]Rom. 3:24-25[/link], the washing, sanctifying, and justifying here are not by the blood in an objective way. They are the subjective washing of regeneration as in [link]Titus 3:5[/link], the subjective sanctifying by the Spirit as in [link]Rom. 15:16[/link], and the subjective justifying in the Spirit as in this verse. All these items of God's salvation were accomplished in us in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ (i.e., in the person of the Lord, in an organic union with the Lord through faith) and in the Spirit of God (i.e., in the power and realization of the Holy Spirit). First, we were washed from the sinful things; second, we were sanctified, separated unto God, transformed by God; and third, we were justified, accepted, by God.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]All things are [note]2[/note]lawful to me, but not all things are [note]3[/note]profitable; all things are [note]2[/note]lawful to me, but I will not be [note]4[/note]brought under the power of anything.
verse.note: The fourth matter dealt with by this Epistle is the abuse of freedom in foods and in the body ([link]vv. 12-20[/link]). Foods for man to exist and sex (pertaining to the body) for man to propagate are both necessary and ordained by God. Man has the right to use them. However, he should not abuse them, nor should he be under their power, controlled and enslaved by them. Abusive eating, such as the eating of things sacrificed to idols, stumbles the weak brothers ([link]8:9-13[/link]; [link]10:28-30[/link], [link]32[/link]), and excessive eating damages our body. Both foods and our stomach will be done away with; God will bring both to nothing. The abuse of sex is fornication. Not only is it condemned by God; it also destroys our body ([link]v. 18[/link]), which is for the Lord.
Lit., under my authority (of choice to do); hence, permissible, allowable, lawful.
Advantageous (not merely convenient), good, worthwhile.

Lit., brought under the authority. This means that all things were under Paul's authority, but he would not be brought under the authority of anything, and that all things were permissible, allowable, lawful to him, but he would not be ruled (enslaved) or brought under the authority, the control, of any. [link]Verse 12[/link] may be considered a proverb that governed the apostle's dealings with some problems mentioned in the following section, [link]6:13-11:1[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Foods are for the [xref]a[/xref]stomach, and the stomach for foods; but God will bring to [xref]b[/xref]nought both it and them. But the [note]2[/note]body is not for fornication but [xref]c[/xref]for the Lord, and the Lord [xref]d[/xref]for the body.
verse.note: Foods and the stomach are for the existence of the body. By themselves they do not mean anything; God will bring them to nothing.

Our body was created for the Lord, and the Lord within us is for our body. He feeds it with material food ([link]Psa. 103:5[/link]) and gives it His resurrection life ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link]), which swallows its death element along with its weakness and sickness. Eventually, He will transfigure it, conforming it to His glorious body. We should not abuse it by committing fornication.

verse.text: And God has both [xref]a[/xref]raised up the Lord and will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]raise us up through His [xref]c[/xref]power.
verse.note: God raised up the Lord bodily. Our body is destined to participate in the Lord's glorious body in resurrection ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]) and to be raised incorruptible ([link]15:52[/link]). This will be the redemption of our body ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]). Even now the Spirit of the resurrected Christ, who dwells in us, gives life to our body ([link]Rom. 8:11[/link]), making it a member of Christ ([link]v. 15[/link]) and a temple of God indwelt by His Holy Spirit ([link]v. 19[/link]).

verse.text: Do you not know that your bodies are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]members of Christ? Shall I then take the members of Christ and make [i]them[/i] members of a prostitute? [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Absolutely not!
verse.note: Because we are organically united with Christ ([link]v. 17[/link]), and because Christ dwells in our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]) and makes His home in our heart ([link]Eph. 3:17[/link]), our entire being, including our purified body, becomes a member of Him. Hence, to practice such membership we need to offer our body to Him ([link]Rom. 12:1[/link], [link]4-5[/link]).
Lit., May it not happen!

verse.text: Or do you not know that he who is joined to a prostitute is one body? For He says, [xref]a[/xref]"The two shall be one flesh."
But he who is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]joined to the Lord is [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]one spirit.
verse.note: This refers to the believers' organic union with the Lord through believing into Him ([link]John 3:15-16[/link]). This union is illustrated by that of the branches with the vine ([link]John 15:4-5[/link]). It is a matter not only [i]of[/i] life but [i]in[/i] life (the divine life). Such a union with the resurrected Lord can only be in our spirit.

This indicates the mingling of the Lord as the Spirit with our spirit. Our spirit has been regenerated by the Spirit of God ([link]John 3:6[/link]), who is now in us ([link]v. 19[/link]) and is one with our spirit ([link]Rom. 8:16[/link]). This is the realization of the Lord, who became the life-giving Spirit through resurrection ([link]15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]) and who is now with our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). This mingled spirit is often referred to in Paul's Epistles, e.g., in [link]Rom. 8:4-6[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Flee [xref]b[/xref]fornication. Every [note]1[/note]sin which a man may do is outside the body, but he who commits fornication sins against his own body.
verse.note: Lit., result of sinning; the same word as for [i]sins[/i] in [link]Mark 3:28[/link] and [link]Rom. 3:25[/link].

verse.text: Or do you not know that your [xref]a[/xref]body is a [xref]b[/xref]temple of the [note]1[/note]Holy Spirit [xref]c[/xref]within you, whom you have [xref]d[/xref]from God, and you are [xref]e[/xref]not your own?
verse.note: The Holy Spirit is in our spirit ([link]Rom. 8:16[/link]), and our spirit is within our body. Hence, our body becomes a temple, a dwelling place, of the Holy Spirit.

verse.text: For you have been [xref]a[/xref]bought with a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]price. So then [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]glorify God in your [xref]d[/xref]body.
verse.note: The precious blood of Christ ([link]Acts 20:28[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]; [link]Rev. 5:9[/link]).

This is to allow God, who dwells in us ([link]1 John 4:13[/link]), to occupy and saturate our body and express Himself through our body as His temple, especially in the two matters of eating and marriage, according to the context of this section, [link]6:13-11:1[/link]. For this we need to exercise a severe and strict control over our body, bringing it into subjection ([link]9:27[/link]) and presenting it to God as a living sacrifice ([link]Rom. 12:1[/link]).

verse.text: Now concerning the [note]1[/note]things of which you wrote: It is [xref]a[/xref]good for a man not to touch a woman.
verse.note: The fifth problem in this Epistle — the matter of marriage — is dealt with here. It is treated according to the principles established in the preceding section ([link]6:12-20[/link]).

verse.text: But because of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fornication, let each man have his own wife, and let each woman have her own husband.
verse.note: Lit., fornications.

verse.text: Let the [xref]a[/xref]husband render to his wife that which is due, and likewise also the wife to the husband.
The [xref]a[/xref]wife does not have authority over her own body, but the husband does; and likewise the husband also does not have authority over his own body, but the wife does.

Do not deprive each other, [xref]a[/xref]except by agreement for a time that you may [note]1[/note]devote yourselves to prayer, and [i]then[/i] be together again, that [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Satan may not [xref]c[/xref]tempt you because of your [note]3[/note]lack of [xref]d[/xref]self-control.
verse.note: Lit., have leisure for, be free for; hence, give oneself to. Prayer requires us to be free from persons, matters, and things. The prayer that requires staying away from the spouse for a time must be special and of great importance.
The tempter, Satan, is crouching to capture the believers.
The same Greek word is translated [i]self-indulgence[/i] in [link]Matt. 23:25[/link].

verse.text: But this I say by way of [note]1[/note]concession, not by way of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]command.
verse.note: This implies that the apostle in his teaching had authority to give commands to the believers.

verse.text: Yet I [note]1[/note]wish all men to be even as I am myself; but each has his own [note]2[/note]gift from God, one in this way, the other in that.
verse.note: Since the apostle Paul was absolute for the Lord and His economy, he wished that all men would be like him. He desired that they not marry but remain as he was ([link]v. 8[/link]) so that they also might be absolute for the Lord's interests without any distraction ([link]vv. 33-34a[/link]). In this wish he expressed the Lord's aspiration concerning His called ones.
For a believer in Christ to be able not to marry is a gift from God ([link]Matt. 19:10-12[/link]). For those who have not received such a gift, it is better to marry ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: But I say to the unmarried and to the widows, It is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]good for them if they remain even as I am.
verse.note: This was the apostle's wish and opinion in his earlier ministry ([link]vv. 7[/link], [link]25[/link], [link]40[/link]). Later, after witnessing the actual outcome, he charged young widows to marry ([link]1 Tim. 5:11-15[/link] and note [link]14[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: But if they do not have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]self-control, let them [xref]b[/xref]marry; for it is better to marry than to burn [i]with desire.[/i]
verse.note: Or, continency. The same Greek word is used in [link]9:25[/link] regarding athletes' abstaining from sensual indulgences during preparation for the games.

verse.text: But to the married [note]1[/note]I charge, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]not I but the Lord, A [xref]b[/xref]wife must not be [xref]c[/xref]separated from [i]her[/i] husband
verse.note: The Old Testament principle of speaking for God (prophesying) is, "Thus says the Lord" ([link]Isa. 10:24[/link]; [link]50:1[/link]; [link]Jer. 2:2[/link]; [link]Ezek. 2:4[/link]). But the New Testament principle of incarnation is, "I [the speaker] charge." The speaker and the Lord are one. Hence, Paul also said, "Not I but the Lord." The Greek word for [i]charge[/i] may be translated [i]enjoin[/i] or [i]command.[/i]

This indicates two things: (1) that the apostle was one with the Lord; hence, what he commanded, the Lord commanded; and (2) that his commands were the Lord's. The Lord had commanded in [link]Matt. 5:31-32[/link] and [link]19:3-9[/link] what the apostle commanded here. Divorce is altogether not allowed by the Lord.

verse.text: (But if indeed she is separated, let her [note]1[/note]remain unmarried or be reconciled to her husband), and a [xref]a[/xref]husband must not leave [i]his[/i] wife.
verse.note: Whether separated or divorced, one should not remarry but should expect reconciliation and wait for it.

verse.text: But to the rest [note]1[/note]I say, I, [xref]a[/xref]not the Lord, If any brother has an unbelieving wife and she consents to dwell with him, he must not [xref]b[/xref]leave her;
verse.note: Again, this is based on the New Testament principle of incarnation. Although he followed to say, "I, not the Lord," whatever the apostle said in the succeeding verses is part of the divine revelation of the New Testament. It was his opinion in the Lord, not the Lord's commandment, yet it still expressed the Lord's mind.

verse.text: And a wife who has an unbelieving husband, and [i]if[/i] he consents to dwell with her, must not leave her husband.
For the unbelieving husband is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctified by the wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the brother; otherwise your children are unclean, but now they are holy.
verse.note: To be sanctified is to be made holy, separated unto God for His purpose. As the believing wife is of the Lord and for the Lord, so her unbelieving husband is made holy, sanctified, separated unto God, because he is for his wife, who is of and for God. It is similar to the situation in which the temple and the altar make the common things holy when the latter are attached to them ([link]Matt. 23:17[/link], [link]19[/link]). The same principle applies to the unbelieving wife and the children. For the unbeliever to be sanctified in this way does not mean that he is saved, just as the sanctification of food through the saints' prayer has nothing to do with salvation ([link]1 Tim. 4:5[/link]). A saved person is a sanctified person, a saint. Anyone who is attached to him and is for him is made holy because of him.

verse.text: But if the unbelieving one separates, let him separate; the brother or the sister is [note]1[/note]not enslaved in such [i]cases,[/i] [note]2[/note]but God has called us in [xref]a[/xref]peace.
verse.note: Not under bondage but freed from his or her marriage to an unbeliever, when the unbeliever leaves the believer.

God in His salvation has called us to Him in the sphere and element of peace. Hence, we should live in this peace. If the unbelieving party in our marriage desires to leave, we should allow it. But that we may live in the peace in which God has called us, God does not want us to initiate any separation as long as the other party consents to remain ([link]v. 13[/link]). The succeeding verses (through [link]v. 24[/link]) are based on this: that God has called us in peace.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For [note]2[/note]how do you know, O [xref]a[/xref]wife, whether you will [xref]b[/xref]save your husband? Or how do you know, O husband, whether you will save your wife?
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that [link]vv. 16-24[/link] are an explanation of the preceding word, that is, that God has called us in peace. To remain in this peace we must keep the word in [link]vv. 16-24[/link].

Since we do not know whether we will save our unbelieving husband or wife, we should not insist that he or she remain with us or that he or she leave. God wants us to remain in the status in which He called us ([link]vv. 20[/link], [link]24[/link]), not to initiate any change. Therefore, we should leave the entire matter to the unbelieving party.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]However as the Lord has apportioned to each one, as God has [xref]a[/xref]called each one, so let him walk. And so I direct in all the [xref]b[/xref]churches.
verse.note: This word strongly charges us to remain in the status of marriage in which God called us ([link]vv. 20[/link], [link]24[/link]).

verse.text: Was anyone called having been circumcised? He need not [note]1[/note]efface [i]it.[/i] Has anyone been called in uncircumcision? He need not be [xref]a[/xref]circumcised.
verse.note: This is to efface the mark of circumcision so that the body may be restored to its original condition.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing, but the [xref]b[/xref]keeping of God's commandments [i]is what counts.[/i]
verse.note: Both circumcision and uncircumcision are outward matters and do not count in reality; only the keeping of God's commandments is what counts ([link]Gal. 5:6[/link]; [link]6:15[/link]; [link]Rom. 2:25-29[/link]).

verse.text: Each one, in the [xref]a[/xref]calling in which he was called, in this let him remain.

Were you called as a [xref]a[/xref]slave? [note]1[/note]Let it not concern you; [note]2[/note]but even if you are able to become [xref]b[/xref]free, [xref]c[/xref]use [i]your status as a slave[/i] rather.
verse.note: Or, do not care for it, let it not trouble you. Since the believers have the Lord as the sufficient grace ([link]2 Cor. 12:9[/link]), they should not be troubled by anything.

[i]But[/i] here conjoins [i]Let it not concern you[/i] and [i]use your status as a slave rather.[/i] It means that a slave who has been called by the Lord should not care for or be troubled by his slavery, but rather should use this status, that is, remain in this status with God ([link]v. 24[/link]) for God's glory. Even if he is able to become free, he should remain in his status as a slave. This corresponds with the basic concept of the apostle's instruction, as explicitly expressed in [link]vv. 20[/link] and [link]24[/link]. However, this part of the verse may be rendered as follows: "but, even if you are able to become free, take advantage of it rather." The apostle's point in this passage is that the believers should not be influenced by their outward status. Either to remain in slavery or to have freedom is all right, as long as it is with God.

verse.text: For the slave who has been called in the Lord is the [note]1[/note]Lord's freedman; likewise the free man who has been called is [note]1[/note]Christ's [xref]a[/xref]slave.
verse.note: The Lord's calling does not change the outward status of His believers, but it does change their inward reality: one who is a slave outwardly is changed to a freedman inwardly, and one who is a free man outwardly is changed to a slave inwardly.

verse.text: You were [xref]a[/xref]bought with a [note]1[/note]price; do not be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]slaves of men.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
Believers inwardly should be slaves only of Christ; they should not become slaves of men.

verse.text: Each one, brothers, in what [i]status[/i] he was [xref]a[/xref]called, in this let him remain [note]1[/note]with God.
verse.note: After being called, the believers do not need to change their outward status, but they do need to have a change in their inward condition, that is, from being without God to being with God, in order to be one with God and have God with them in their status, whatever it may be.

verse.text: Now concerning [xref]a[/xref]virgins I have [xref]b[/xref]no [note]1[/note]commandment of the Lord, but I give [note]1[/note][i]my[/i] [xref]c[/xref]opinion as one who has been shown [xref]d[/xref]mercy by the Lord to be [xref]e[/xref]faithful.
verse.note: A wife should not be separated from her husband. This, the apostle said, is the Lord's commandment ([link]v. 10[/link]). Concerning virgins' not marrying, he said that he had no commandment of the Lord, but he gave his opinion in the succeeding verses. He dared to do this because he had been shown mercy by the Lord to be faithful to the Lord's interests, and he was truly one with the Lord. His opinion expressed the Lord's desire. This again is based on the New Testament principle of incarnation.

verse.text: I consider then that this is good because of the [note]1[/note]present [note]2[/note]necessity, that [i]it is[/i] [xref]a[/xref]good for a man to be as he is.
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]present[/i] may mean also that the presence of a certain thing foreshadows and inaugurates something to come. Here the present necessity, or distress, indicates that more anguish is to come, as prophesied by the Lord in [link]Matt. 24:8[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]21[/link].

Or, pressure, constraint; hence, distress, anguish. The word refers to the necessities of life in the present age, the demand of which constrains and presses people and becomes a distress and anguish to them. See note [link]10[sup]3[/sup] in 2 Cor. 12[/link].

verse.text: Have you been bound to a wife? Do not seek a release. Have you been released from a wife? Do not seek a wife.

But even if you do [xref]a[/xref]marry, you have [xref]b[/xref]not sinned; and if the virgin marries, she has not sinned; but such ones will have affliction in the flesh, and I am trying to spare you.
But this I say, brothers, the time is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]shortened. Henceforth both those who have wives should be as though they had none,
verse.note: The concept that at Paul's time the time was shortened was due to the fact that the long period between the latter part of the first century and Christ's second coming was not revealed to the earlier apostles ([link]Matt. 24:36[/link]). They expected the Lord to return in their generation.

verse.text: And those who weep as though they did not weep, and those who rejoice as though they did not rejoice, and those who buy as though they did not possess,
And those who use the world as though they did not abuse [i]it;[/i] for the fashion of this world is [xref]a[/xref]passing away.
But I desire you to be without [xref]a[/xref]care. The unmarried [xref]b[/xref]cares for the things of the Lord, how he may please the Lord;
But he who has married [xref]a[/xref]cares for the things of the world, how he may please his wife,

And is [note]1[/note]distracted. Both the unmarried woman and the virgin care for the things of the Lord, that she may be holy both in body and in spirit; but she who has married [xref]a[/xref]cares for the things of the world, how she may please her husband.
verse.note: Lit., divided. A man who would please his wife is distracted, divided, from the things of the Lord ([link]v. 35[/link]).

verse.text: But this I say for your own profit, not that I may [note]1[/note]put a noose upon you but that you may be comely and may wait on the Lord without [xref]a[/xref]distraction.
verse.note: I.e., entangle you with a snare, constrain you to obey my word.

verse.text: But if anyone thinks that he is behaving unbecomingly to his virgin [i]daughter,[/i] if she is past the bloom of youth and thus it must be so, let him do what he wishes, he does [xref]a[/xref]not sin; let them marry.

But he who stands firm in his heart, [note]1[/note]being under no constraint, and has authority with respect to his own will and has [note]2[/note]decided this in his own heart, to keep his own virgin [i]daughter,[/i] he will do well.
verse.note: Lit., not having necessity.
Or, judged.

verse.text: So then both he who gives his own virgin [i]daughter[/i] in [xref]a[/xref]marriage does well, and he who does not give [i]her[/i] in marriage will do better.
A wife is [xref]a[/xref]bound for so long a time as her husband lives; but should the husband fall asleep, she is free to be married to whom she wishes, [xref]b[/xref]only [i]to one[/i] in the Lord.
But she is [note]1[/note]more blessed if she so remains, according to my [xref]a[/xref]opinion; but I think that I [note]2[/note]also have the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit of God.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link].

In [link]v. 10[/link] the apostle said, "I charge, not I but the Lord." In [link]v. 12[/link] he said, "I say, I, not the Lord." In [link]v. 25[/link] he said, "I have no commandment of the Lord, but I give my opinion." Here he says, "according to my opinion; but I think that I also have the Spirit of God." All these words indicate the New Testament principle of incarnation (that is, that God and man, man and God, become one). This differs drastically from the principle of Old Testament prophecy (that is, that man speaks for God). In the Old Testament the word of Jehovah came upon a prophet ([link]Jer. 1:2[/link]; [link]Ezek. 1:3[/link]), the prophet being simply the mouthpiece of God. But in the New Testament the Lord becomes one with His apostles, and they become one with Him; thus, the two speak together. His word becomes their word, and whatever they utter is His word. Hence, the apostle's charge was the Lord's charge ([link]v. 10[/link]). What he said, though it was not spoken by the Lord, still became part of the divine revelation in the New Testament ([link]v. 12[/link]). He was one with the Lord to such a degree that even when he gave his own opinion, not the commandment of the Lord ([link]v. 25[/link]), he thought that he also had the Spirit of God. He did not claim definitely to have the Spirit of God, but he [i]thought[/i] that he [i]also[/i] had the Spirit of God. This is the highest spirituality; it is based on the principle of incarnation.

verse.text: Now concerning [note]1[/note]things sacrificed to [xref]a[/xref]idols, we [note]2[/note]know that we all have [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]knowledge. [note]4[/note]Knowledge [xref]c[/xref]puffs up, but [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]love [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]builds up.
verse.note: The sixth problem dealt with by this Epistle is the matter of eating things sacrificed to idols ([link]8:1-11:1[/link]).
Referring to the inward, subjective consciousness.
[i]Knowledge[/i] in this verse and in [link]vv. 7[/link], [link]10[/link] refers to the outward, objective knowledge, which is common and general.

The outward, objective knowledge that puffs up comes from the tree of knowledge of good and evil, the source of death. Spiritual (not fleshly) love, which is an expression of life as described in [link]ch. 13[/link], builds up. It comes from the tree of life, the source of life. This is the love of God ([link]1 John 4:16[/link]) infused into us by faith, which has brought us into the organic union with God. By this love we love God ([link]v. 3[/link]) and the brothers ([link]1 John 4:21[/link]), and according to this love we should walk ([link]Rom. 14:15[/link]). Thus, our walk builds up ([link]10:23[/link]).

Referring not only to the edification of individual believers but also to the building up of the corporate Body of Christ ([link]14:4-5[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:16[/link]). This book stresses the matter of building up ([link]3:9-10[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]10:23[/link]).

verse.text: If anyone [xref]a[/xref]thinks that he [note]1[/note]knows anything, he has [xref]b[/xref]not yet come to [note]1[/note]know as he ought to [note]1[/note]know;
verse.note: Referring to the outward, objective knowledge. So for [i]known[/i] in [link]v. 3[/link].

verse.text: But if anyone [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]loves God, this one is [xref]b[/xref]known by Him.
verse.note: The highest and noblest love. It must be spiritual, not fleshly, although it requires the exercise of man's entire being ([link]Mark 12:30[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore concerning the eating of things [xref]a[/xref]sacrificed to idols, we [note]1[/note]know that an [xref]b[/xref]idol is [xref]c[/xref]nothing in the world and that there is no God but [xref]d[/xref]one.
verse.note: Referring to the inward, subjective consciousness. To realize that an idol is nothing and that there is no God but one requires our inward, subjective consciousness derived from our spirit through our mind. This consciousness is much deeper than the outward, objective knowledge, which is merely in our mind.

verse.text: For even if there are so-called [xref]a[/xref]gods, either in heaven or on earth, even as there are many gods and many lords,

Yet to [note]1[/note]us there is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]one God, the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Father, [note]4[/note]out from whom are [xref]c[/xref]all things, and we are [note]4[/note]unto Him; and [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]one Lord, [note]6[/note]Jesus Christ, [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]through whom are all things, and we are [note]4[/note]through Him.
verse.note: The believers in Christ, the Christians.
In contrast to [i]many gods[/i] in [link]v. 5[/link]. Our God is uniquely one.
A designation of our God, who is the source of all things. This designation makes our God utterly distinct from the many false gods.

The Father is the source of all things; thus, all things are out from Him. However, only we as believers will turn to Him; hence, we are unto Him. Similarly, all things that the Father created came into being through Jesus Christ as the means, and it is through the means of the Lord's regeneration that we as believers turn to the Father and are unto Him. Hence, both we and all things are through Christ.
In contrast to [i]many lords[/i] in [link]v. 5[/link]. Our Lord also is uniquely one.

The divine and human title of our Lord that distinguishes Him from the many lords. Our God, the Father, is the unique source of all things, and our Lord, Jesus Christ, is the unique means through whom all things came into being.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]this knowledge is not in all men; but some, being accustomed to the idol until now, [xref]b[/xref]eat [i]the food[/i] as an [xref]c[/xref]idol sacrifice, and their [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]conscience, being weak, is [note]2[/note]defiled.
verse.note: A weak conscience is due to the lack of proper and adequate knowledge. This indicates that our knowledge has much to do with our conscience. The ex-idol worshippers who are now believers in Christ, being accustomed to the idol until now, lack the knowledge that an idol is nothing ([link]v. 4[/link]). Thus, their conscience is weak concerning the matter of idols.
The weak conscience is defiled when it is touched by any matter about which it lacks adequate knowledge.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]food will not commend us to God; neither if we do not eat are we lacking, nor if we eat do we [note]1[/note]abound.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to abound so that one becomes full and excelling;[/i] hence, become full and excelling. Here it denotes that eating things sacrificed to idols cannot cause us to become full and excelling in any respect before God; therefore, neither can not eating cause us to be lacking, which is in contrast to being full and excelling.

verse.text: But beware lest somehow this [note]1[/note]right of yours become a [xref]a[/xref]stumbling block to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]weak ones.
verse.note: Or, liberty. Lit., authority. So also in [link]9:4-5[/link].
Those whose conscience is weakened by a lack of knowledge.

verse.text: For if anyone sees you who have [xref]a[/xref]knowledge reclining [i]at table[/i] in an [xref]b[/xref]idol temple, will not his [xref]c[/xref]conscience, if he is weak, be [note]1[/note]emboldened to eat the things [xref]d[/xref]sacrificed to the idols?
verse.note: Lit., built up. The conscience of the weak believers will be built up with boldness to do what it formerly dared not do. This is a sudden building up without a logical and solid foundation. Hence, it is an improper building up that actually ruins. Although the conscience of the weak believers is emboldened to eat what has been sacrificed to idols, such a practice will eventually ruin them because they do not have adequate knowledge to support their emboldened yet still weak conscience.

verse.text: For the one who is [xref]a[/xref]weak is being [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]destroyed by your [xref]c[/xref]knowledge, the brother because of whom Christ [xref]d[/xref]died.
verse.note: This denotes perishing, not perishing for eternity but perishing in the Christian life. The weak believer is destroyed by the carelessness of the stronger one who has knowledge.

verse.text: And sinning in this way against the brothers and [note]1[/note]wounding their weak [xref]a[/xref]conscience, you sin against Christ.
verse.note: Lit., smiting (unto damage).

verse.text: Therefore if food [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]stumbles my brother, I shall by no means eat [note]2[/note]meat forever, that I may not [note]1[/note]stumble my brother.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to snare, to entrap.[/i] Cf. note [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].
I.e., animal flesh, referring to the meat offered to idols. Since meat is more tempting than other kinds of food, the apostle mentioned it specifically.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Am I not [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]free? Am I not an [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]apostle? Have I not [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]seen Jesus our Lord? Are you not my [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]work in the Lord?
verse.note: This chapter is an insertion in this section on eating idol sacrifices. In this insertion the apostle presented himself to the Corinthian believers as a pattern, that they might not stumble others but build them up by practicing the principle of considerate love set forth in [link]8:13[/link].

The apostle Paul was free from all men, being enslaved to no one ([link]v. 19[/link]). As all believers in Christ should be, he was free also from the bondage of any particular way of eating, although he practiced the principle of considerate love.

As he presented himself a pattern to the believers, the apostle came to the matter of his apostleship, which gave him authority to deal with all the problems covered in this book, serious problems concerning the church life and its fellowship. His handling of these problems was based not only on his teaching but also on the authority inherent in his apostleship. To deal with the situation, he had to take this standing and make this matter clear to the Corinthian believers. They had questioned his apostleship and were in a chaotic situation, mainly because of the foolishness of their worldly wisdom, self-confidence, and pride.[br][br]The Greek word for [i]apostle[/i] means [i]one who is sent.[/i] An apostle of the Lord is a believer who is sent out by Him with His authority to preach the gospel of God, to teach the divine truth, and to establish churches. In the first section of Acts, Peter and John were such apostles among the Jews, and in the second section of Acts, Paul and Barnabas were such apostles among the Gentiles. After them, others also became apostles, such as Silas (i.e., Silvanus) and Timothy ([link]1 Thes. 1:1[/link]; [link]2:6[/link]). As long as one has the power to preach the gospel, the gift to teach the divine truth, and the ability to establish churches, he is qualified and confirmed to be an apostle sent by the Lord with His commission and authority.

This refers to Paul's having seen the Lord in His glorious resurrected body ([link]15:5-8[/link]). This is a special privilege; it constitutes some dignity and glory to the seer, but it is not a requirement or qualification for being the Lord's apostle. This is fully proven by the case of Barnabas, who was one of the apostles ([link]Acts 14:14[/link]) yet did not see the Lord in this way. However, to know the Lord in spirit by spiritual revelation is definitely needed for one to be an apostle.
The fruitful result of his work in the Lord was a proof of, not a qualification for, Paul's apostleship.
verse.xref: [link]1 Cor. 1:1[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 2:7[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:11[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 12:12[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 2:6[/link]; cf. [link]Rev. 2:2[/link]

verse.text: If to others I am not an apostle, yet surely I am to [note]1[/note]you; for you in the Lord are the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]seal of my [xref]b[/xref]apostleship.
verse.note: Because he had begotten them in the Lord through the gospel ([link]4:15[/link]). The fruit of his labor was the evidence of his apostleship.

The sufficient result of the apostle's effective work was not only an evidence, a proof, but also a seal of his apostleship. It put a distinctive mark on his apostolic labor that authenticated and certified his apostleship.

verse.text: My defense to those who examine me is [note]1[/note]this.
verse.note: Referring to the defense in [link]vv. 1-2[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Do we not have a [note]2[/note]right to [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]eat and to drink?
verse.note: The apostle's bold, frank, strong, and direct defense in [link]vv. 4-15[/link] reveals that he was a person with a pure heart and spirit, and that in the Lord's work he had no intention other than Christ and His Body.
Or, liberty.
To eat and drink for the gospel ([link]v. 14[/link]) at the expense of the saints and the churches.

verse.text: Do we not have a right to take along a sister as a wife, [xref]a[/xref]even as the rest of the apostles and the [xref]b[/xref]brothers of the Lord and [xref]c[/xref]Cephas?
Or do only I and [xref]a[/xref]Barnabas not have the [xref]b[/xref]right not to work?

What soldier ever [xref]a[/xref]serves by his own wages? Who [xref]b[/xref]plants a [xref]c[/xref]vineyard and does not [xref]d[/xref]partake of its fruit? Or who shepherds a flock and does not partake of the milk of the flock?
Am I speaking these things [xref]a[/xref]according to man? Or does the law not also say these things?
For in the law of Moses it is written: [xref]a[/xref]"You shall not muzzle the ox [note]1[/note]while it is treading out the grain." Is it for oxen that God cares?
verse.note: Or, that is treading out the grain.

verse.text: Or does He say [i]it[/i] altogether for our sake? Yes, for our sake it was written because the [xref]a[/xref]plowman should plow in hope, and he who threshes, in hope of partaking.
If we have sown to you the [xref]a[/xref]spiritual things, is it a great thing if we shall reap from you the fleshly things?

If others partake of this right over you, should not rather we? Yet we did [xref]a[/xref]not use this right, but we [note]1[/note]bear all things that we may [xref]b[/xref]not cause any hindrance to the gospel of Christ.
verse.note: Or, endure. Lit., contain (as a vessel), conceal; hence, cover (as a roof).

verse.text: Do you not know that those who labor on the [note]1[/note]sacred things [xref]a[/xref]eat the things of the sacred temple, [i]that[/i] those who attend to the altar have their portion with the altar?
verse.note: The word for [i]sacred[/i] here is different from the word for [i]holy[/i] in [link]Rom. 1:2[/link] and the word for [i]holiness[/i] in [link]Luke 1:75[/link], and is the same as the word for [i]sacred[/i] in [link]2 Tim. 3:15[/link]. It denotes the sacredness of the things that are related to the worship of God.

verse.text: So also the Lord directed those who announce the gospel to [xref]a[/xref]live from the gospel.

But I myself have not used [xref]a[/xref]any of these things; and I have not written these things that it may be so with me; for it is good for me [note]1[/note]rather to die than[note]2[/note] — No one shall make my [xref]b[/xref]boast void.
verse.note: The apostle was desperately absolute for the Lord's interests. He was willing not only to sacrifice all his rights ([link]vv. 12[/link], [link]15a[/link], [link]18[/link]) but also to pay the price even of his life.
Than what? Paul did not finish the sentence. Perhaps he was referring to the things mentioned in the first half of this verse.

verse.text: For if I preach the gospel, I have no boast, for [xref]a[/xref]necessity is laid upon me; for woe to me if I do not preach the gospel.
If I do this of my own will, I have a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reward; but if not of my own will, I am [xref]b[/xref]entrusted with a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]stewardship.
verse.note: This book was written not to help lost sinners to be saved but to help saved believers to grow ([link]3:6-7[/link]), to build with the precious materials ([link]3:10[/link], [link]12-14[/link]), to care for the Lord's members ([link]8:9-13[/link]), and to run the race ([link]v. 24[/link]). Hence, a reward is mentioned repeatedly as an incentive to the believers for their progress ([link]3:14[/link]; [link]9:18[/link], [link]24-25[/link]). See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link].

Or, household administration, household dispensation. The apostle was not only a preacher but also a steward in God's house, a household administrator, dispensing Christ's salvation, life, and riches to His believers. Such a ministry was the stewardship with which he had been entrusted and commissioned ([link]Eph. 3:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:1[/link]).

verse.text: What then is my reward? That in preaching the gospel I may present the gospel [xref]a[/xref]without charge, so as [xref]b[/xref]not to use to the full my right in the gospel.
For though I am [xref]a[/xref]free from [note]1[/note]all, I have [xref]b[/xref]enslaved myself to [note]1[/note]all that I might gain the more.
verse.note: I.e., all men.

verse.text: And to the Jews I became [xref]a[/xref]as a Jew in order that I might [xref]b[/xref]gain Jews; to those [xref]c[/xref]under law, as under law (though I myself am [xref]d[/xref]not under law), that I might gain those under law.

To those [xref]a[/xref]without law, [xref]b[/xref]as without law (though I am not [note]1[/note]without law to God but [note]2[/note]within [xref]c[/xref]law to Christ), that I might gain those without law.
verse.note: I.e., outside the sphere, the limit, of law; hence, without law.

I.e., within the sphere, the limit, of law; hence, subject to law. Paul took Christ as his life and lived by Christ. This Christ, who lived in him as life and who has the law of life and is the very law of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]), ruled and regulated him that he might be legitimately, legally, rightfully, and duly subject to Christ. Therefore, Paul was within a higher and better law, being subject to the law of life. Hence, he was not outside law and was not without law to God.

verse.text: To the weak I [xref]a[/xref]became weak that I might gain the weak. To all men I have [note]1[/note]become [xref]b[/xref]all things that I might by all means [xref]c[/xref]save some.
verse.note: This means that the apostle adapted himself to all things, that is, to different ways of eating and practice ([link]v. 23[/link]), for the sake of all men.

verse.text: And I do all things for the sake of the gospel that I may become a [note]1[/note]fellow [xref]a[/xref]partaker of it.
verse.note: Or, joint participant, cooperator, copartner. The apostle was not only a fellow partaker, a joint participant, enjoying the gospel but also a cooperator, a copartner, laboring for the gospel. However, here he referred to the enjoyment of the gospel. Hence, this word is rendered [i]fellow partaker[/i] in the text.

verse.text: Do you not know that those who [note]1[/note]run on a [xref]a[/xref]racecourse all run, but one receives the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]prize? [xref]c[/xref]Run in this way, that you may [note]3[/note]lay hold.
verse.note: This reveals that the Christian life is a race that we must run successfully.
I.e., a reward as an incentive. See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup][/link].
I.e., obtain.

verse.text: And everyone who [xref]a[/xref]contends exercises self-control in all things; they then, that they may receive a corruptible [note]1[/note]crown, but we, [xref]b[/xref]an [xref]c[/xref]incorruptible.
verse.note: A chaplet made of leaves for the athletic contests at that time. The incorruptible crown, which the Lord will award to His overcoming saints who win the race, is a reward in addition to salvation (see note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link]). We, His believers, have all received His salvation through faith in Him. This has been settled once for all. But whether we will be rewarded by Him depends on how we run the race. Here, in this chapter, the apostle was running the course ([link]v. 26[/link]). In Philippians, one of his last Epistles, he was still running ([link]Phil. 3:14[/link]). It was not until the last moment of his running, in [link]2 Tim. 4:6-8[/link], that he had the assurance that he would be rewarded by the Lord at His appearing. In view of this prize the apostle charged the Corinthian believers to run the race that they might obtain the reward ([link]v. 24[/link]).

verse.text: I therefore [xref]a[/xref]run in this way, not as though without a clear aim; I box in this way, not as though beating the [xref]b[/xref]air;

But I [note]1[/note]buffet my body and [note]2[/note]make [i]it[/i] my slave, [note]3[/note]lest perhaps having [note]4[/note]preached to others, I myself may become [note]5[/note][xref]a[/xref]disapproved.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]to beat the face under the eye black and blue.[/i] This is not to ill-treat the body, as in asceticism, nor to consider the body evil, as in Gnosticism. This is to subdue the body and make it a conquered captive to serve us as a slave for fulfilling our holy purpose. This is equivalent to putting to death our earthly members ([link]Col. 3:5[/link]) and putting to death the practices of the body ([link]Rom. 8:13[/link]), not allowing our body to be used for the indulgence of lust or doing anything on our own except what is holy to God. The Corinthians misused their body by indulgence in fornication, not caring for God's temple ([link]6:19[/link]), and in the unrestrained eating of things sacrificed to idols, not caring for weak believers ([link]8:9-13[/link]).
A metaphor meaning to lead the vanquished as a captive and a slave, to bring the captive into slavery, making him a slave to serve the conqueror's purpose.
The Greek word implies possibility.

According to the context of [link]vv. 24-27[/link], this refers to the preaching of the reward as an incentive to the Christian runners. This is related to the kingdom, the manifestation of which will be a reward to the overcoming saints who have won the Christian race. See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].

Or, disqualified, rejected; i.e., unworthy of the prize. The apostle was surely saved by grace through faith in Christ. Not only so, he was called to be an apostle to carry out God's New Testament economy. Nonetheless, here he was very much on the alert to run his course ([link]Acts 20:24[/link]) by subduing his body to serve his holy purpose, that he might not be disapproved and rejected at the judgment seat of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]) and be found unworthy of the reward of the coming kingdom. See [link]Matt. 7:21-23[/link]; [link]25:11-12[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For I do not want you to be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]ignorant, brothers, that [note]3[/note]all our fathers were under the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]cloud, and all passed through the [xref]c[/xref]sea;
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that [link]ch. 10[/link] is not only a continuation of [link]ch. 9[/link] but also a further definition of running the race covered in [link]9:24-27[/link], using as an illustration the children of Israel running on the racecourse in the wilderness to enter into the promised land.
This refers to the word [i]Do you not know[/i] in [link]9:24[/link].
This indicates that all the children of Israel who had enjoyed the passover entered into the race and began to run the race from the time they left the land of Rameses ([link]Exo. 12:37[/link]).

The cloud that covered the children of Israel typifies the Spirit of God, who is with the New Testament believers. Immediately after the New Testament believers take Christ as their Passover ([link]5:7[/link]), the Spirit of God comes to be with them and lead them to run the Christian race, just as the pillar of cloud led the children of Israel ([link]Exo. 13:21-22[/link]; [link]14:19-20[/link]).

verse.text: And all were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]baptized [note]2[/note]unto Moses [note]3[/note]in the cloud and in the sea;
verse.note: The passing of the children of Israel through the Red Sea ([link]Exo. 14:21-30[/link]) typifies the baptism of the New Testament believers ([link]Rom. 6:4[/link]).

The children of Israel were baptized unto Moses to begin the holy race for the fulfilling of God's purpose, that is, to enter into the good land and build the temple, that God might have a kingdom with an expression of Himself on the earth. This typifies the baptizing of the New Testament believers into Christ ([link]Gal. 3:27[/link]) that God may have His kingdom with the church as His expression on the earth.

[i]In the cloud[/i] signifies in the Spirit, and [i]in the sea[/i] denotes in the water. The New Testament believers were baptized in the water and in the Spirit ([link]Matt. 3:11[/link]; [link]Acts 1:5[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]).

verse.text: And all ate the same [note]1[/note]spiritual [xref]a[/xref]food,
verse.note: Referring to manna ([link]Exo. 16:14-18[/link]), typifying Christ as our daily life supply ([link]John 6:31-35[/link]) for the Christian journey. We believers should all eat the same spiritual food and should not eat anything other than Christ.

verse.text: And all drank the same [note]1[/note]spiritual [xref]a[/xref]drink; for they drank of a [note]2[/note]spiritual rock which followed [i]them,[/i] and the rock was Christ.
verse.note: Referring to the living water that flowed out of the cleft rock ([link]Exo. 17:6[/link]), typifying the Spirit, who flowed out of the crucified and resurrected Christ, as our all-inclusive drink ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]). For our running of the race we should all drink the same spiritual drink and should not drink anything other than the all-inclusive Spirit.

The rock that was smitten and cleft to flow out the living water for God's chosen people ([link]Exo. 17:6[/link]) was a physical rock. Yet the apostle called it a spiritual rock because it typified Christ, who was smitten and cleft by God to flow out the water of life ([link]John 19:34[/link]) to satisfy the thirst of His believers. Hence, the apostle said that the rock was Christ. Since it was a spiritual rock signifying Christ, it was able to follow the children of Israel. This indicates that Christ as the real rock is following His believers.

verse.text: But with most of them God was not well pleased, for they were [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]strewn along in the wilderness.
verse.note: I.e., laid low on the ground by being slain. This refers to [link]Num. 14:16[/link], [link]29[/link].

verse.text: Now these things occurred as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]examples to [note]2[/note]us, that we should not be ones who lust after evil things, even as they also [xref]b[/xref]lusted.
verse.note: Lit., types (so also in [link]v. 11[/link]); i.e., figures of facts or of spiritual truths. This book takes the history of the children of Israel in the Old Testament as a type of the New Testament believers. In [link]5:7-8[/link] the believers experienced Christ as their Passover and began to keep the Feast of Unleavened Bread. Here in this chapter they are baptized unto their Moses (Christ), passing through their Red Sea (the death of Christ). They are now eating the spiritual food and drinking the spiritual drink that they might take their journey (the Christian race) toward their good land (the all-inclusive Christ). Also, they are warned here ([link]v. 11[/link]) not to repeat the history of the children of Israel in doing evil against God, as illustrated in [link]vv. 6-11[/link].[br][br]The goal of God's calling of the children of Israel was that they would enter into the promised land to enjoy its riches so that they might establish God's kingdom and be God's expression on earth. However, although all Israel was redeemed through the passover, delivered out of the Egyptian tyranny, and brought to the mountain of God to receive the revelation of God's dwelling place, the tabernacle, nearly all fell and died in the wilderness, failing to reach this goal ([link]Heb. 3:7-19[/link]) because of their evildoings and unbelief. Only Caleb and Joshua reached the goal and entered into the good land ([link]Num. 14:27-30[/link]). This signifies that although we have been redeemed through Christ, delivered out of Satan's bondage, and brought into the revelation of God's economy, we may yet fail to reach the goal of God's calling, that is, to enter into the possession of our good land, Christ ([link]Phil. 3:12-14[/link]), and enjoy His riches for the kingdom of God that we may be His expression in the present age and participate in the fullest enjoyment of Christ in the kingdom age ([link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]). This should be a solemn warning to all New Testament believers. It was especially applicable to the Corinthians, who were in danger of repeating the failure of the children of Israel in the wilderness.
The apostle included himself with all believers in the matter of running the Christian race.

verse.text: Neither become [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]idolaters, as [xref]b[/xref]some of them did; as it is written, [xref]c[/xref]"The people sat down to [note]1[/note]eat and drink, and stood up to [xref]d[/xref]play."
verse.note: The abusive eating by the children of Israel was related to their idolatry in worshipping the golden calf ([link]Exo. 32:1-6[/link]). The apostle's word here implies that the Corinthians' inconsiderate eating of idol sacrifices was also somewhat related to idolatry.

verse.text: Neither let us commit [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fornication, as some of them [xref]b[/xref]committed fornication, and there [note]2[/note]fell in one day [xref]c[/xref]twenty-three thousand.
verse.note: Fornication accompanies idolatry ([link]Num. 25:1-2[/link]). Hence, these two things are referred to together, as also in [link]Acts 15:20[/link], [link]29[/link]. Undoubtedly, the implication here is that these two evils existed among the Corinthian believers. Hence, these are the main things dealt with in [link]chs. 5-10[/link].
This is to be laid low on the ground by being slain.

verse.text: Neither let us [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]test Christ, as some of them [xref]b[/xref]tested [i]Him[/i] and were destroyed by the [xref]c[/xref]serpents.
verse.note: Lit., try to the utmost, tempt thoroughly. [i]Tested,[/i] later in this verse, does not carry the meaning of [i]to the utmost[/i] and [i]thoroughly.[/i]

verse.text: Neither [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]murmur, just as some of them [xref]b[/xref]murmured and [xref]c[/xref]perished by the [note]2[/note]destroyer.
verse.note: The murmuring of the children of Israel ([link]Num. 16:41[/link]) typified the negative speaking of the Corinthian believers against the apostle ([link]4:3[/link]; [link]9:3[/link]).
God's executing angel ([link]Exo. 12:23[/link]; [link]2 Sam. 24:16-17[/link]).

verse.text: Now these things [note]1[/note]happened to them as an [xref]a[/xref]example, and they were [xref]b[/xref]written for our admonition, unto whom the [note]2[/note]ends of the ages [note]3[/note]have come.
verse.note: Lit., were happening.

[i]The ages[/i] refers to all the past ages. [i]The ends of the ages[/i] refers to the fact that all the past ages were consummated at the beginning of the New Testament age; hence, the ends of the ages had come to the people of that time. Those people could, in the New Testament age, take the admonition from the history of the children of Israel. After the New Testament age is the kingdom age, during which these examples in the Old Testament age will no longer serve for the running of the Christian race.
Lit., have come down, have arrived.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]So then let him who [xref]a[/xref]thinks he [xref]b[/xref]stands take heed lest he [note]2[/note]fall.
verse.note: Based on the admonition in [link]vv. 5-11[/link], the apostle warned the Corinthians not to think that they were standing steadfast, with no danger of falling dead as the children of Israel had.

As the failing children of Israel fell and died in the wilderness ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]8[/link]). Some Corinthian believers did fall and die because they offended the Lord's Body ([link]11:27-30[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]No [note]2[/note]temptation has taken you except [note]3[/note]that which is common to man; and God is [xref]a[/xref]faithful, who will not allow that you be [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]tempted beyond what you are able, but will, with the [note]2[/note]temptation, also make the way out, that you may be able to [xref]c[/xref]endure [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: This verse is a continuation of the warning given in [link]v. 12[/link], indicating, on the one hand, that we should take heed not to be tempted lest we fall and die, and, on the other hand, that God in His faithfulness will not allow any temptation to befall us beyond what we are able to endure, but will, with the temptation, always make the way out for us.
Or, trial ([link]2 Pet. 2:9[/link]; cf. [link]Dan. 3:17-18[/link]).
Lit., that which is human.
Or, tried.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore, my beloved, flee from [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]idolatry.
verse.note: This indicates that the following section, to [link]v. 30[/link], is a conclusion to the preceding section, from [link]8:1[/link], concerning eating things sacrificed to idols.
Referring to the idolatry involved in eating things sacrificed to idols.

verse.text: I speak as to prudent men; you [xref]a[/xref]judge what I say.

The [xref]a[/xref]cup of blessing which we [xref]b[/xref]bless, is it not the [note]1[/note]fellowship of the [xref]c[/xref]blood of Christ? The [xref]d[/xref]bread which we break, is it not the [note]1[/note]fellowship of the [xref]e[/xref]body of Christ?
verse.note: Or, joint participation in. [i]Fellowship[/i] here refers to the believers' communion in the joint participation in the blood and body of Christ. This makes us, the participants in the Lord's blood and body, not only one with one another but also one with the Lord. We, the participants, make ourselves identified with the Lord in the fellowship of His blood and body. The apostle's thought here was to illustrate how eating and drinking make the eaters and drinkers one with what they eat and drink. The Corinthians should have realized that their abusive eating of idol sacrifices actually made them one with the demons behind the sacrifices.

verse.text: Seeing that there is [note]1[/note]one bread, we who are many are [xref]a[/xref]one Body; for we all [note]2[/note]partake of the one bread.
verse.note: The one bread signifies the one Body of Christ. We all are one Body because we all partake of the one bread. Our joint partaking of the one bread makes us all one. This indicates that our partaking of Christ makes us all His one Body. The very Christ of whom we all partake constitutes us His one Body.

Partaking of (that is, eating — [link]vv. 28-30[/link]) the one bread identifies us with it. This indicates that our partaking of Christ, our enjoying of Christ, identifies us with Him, making us one with Him.

verse.text: Look at Israel [xref]a[/xref]according to the flesh. Are not those who [xref]b[/xref]eat the sacrifices those who [note]1[/note]have fellowship with the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]altar?
verse.note: Or, participate jointly in. Those who eat the sacrifices of the altar not only have fellowship with one another and with the altar but also participate jointly in what they eat. Their participation in what they eat makes them one with the sacrifices of the altar. This too illustrates how eating makes the eater one with what he eats. Eating things sacrificed to idols does the same: it identifies the eaters with the demons behind the sacrifices.
Since the altar is the base of the sacrifices offered to God, eating the sacrifices of the altar makes the eaters those who have fellowship with, those who participate jointly in, the altar.

verse.text: What then am I saying? That what is [xref]a[/xref]sacrificed to an idol is anything? Or that an idol is anything?

[i]No,[/i] but that the things which the Gentiles sacrifice, they sacrifice to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]demons and not to God; and I do not want you to become [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]those who have fellowship with demons.
verse.note: An idol and the things sacrificed to an idol are nothing ([link]v. 19[/link]; [link]8:4[/link]). But behind them are the demons, who are abominable and hateful to God. The believers, who worship God, should abstain from identifying themselves with demons and becoming those who have fellowship with demons through the eating of things sacrificed to idols. Since demons are the reality of idols, the eating of things sacrificed to idols makes the eaters those who have fellowship with, those who participate jointly in, demons.

See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup][/link]. The eaters of things sacrificed to idols become not only those who fellowship with demons but also those who participate jointly in demons, making themselves one with demons.

verse.text: You cannot [note]1[/note]drink the Lord's [xref]a[/xref]cup and the demons' cup; you cannot partake of the Lord's [xref]b[/xref]table and of the [xref]c[/xref]demons' table.
verse.note: To drink the Lord's cup and partake of the Lord's table is to identify ourselves with the Lord. To drink the demons' cup and partake of the demons' table is to make ourselves one with demons.

verse.text: Or do we [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]provoke the Lord to [xref]b[/xref]jealousy? Are we [xref]c[/xref]stronger than He?
verse.note: The Lord is the jealous God ([link]Exo. 20:5[/link]). Idolatry is utterly abominable and hateful to Him. If we participate in fellowship with demons, making ourselves one with them, we will provoke the Lord to jealousy. Hence, we must flee from idolatry ([link]v. 14[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]All things are [note]2[/note]lawful, but not all things are [note]3[/note]profitable; all things are [note]2[/note]lawful, but not all things [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]build up.
verse.note: [link]Verses 14-22[/link] deal with the eating of idol sacrifices from the aspect of making oneself one with demons. From [link]v. 23[/link] through [link]11:1[/link] this matter is dealt with from the view of building up others to the glory of God ([link]v. 31[/link]).
See note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].
See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

The parallel verse, [link]6:12[/link], ends with [i]I will not be brought under the power of anything.[/i] This verse ends with [i]not all things build up.[/i] The former concerns ourselves; the latter, others.

verse.text: Let no one [xref]a[/xref]seek his own [i]profit,[/i] but that of the other.
Everything sold in a [note]1[/note]meat market [xref]a[/xref]eat, asking no questions for [xref]b[/xref]conscience' sake;
verse.note: At the apostles' time, usually only a part of what had been sacrificed to idols was consumed. The rest was given to the priests or to the poor, or was sold again in the market. Buyers might unknowingly purchase meat offered to idols.

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]earth is the Lord's and the fullness thereof.
If any of the unbelievers invites you and you wish to go, [xref]a[/xref]eat everything that is set before you, asking no question for [xref]b[/xref]conscience' sake.
But if anyone says to you, This has been offered in sacrifice, do [xref]a[/xref]not eat, for his sake who pointed it out and for [xref]b[/xref]conscience' sake.
Conscience, I say, not your own, but the other's. For why is my [xref]a[/xref]freedom judged by [i]some[/i] other conscience?
If I [note]1[/note]partake with [xref]a[/xref]thankfulness, why am I spoken [xref]b[/xref]evil of concerning that for which I give thanks?
verse.note: I.e., eat. This indicates that eating is partaking ([link]v. 17[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore [note]2[/note]whether you [xref]a[/xref]eat or drink, or [xref]b[/xref]whatever you do, do all to the [xref]c[/xref]glory of God.
verse.note: This indicates that [link]10:31-11:1[/link] is a conclusion to this subsection (from [link]v. 23[/link]).

[link]Verses 23[/link], [link]31[/link], and [link]6:12[/link] give us four basic principles for regulating the New Testament believers' conduct. All things are lawful, but whatever we do, (1) as to the thing itself, must be profitable, (2) as to ourselves, must not bring us under the power of anything, (3) as to others, must build them up, and (4) as to God, must glorify Him. Otherwise, nothing is permissible.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Do not become a [xref]a[/xref]stumbling block, both to [note]2[/note]Jews and to Greeks and to the [xref]b[/xref]church of God;
verse.note: The Greek expression rendered [i]do not become a stumbling block[/i] is based on the same root as the word for [i]stumbling block[/i] in [link]8:9[/link]; it is different from the word for [i]stumble[/i] in [link]8:13[/link].

In New Testament times people are of three categories: (1) the Jews — God's chosen people; (2) the Greeks — the unbelieving Gentiles; and (3) the church — a composition of the believers in Christ. We should not be an offense, a stumbling block, to anyone in these three categories, that they might be saved ([link]v. 33[/link]).

verse.text: Even as [note]1[/note]I also [xref]a[/xref]please [xref]b[/xref]all men in all things, not [xref]c[/xref]seeking my own advantage but that of the many, that they may be [xref]d[/xref]saved.
verse.note: What an example the apostle has set for us!

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Be [xref]a[/xref]imitators of [note]2[/note]me, as I also am [xref]b[/xref]of Christ.
verse.note: This verse is the last sentence of the conclusion of [link]ch. 10[/link].
If one is an imitator of Christ, we should be imitators of him. This makes us also imitators of Christ. Otherwise, we should be imitators of no man.

verse.text: But I [xref]a[/xref]praise you because in all things you have [xref]b[/xref]remembered me and hold fast the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]things that I have handed down even as I handed [note]1[/note][i]them[/i] down to you.
verse.note: Instructions handed down by word of mouth or writing ([link]2 Thes. 2:15[/link]).

verse.text: But I want you to know that [note]1[/note]Christ is the [xref]a[/xref]head of every man, and the [note]2[/note]man is the [xref]b[/xref]head of the woman, and [note]3[/note]God is the [xref]c[/xref]head of Christ.
verse.note: [link]Verses 3-16[/link] deal with the seventh problem, the problem concerning head covering. The first six problems, dealt with in [link]chs. 1-10[/link], may be considered one group. They are concerned with matters in the realm of human life. The last five problems, dealt with in [link]chs. 11-16[/link], constitute another group. They are concerned with matters in the realm of God's administration. The first problem in this latter group concerns the headship of Christ and of God in the divine government. In [link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link] the headship of Christ over all things is to His Body, the church. Here the headship of Christ over every man is related to individuals. Christ is the Head of the Body, the church ([link]Eph. 5:23[/link]), corporately, and of the believers individually. He is the Head of every one of us directly. In the apostle's dealing with the Corinthians' problems related to God's administration, the headship of Christ and of God was his first concern.

In the divine governmental ordination, woman is under the headship of man. God created the female in this way ([link]Gen. 2:18-24[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 2:13[/link]). According to the nature ([link]v. 14[/link]) created by God, woman is subordinate to man.

Christ is God's anointed One, the One appointed by God. Hence, He is under God, and God as the Originator is His Head. This refers to the relationship between Christ and God in the divine government.[br][br]In dealing with the problem of head covering, the apostle took the headship of God, the headship of Christ, and the headship of man as strong ground for his instruction. His instruction concerning head covering was based not on any religious practice or human custom but on the headship in God's governmental administration. Such a strong base leaves no ground for argument over the matter of head covering.

verse.text: Every man praying or [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prophesying with his head covered [note]2[/note]disgraces his head.
verse.note: I.e., speaking for God. See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].

Since man has the headship over woman and is God's image and glory ([link]v. 7[/link]), he should keep his head manifested, unconcealed, uncovered, when he touches the throne of God's administration by praying to God or speaking for Him. Otherwise, he dishonors or shames his head.

verse.text: But every woman [xref]a[/xref]praying or [xref]b[/xref]prophesying with her head [note]1[/note]uncovered disgraces her head; for it is one and the same as she who is [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]shaved.
verse.note: Since woman is under the headship of man, she should keep her head covered, not exposed, when she touches the divine administration by praying to God or speaking for God. Otherwise, she disgraces or shames her head, as if her head were shaved, because she denies the divine governmental ordination by exposing her head to the observing angels ([link]v. 10[/link]) while touching the authority of God.
This is a strong indication that for a woman to have her head shaved or her hair cut off is shameful ([link]v. 6[/link]).

verse.text: For if a woman is not covered, let [i]her hair[/i] also be cut off; but if it is shameful for a woman to have [i]her hair[/i] cut off or to be shaved, [note]1[/note]let her be covered.
verse.note: This indicates that the head covering is a covering in addition to long hair. For a woman to keep her hair long, not having her head shaved, means that she does not reject God's governmental ordination; and for a woman to have a head covering in addition to her long hair indicates that she says amen to the divine ordination.

verse.text: For a man ought not to have his head covered, since he is [note]1[/note]God's [xref]a[/xref]image and glory; but the woman is the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]glory of the man.
verse.note: Man was made in God's image ([link]Gen. 1:26[/link]) to express God and glorify Him. Since man bears God's image and glory and represents God, he should not have his head covered. If he does, God's image and glory will be concealed.

Since the woman is the glory of the man, she should not have her head exposed but should have it covered. She should not express herself but the man, under whom she is. The apostle took this too as ground for his teaching concerning head covering.

verse.text: For man is not out of woman, but [note]1[/note]woman [xref]a[/xref]out of man;
verse.note: As a rib taken out of man, woman was made out of man ([link]Gen. 2:21-23[/link]).

verse.text: For also man was not [note]1[/note]created for the sake of the woman, but [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]woman for the sake of the man.
verse.note: Here the apostle took God's purpose in the creation of man and woman as further strong ground for his teaching concerning head covering. That teaching is not based on any man-made custom but on the divine purpose in creation.
Woman was made for the purpose of matching man ([link]Gen. 2:18[/link], [link]24[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore the woman ought to have [i]a[/i] [note]1[/note][i]sign[/i] of submission to [xref]a[/xref]authority on her head for the [note]2[/note]sake of the [xref]b[/xref]angels.
verse.note: I.e., the head covering, which signifies man's headship over the woman.

This was further ground for the teaching concerning head covering. Head covering is closely related to God's headship, God's authority. The archangel with his subordinates rebelled against God's headship ([link]Ezek. 28:13-18[/link]; [link]Isa. 14:12-15[/link]; [link]Matt. 25:41[/link]), establishing his kingdom of darkness ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link]; [link]Col. 1:13[/link]), and became Satan, God's adversary. After God created man, Satan seduced man to follow him and rebel against God. Then God sent His Son to destroy Satan and rescue man out of his authority back to God's kingdom ([link]1 John 3:8[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:14[/link]; [link]Col. 1:13[/link]). Now, when the believers worship God in praying to Him or in speaking for Him, they should bear some signs that they are under God's headship, the divine authority, showing the observing angels (cf. [link]4:9[/link]), who are concerned with this matter, that they (the believers) are keeping God's ordained order in His administration. For this, the sisters should have a sign, a covering, on their head.

verse.text: However neither is woman without man, nor man without woman, [note]1[/note]in the Lord.
verse.note: I.e., in the Lord's plan, in the Lord's arrangement.

verse.text: For just as the woman is [note]1[/note]out from the man, so also is the man [note]1[/note]through the woman; but [xref]a[/xref]all things are out from God.
verse.note: Man is the source of the woman's existence. Hence, the woman is out of the man. Woman is the means through which the man is born. Hence, the man is through the woman ([link]Gen. 2:21-23[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Judge [i]this[/i] in your own selves: Is it fitting for a woman to pray uncovered to God?
Does not even [note]1[/note]nature itself teach you that if a man has long hair, it is a dishonor to him,
verse.note: I.e., our natural constitution according to God's creation. Nature itself tells us that man should not have long hair, but that the woman should. The woman realizes by her female constitution that to have long hair to cover her head is a glory. This too is strong ground for the apostle's teaching concerning head covering. His teaching is not according to customs or practices established by man but according to man's nature, which was created by God.

verse.text: But if a woman has long hair, it is a glory to her, because her long hair has been given to her for a covering.
But if anyone seems to be contentious, we do not have [note]1[/note]such a custom [i]of being so,[/i] neither the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]churches of God.
verse.note: The custom of contention, disputation, and debating. Neither the apostles nor the churches tolerated any disputation concerning the apostles' teaching.
That [i]churches[/i] here is plural indicates that all the local churches are independent of one another, yet they all act in the same way according to the apostles' teaching.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But I give [i]you[/i] [note]2[/note]this charge and do not [xref]a[/xref]praise [i]you,[/i] because you [xref]b[/xref]come together not for the better but for the worse.
verse.note: [i]But[/i] here indicates a contrast between [i]I[/i]... do not praise you in this verse and [i]I praise you[/i] in [link]v. 2[/link].
From this verse to the end of the chapter the apostle dealt with the eighth problem, the problem concerning the Lord's supper.

verse.text: For first of all, when you come together [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]in the church, I hear that [xref]b[/xref]divisions exist among you; and some part [i]of it[/i] I believe.
verse.note: I.e., in the assembly of the church ([link]14:34-35[/link]).

verse.text: For there must even be [note]1[/note]parties among you, that those who are [note]2[/note]approved may become [note]3[/note]manifest among you.
verse.note: Sects, schools of different opinions, as in [link]Gal. 5:20[/link].
Tested and found to have met the specifications.
Sects are useful for manifesting the approved ones, who are not sectarian.

verse.text: When therefore you come together in the same place, it is not to eat the [note]1[/note]Lord's supper;
verse.note: In [link]10:21[/link] the Lord's supper is called "the Lord's table." The emphasis of the Lord's table is on the fellowship of the Lord's blood and of His body ([link]10:16-17[/link]), the participation in the Lord, the enjoyment of the Lord in mutuality, in fellowship; whereas the stress of the Lord's supper is on the remembrance of the Lord ([link]vv. 24-25[/link]). At the Lord's table we receive His body and blood for our enjoyment; at the Lord's supper we give Him our remembrance for His enjoyment.

verse.text: For in your eating, each one takes his own [note]1[/note]supper first, and one is hungry and the other is drunk.
verse.note: In the apostle's time the believers had a custom of coming together for supper, the main meal of the day, with the rich bringing more and better food for the mutual enjoyment and the poor, less food. This was called a love feast ([link]2 Pet. 2:13[/link]; [link]Jude 12[/link]), and it came from the background of the passover feast ([link]Luke 22:13-20[/link]). At the end of their love feast they ate the Lord's supper with the bread and the cup to remember the Lord ([link]vv. 23-25[/link]). The Corinthians did not do it properly. They did not wait for one another (cf. [link]v. 33[/link]). Each took his own supper first. The rich became drunken and the poor were hungry ([link]v. 21[/link]). This caused divisions and parties among them ([link]v. 18[/link]) and spoiled the Lord's supper. Thus, their eating was not the eating of the Lord's supper ([link]v. 20[/link]).

verse.text: Do you not have houses to eat and drink in? Or do you despise the [xref]a[/xref]church of God and [xref]b[/xref]put those to shame who have not? What shall I say to you? Shall I praise you? In this I do not [xref]c[/xref]praise [i]you.[/i]

For I [xref]a[/xref]received from the Lord that which also I delivered to you, that the Lord Jesus [xref]b[/xref]in the night in which He was [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]betrayed [xref]d[/xref]took bread,
verse.note: Lit., delivered up.

verse.text: And having given thanks, He [note]1[/note]broke [i]it[/i] and said, This is My body, which is [i]given[/i] for you; this do [note]2[/note]unto the [note]3[/note]remembrance of Me.
verse.note: The bread is broken that we may eat it ([link]Matt. 26:26[/link]).

The word [i]unto,[/i] here and in the next verse, implies not only a purpose but also a result. Participation in the Lord's supper will surely produce a result — a continual remembrance of the Lord for His satisfaction.
To take the Lord's supper is for the remembrance of the Lord Himself, not for anything else.

verse.text: Similarly also the cup after they had dined, saying, This [note]1[/note]cup is the [xref]a[/xref]new covenant [i]established[/i] in My blood; this do, as often as you [note]2[/note]drink [i]it,[/i] unto the remembrance of Me.
verse.note: The bread is of life ([link]John 6:35[/link]) and the cup is of blessing ([link]10:16[/link]). This cup is the new covenant, comprising all the rich blessings of the New Testament, including God Himself. The new covenant was established by the Lord's blood, which He shed on the cross for our redemption ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]).

The real remembrance of the Lord is to eat the bread and drink the cup ([link]v. 26[/link]), that is, to participate in, to enjoy, the Lord, who has given Himself to us through His redeeming death. To eat the bread and drink the cup is to take in the redeeming Lord as our portion, as our life and blessing. This is to remember Him in a genuine way.

verse.text: For as often as you eat this bread and drink the cup, you [note]1[/note]declare the Lord's death [note]2[/note]until He [xref]a[/xref]comes.
verse.note: Or, proclaim, display. To take the Lord's supper is not to remember the Lord's death but to declare and display it. We remember the Lord Himself by declaring and displaying His death.

We should take the Lord's supper unto the remembrance of Him by declaring His redeeming death without ceasing until He comes back to set up God's kingdom ([link]Matt. 26:29[/link]). By His first coming the Lord accomplished His death to carry out an all-inclusive redemption for the producing of the church. After His death He went away to receive the kingdom, and He will come again with the kingdom ([link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]; [link]Luke 19:12[/link]). The period between His first and second comings is the church age. The church thus bridges the gap between the Lord's first coming and His second coming and connects His death in the past with God's kingdom in the future.
