Hence, to declare the Lord's death until He comes may imply the declaring of the existence of the church for the bringing in of the kingdom. When we eat the Lord's supper in this way, with a view to a continual remembrance of Him in His first and second comings, that supper becomes a satisfaction to Him in relation to the kingdom, God's administration.

verse.text: So then whoever [xref]a[/xref]eats the [xref]b[/xref]bread or [xref]a[/xref]drinks the [xref]b[/xref]cup of the Lord in an [note]1[/note]unworthy manner will [note]2[/note]be guilty of the body and of the [xref]c[/xref]blood of the Lord.
verse.note: I.e., not respecting the significance of the bread and the cup of the Lord, which signify His body broken for us and His blood shed for our sins through His death, accomplished for our redemption.
I.e., bring judgment to himself ([link]vv. 29-30[/link]).

verse.text: But let a man [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prove himself, and in this way let him eat of the bread and drink of the cup.
verse.note: I.e., examine himself, put himself to the test and have himself approved, meeting the prescribed specifications.

verse.text: For he who eats and drinks, eats and drinks [note]1[/note]judgment to himself if he does not [note]2[/note]discern [note]3[/note]the body.
verse.note: Eating the bread or drinking the cup of the Lord in an unworthy manner brings judgment to us. This judgment is not a condemnation but the Lord's temporary discipline ([link]v. 32[/link]).

Lit., to distinguish, separate, discriminate, make a distinction. To fail to discern the Lord's body is to fail to make a distinction between the bread, which signifies the Lord's body, and common food. It is to fail to evaluate the significance of the bread that we take at the Lord's supper. This brings judgment, the Lord's discipline, to us.

The apostle used the expression [i]the body[/i] instead of [i]the body of the Lord.[/i] This may imply the fact that, in addition to the physical body of the Lord ([link]v. 24[/link]), there is the mystical Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 4:4[/link]). Therefore, when we participate in the Lord's table, we must discern whether the bread on the table signifies the one Body of Christ or any division of man (any denomination). In discerning the Body of Christ, we should not partake of the bread in any division or with any divisive spirit. Our participation in the Lord's table must be the unique fellowship of His unique Body without any division in practice or in spirit.[br][br]The apostle's dealing with head covering concerns the Head ([link]v. 3[/link]); his dealing with the Lord's supper (the Lord's table) concerns the Body. Regarding the headship of Christ, which represents God and is represented by man, we must keep the divine governmental order ordained by God, without any disorder. Regarding the Body of Christ, we must be properly regulated by the apostle's instruction, without any confusion and division. The Head is Christ, and the Body is the church. Christ and the church — these two — are the controlling and directing factors of the apostle's dealings with the confused and disorderly church. In [link]chs. 1-10[/link] he dealt with the church's problems first by stressing Christ as God's center and our portion. After this, in [link]chs. 11-16[/link] he emphasized the church as God's goal and our concern. In [link]chs. 1-10[/link] he began with Christ as the antibiotic to heal the sick church's diseases. Then from [link]ch. 11[/link] he went on to the church and used the church, the Body, as the inoculation against the church's disorder. Both Christ and the church are crucial to the carrying out of God's administration in His New Testament economy.

verse.text: Because of [note]1[/note]this many among you are [note]2[/note]weak and sick, and a number [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]sleep.
verse.note: I.e., not discerning the body.

This is the discipline, the temporary judgment of the Lord, on those who participate unworthily in the Lord's body. The Lord first disciplined them, so that they became weak physically. Then, since they would not repent of their offense, they were further disciplined and became sick. Because they still would not repent, the Lord judged them by death. To die in this way is equivalent to being strewn along in the wilderness in [link]10:5[/link].
I.e., have died ([link]1 Thes. 4:13-16[/link]).

verse.text: But if we [note]1[/note]discerned ourselves, we would not be judged.
verse.note: I.e., discriminated ourselves, formed a right estimate of ourselves.

verse.text: But being [note]1[/note]judged by the Lord, we are [xref]a[/xref]disciplined that we may not be [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]condemned with the world.
verse.note: Temporarily.
Forever.

verse.text: So then, my brothers, when you come together to eat, [note]1[/note]wait for one another.
verse.note: This charge is due to the condition described in [link]v. 21[/link].

verse.text: If anyone is hungry, let him eat at [xref]a[/xref]home, that you may not come together for judgment. And the [note]1[/note]rest I will set in order when I [xref]b[/xref]come.
verse.note: This indicates that the apostle did not give instructions for everything related to the practice of the church. For "the rest" we need to seek the Lord's leading, based on and governed by the principles set forth in the New Testament.

verse.text: Now concerning [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spiritual [i]gifts,[/i] brothers, I do not want you to be [xref]b[/xref]ignorant.
verse.note: In [link]chs. 12-14[/link] Paul dealt with the ninth problem among the Corinthians, the problem of spiritual gifts in relation to God's administration and operation.

verse.text: You know that when you were [xref]a[/xref]Gentiles, you were [i]always[/i] being led away to [xref]b[/xref]dumb idols, whenever and however you were [note]1[/note]led.
verse.note: Like a violent wind, the frenzied promoting by the promoters of idolatry among the Greeks in those days was leading people away to idols. Here the apostle referred to the leading of this kind that the Corinthian believers received in the days when they were Gentiles. They were led away to different kinds of idols to worship and serve them, at whatever time and in whatever way they were led by the frenzied ones.

verse.text: Therefore I make known to you that no one [note]1[/note]speaking in the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit of God says, Jesus [i]is[/i] [note]2[/note]accursed; and [note]3[/note]no one can say, [xref]b[/xref]Jesus [i]is[/i] Lord! except in the [xref]c[/xref]Holy Spirit.
verse.note: The apostle's thought here was that the dumb, voiceless idols in [link]v. 2[/link] make their worshippers dumb and voiceless. But the living God causes His worshippers to speak in His Spirit. This kind of speaking is related to the spiritual gifts. No one who speaks in the Spirit of God would say, "Jesus is accursed"; he would like to say, and he is able to say, "Jesus is Lord!" No worshippers of God should be silent; all should use their voices to speak forth "Jesus is Lord!" in the Spirit of God. This — to speak "Jesus is Lord!" — is the main function of all the spiritual gifts.
See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

This indicates that when we say with a proper spirit, "Jesus is Lord!" we are in the Holy Spirit. Hence, to call on the Lord Jesus is the way to participate in, to enjoy, and to experience the Holy Spirit.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But there are [note]2[/note]distinctions of [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]gifts, but the [xref]b[/xref]same Spirit;
verse.note: [i]But[/i] here indicates a contrast between [link]v. 3[/link] and [link]v. 4[/link]. [link]Verse 3[/link] says that when we minister by speaking in the Spirit of God, we all say "Jesus is Lord!" exalting Jesus as the Lord. But the gifts for the manifestation of the Spirit are different, diverse.
Or, diversities, varieties, distributions. So also in [link]vv. 5-6[/link].

[i]Gifts[/i] here refers to the outward gifts, the abilities or capacities for service. Some of them are miraculous, and some are developed out of the initial gifts mentioned in [link]1:7[/link] (see note 1 there). All are different from the initial gifts.

verse.text: And there are distinctions of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ministries, yet the [xref]b[/xref]same Lord;
verse.note: I.e., services. The gifts in [link]v. 4[/link] are for these ministries, in which the operations in [link]v. 6[/link] are manifested.

verse.text: And there are distinctions of [note]1[/note]operations, but the [xref]a[/xref]same [note]2[/note]God, who [xref]b[/xref]operates all things in all.
verse.note: Lit., effects of operations. Referring to the result produced by the divine power's energizing of the gifts in their activities. This result is the operation ([link]Eph. 4:16[/link]) manifested by the gifts.

The gifts are by the Spirit; the ministries, the services, are initiated by the Lord and are for the Lord; and the operations are of God. Here the Triune God is involved in these three matters — the gifts, the ministries, and the operations. The gifts by the Spirit are to carry out the ministries for the Lord, and in the ministries for the Lord are manifested the operations of the gifts, produced by God's operating, God's working. This is the Triune God moving in the believers for the accomplishing of His eternal purpose to build up the church, the Body of Christ, for the expression of God.

verse.text: But to [xref]a[/xref]each one is given the [note]1[/note]manifestation of the Spirit [note]2[/note]for [xref]b[/xref]what is profitable.
verse.note: All the different gifts are the manifestation of the Spirit, in that the Spirit is manifested in the believers who have received the gifts. Such manifestation of the Spirit is for the profit of the church, the Body of Christ.
I.e., for the growth in life of the members of the Body of Christ and for the building up of Christ's Body.

verse.text: For to one through the Spirit a [note]1[/note]word of [xref]a[/xref]wisdom is given, and to another a [note]1[/note]word of [xref]b[/xref]knowledge, according to the same Spirit;
verse.note: According to the context of this book, the word of wisdom is the word concerning Christ as the deeper things of God, predestined by God to be our portion ([link]1:24[/link], [link]30[/link]; [link]2:6-10[/link]). The word of knowledge is the word that imparts a general knowledge of things concerning God and the Lord ([link]8:1-7[/link]). The word of wisdom is mainly out of our spirit through revelation; the word of knowledge is mainly out of our understanding through teaching. The former is deeper than the latter. However, both of these, not speaking in tongues nor any other miraculous gift, are listed as the first gifts and the topmost manifestation of the Spirit because both are the most profitable ministries, or services, for the edification of the saints and the building up of the church to carry out God's operation.

verse.text: To a different one [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith in the same Spirit, and to another [note]2[/note]gifts of [xref]b[/xref]healing in the one Spirit,
verse.note: Such as the faith that can remove mountains, as mentioned in [link]13:2[/link] and [link]Mark 11:22-24[/link].
Miraculous power for healing different diseases.

verse.text: And to another operations of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]works of power, and to another [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]prophecy, and to another [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]discerning of spirits; to a different one [i]various[/i] kinds of [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]tongues, and to another [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]interpretation of tongues.
verse.note: Works of miraculous power, miracles, other than healing, such as Peter's raising of Dorcas from the dead ([link]Acts 9:36-42[/link]).

Speaking for God and speaking forth God, including foretelling and predicting. To speak for God and to speak forth God are gifts out of life, gifts developed by the growth in life; foretelling and predicting are miraculous gifts and have nothing to do with life (see second half of note [link]10[sup]5[/sup][/link]).
To distinguish the Spirit that is out of God from those spirits that are not out of God ([link]1 Tim. 4:1[/link]; [link]1 John 4:1-3[/link]).

A proper language or dialect ([link]Acts 2:4[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]11[/link]) either of men or of angels ([link]13:1[/link]), not meaningless voices or sounds. The genuine and proper speaking in tongues is one of the many gifts of the Spirit ([link]v. 4[/link]), one of the many aspects of the manifestation of the Spirit ([link]v. 7[/link]). Some say that speaking in tongues is the initial evidence of the baptism in the Spirit, and that later it becomes a gift of the Spirit. They say that every believer must speak in tongues as the initial evidence, but that not every believer needs to have the gift of speaking in tongues. This kind of teaching has no ground in the New Testament. The New Testament makes it abundantly clear that speaking in tongues is only one of the many gifts of the Spirit and that not all the believers have this gift.

To make the unknown tongues known, understandable ([link]14:13[/link]). This is the ninth item of the manifestation of the Spirit listed here. However, the manifestation of the Spirit by the believers consists of more than nine items. The apostleship, helps, and administrations by the Spirit listed in [link]v. 28[/link], the seeing of visions and the dreaming of dreams by the Spirit mentioned in [link]Acts 2:17[/link], the signs and wonders referred to in [link]Heb. 2:4[/link], and three of the five miraculous acts prophesied in [link]Mark 16:17-18[/link] are not listed here. The apostle listed here only nine items of the Spirit's manifestation as an illustration. Of these nine, speaking in tongues and interpretation of tongues are listed as the last two because they are not as profitable as the other items for the building up of the church ([link]14:2-6[/link], [link]18-19[/link]). Of these nine gifts and those listed in [link]vv. 28-30[/link], prophecy as prediction, faith, gifts of healing, works of power, speaking in tongues, and interpretation of tongues are miraculous. The rest — a word of wisdom (such as the word of the apostles), a word of knowledge (such as the word of the teachers), and speaking for God and speaking forth God in prophecy by the prophets, discerning of spirits, helps, and administrations — are gifts developed by the growth in life ([link]3:6-7[/link]), like those listed in [link]Rom. 12:6-8[/link], out of the inward, initial gifts mentioned in [link]1:7[/link] (see note 1 there). The miraculous gifts, especially speaking in tongues and interpretation of tongues, do not require any growth in life. The Corinthians did much speaking in tongues, yet they still remained infants in Christ ([link]3:1-3[/link]). However, the gifts developed in life require growth in life, even maturity, for the building up of the church. It was for this purpose that this Epistle was written to the Corinthians.

verse.text: But the one and the same Spirit operates all these things, [xref]a[/xref]distributing to each one respectively even as He [xref]b[/xref]purposes.
[note]1[/note]For even as the body is [xref]a[/xref]one and has many [xref]b[/xref]members, yet all the members of the body, being many, are one body, so also is [note]2[/note]the Christ.
verse.note: [i]For[/i] indicates that this verse is an explanation of [link]v. 11[/link], which says that the one Spirit operates all the various aspects of His manifestation, distributing them to many believers individually. This is just like our physical body in its being one and having many members.

Referring to the corporate Christ, composed of Christ Himself as the Head and the church as His Body with all the believers as members. All the believers of Christ are organically united with Him and constituted with His life and element and have thus become His Body, an organism, to express Him. Hence, He is not only the Head but also the Body. As our physical body has many members yet is one, so is this Christ.

verse.text: For also in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]one Spirit we were all [xref]b[/xref]baptized into [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]one Body, whether [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]Jews or Greeks, whether [note]4[/note]slaves or free, and were all given to [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]drink one [xref]f[/xref]Spirit.
verse.note: As the Spirit is the sphere and element of our spiritual baptism, and as in such a Spirit we were all baptized into one organic entity, the Body of Christ, so we should all, regardless of our race, nationality, and social rank, be this one Body. Christ is the life and constituent of this Body, and the Spirit is the reality of Christ. It is in this one Spirit that we were all baptized into this one living Body to express Christ.

The believers of Christ are baptized through water and in the Spirit into (1) Christ, (2) the death of Christ ([link]Rom. 6:3[/link]), (3) the name — the person — of the Triune God ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]), and (4) the Body of Christ. Baptism ushers the believers into an organic union with Christ and the Triune God, making them living members of the Body of Christ. All the gifts, as the manifestation of the Spirit distributed to the individual believers by the Spirit, are for the profit, the building up, of this Body. The apostle was very conscious of this. He was Body-conscious, Body-centered, unlike the Corinthians and so many other believers through the centuries who are self-centered concerning spiritual gifts. Hence, after this verse he gave the Corinthians a long discourse concerning the Body. His intention was to rescue them from self-seeking back to a concern for the Body, that they might no longer be for their individual profit but for the building up of the Body.
Referring to races and nationalities.
Referring to social ranks.

To be baptized in the Spirit is to get into the Spirit and to be lost in Him; to drink the Spirit is to take the Spirit in and to have our being saturated with Him. By these two procedures we are mingled with the Spirit. To be baptized in the Spirit is the initiation of the mingling and is once for all. To drink the Spirit is the continuation and accomplishment of the mingling and is perpetual, forever. This requires us to call on the Lord continually and draw water with joy from Him as the fountain of living water ([link]Isa. 12:3-4[/link]; [link]John 4:10[/link], [link]14[/link]).

verse.text: For the body is not one member but [xref]a[/xref]many.
If the foot should say, Because I am not a hand, I am not of the body, [i]it is[/i] not [i]that[/i] because of this it is not of the body.
And if the ear should say, Because I am not an eye, I am not of the body, [i]it is[/i] not [i]that[/i] because of this it is not of the body.
If the whole body were an eye, where would the hearing be? If the whole were the hearing, where would the smelling be?
But now God has [xref]a[/xref]placed the members, each one of them, in the body, even as He [xref]b[/xref]willed.
And if all were one member, where would the body be?
But now the members are many, but the body [xref]a[/xref]one.
And the eye cannot say to the hand, I have no need of you; nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.
But much rather the members of the body which seem to be weaker are necessary.
And those [i]members[/i] of the body which we consider to be less honorable, these we clothe with more abundant honor; and our uncomely [i]members come to[/i] have more abundant comeliness,
But our comely [i]members[/i] have no need. But God has [note]1[/note]blended the body together, giving more abundant honor to the [i]member[/i] that lacked,
verse.note: Implying to be mutually adjusted. God has blended all the different members of Christ together into one Body. For this we need much transformation ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]); that is, we need to be transformed from the natural life to the spiritual by the same Spirit for the practical Body life.

verse.text: That there would be no [xref]a[/xref]division in the body, but [i]that[/i] the members would have the [note]1[/note]same care for one another.
verse.note: In the Body life the same care should be given to all the different members. A difference in care causes division.

verse.text: And whether one member [xref]a[/xref]suffers, all the members suffer with [i]it;[/i] or one member is glorified, all the members [xref]b[/xref]rejoice with [i]it.[/i]
Now you are the Body of Christ, and [xref]a[/xref]members individually.

And God has [xref]a[/xref]placed some in the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]church: first [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]apostles, second [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]prophets, third [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]teachers; then [note]5[/note][xref]f[/xref]works of power, then [note]6[/note]gifts of [xref]g[/xref]healing, [note]7[/note]helps, [note]8[/note][xref]h[/xref]administrations, [i]various[/i] kinds of [note]9[/note][xref]i[/xref]tongues.
verse.note: The church here refers to the church in both its universal and local aspects. In [link]vv. 12-27[/link] the church is the Body of Christ. The Body is an organism for Christ as the believers' life to grow and express Himself. The church is an assembly for God to operate His administration.

Those who are called and sent by God ([link]1:1[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:1[/link]) (1) to preach the gospel that sinners may be saved to be the materials for the building of the church, (2) to establish the churches ([link]Acts 14:21-23[/link]), and (3) to teach the divine truth (see note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 9[/link]). Their ministry is universal for all the churches.

Those who speak for God and speak forth God by God's revelation, and who speak sometimes with inspired prediction ([link]Acts 11:27-28[/link]). For the edifying of the saints and the establishing of the churches, they are second only to the apostles.

Those who teach the truths according to the apostles' teaching ([link]Acts 2:42[/link]) and the prophets' revelation. Both prophets and teachers are universal as well as local ([link]Eph. 4:11[/link]; [link]Acts 13:1[/link]).
See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link].
See note [link]9[sup]2[/sup][/link].
Or, helpers, helpings. These must refer to the services of the deacons and deaconesses ([link]1 Tim. 3:8-13[/link]).
Or, administrators, governings; referring to the eldership in the church.
See note [link]10[sup]4[/sup][/link]. This is the second time that speaking in tongues is listed as the last of the aspects of God's operation in the church.

verse.text: Are all apostles? Are all prophets? Are all teachers? Do all [i]have[/i] works of power?
Do all have gifts of healing? Do all [note]1[/note]speak in tongues? [note]2[/note]Do all [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]interpret [i]tongues?[/i]
verse.note: Speaking in tongues and interpretation of tongues are again, for the third time, listed last in Paul's writing because they render the least profit to the church ([link]14:4-6[/link], [link]19[/link]).
Of course, the answer to this question and the other six is no.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]earnestly [xref]a[/xref]desire the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]greater gifts. And moreover I show to you a [note]3[/note]most excellent way.
verse.note: Or, be zealous for, delight in.

This indicates that some gifts, such as speaking in tongues and interpretation of tongues, are smaller because they are less profitable to the church, and that we should desire earnestly the greater gifts, such as prophesying and teaching, which are more profitable for the building up of the church ([link]14:1-6[/link]). To have these greater gifts, we need to grow in life unto maturity. The greater gifts are developed, by growth in life, out of the initial gifts ([link]1:7[/link]) that we received when we were regenerated.
The most excellent way to have the greater gifts is love, which is fully defined in the following chapter.

verse.text: If I speak in the [xref]a[/xref]tongues of men and of angels but do not have [xref]b[/xref]love, I have become [note]1[/note]sounding brass or a [note]1[/note]clanging cymbal.
verse.note: Sounding brass and a clanging cymbal give sounds without life. This is a genuine illustration of tongue-speaking.

verse.text: And if I have [i]the gift of[/i] [xref]a[/xref]prophecy and know all [xref]b[/xref]mysteries and all [xref]c[/xref]knowledge, and if I have all [xref]d[/xref]faith so as to [xref]e[/xref]remove mountains, but do not have love, I am nothing.

And if I [xref]a[/xref]dole out all my possessions to feed [i]others,[/i] and if I [note]1[/note]deliver up my [xref]b[/xref]body [note]2[/note]that I may boast, but do not have love, I profit nothing.
verse.note: As a martyr.
Some MSS read, that I may be burned.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Love [xref]b[/xref]suffers long. Love is kind; it is not [xref]c[/xref]jealous. Love does not [xref]d[/xref]brag [i]and[/i] is not [xref]e[/xref]puffed up;
verse.note: Life is the element of God; love is the expression of God as life. Hence, God is love ([link]1 John 4:16[/link]). God as life is expressed in love. All the fifteen virtues of love listed in [link]vv. 4-7[/link] are the divine virtues of God's life. Such a life differs from the outward gifts listed in [link]ch. 12[/link]. The Corinthians were pursuing the outward gifts, but they neglected love, the expression of God's life. Hence, they were still fleshy, fleshly, or soulish ([link]3:1[/link], [link]3[/link]; [link]2:14[/link]). They needed to grow in life (expressed by their love in caring for the Body of Christ), pursuing love, not the outward gifts, that they might be spiritual ([link]2:15[/link]).

verse.text: It does not behave unbecomingly [i]and[/i] does not [xref]a[/xref]seek its own things; it is not provoked [i]and[/i] does not take account of evil;
It does [xref]a[/xref]not rejoice because of [note]1[/note]unrighteousness, but [xref]b[/xref]rejoices with the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]truth;
verse.note: The totality of unrighteousness is Satan, and the totality of truth is God. Love as the expression of the divine life does not rejoice over Satan's unrighteousness but rejoices with God's truth.

verse.text: It [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]covers all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]bear[/i] in [link]9:12[/link] (see note there). This word means not only (1) [i]to contain, to hold (as a vessel[/i]), and (2) [i]to cover (as a roof[/i]) others' mistakes, but also (3) [i]to shelter and protect by covering (as a roof[/i]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Love [note]1[/note]never falls [i]away.[/i] But whether [xref]b[/xref]prophecies, they will be rendered useless; or [xref]c[/xref]tongues, they will cease; or [xref]d[/xref]knowledge, it will be rendered useless.
verse.note: I.e., survives everything, holds its place. Love survives everything and holds its place forever. It never fails, never fades out or comes to an end. It is like the eternal life of God. All the gifts, whether prophecies, or tongues, or knowledge, are means for God's operation; they are not life, which expresses God. Hence, they will cease and be rendered useless. They are all dispensational. Only life, which love expresses, is eternal. According to the succeeding verses, all gifts are for the immature child in this age. They will all be rendered useless in the next age. Only love is characteristic of a mature man and will last for eternity. Hence, when we live and act by love, we have a foretaste of the next age and of eternity.

verse.text: For we [xref]a[/xref]know in part, and we prophesy in part;
But [note]1[/note]when that which is [note]2[/note]complete comes, [note]3[/note]that which is in part will be rendered useless.
verse.note: In the next age — the kingdom age.
Or, mature; in contrast to being a child in the next verse.
I.e., prophecies, knowledge, etc., as mentioned in [link]v. 8[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]When I was a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]child, I spoke as a child, I thought as a [xref]b[/xref]child, I [note]3[/note]reasoned as a child; [note]4[/note]since I have become a man, I have done away with childish things.
verse.note: In this age the believers are children, having all the childish gifts.
I.e., immature.
Lit., reckoned.

In the next age the mature believers will become men, and all the childish gifts, especially those that are least — tongue-speaking and its interpretation — will be rendered useless. However, we can have a foretaste of the next age by living a life of love in this age. Love matures us in life; gifts keep us in childhood.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]now we see [note]2[/note]in a [xref]a[/xref]mirror [note]3[/note]obscurely, but at [note]4[/note]that time [xref]b[/xref]face to face; [note]1[/note]now I [xref]c[/xref]know in part, but at [note]4[/note]that time I will fully [xref]d[/xref]know even as also I was fully known.
verse.note: In this age.

Some sources say that this is to see through a window. "That is, through some medium which, in degree, hinders vision. The word means also 'a mirror,' but it is used for window, made, not of clear transparent glass, as now, but of semi-transparent materials" — J. N. Darby in his New Translation.
Lit., in a riddle.
In the next age.

verse.text: Now there abide [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith, [xref]b[/xref]hope, [xref]c[/xref]love, these three; and the greatest of these is [xref]d[/xref]love.
verse.note: Faith receives the divine things ([link]John 1:12[/link]) and substantiates the spiritual and unseen things ([link]Heb. 11:1[/link]). Hope reaps and partakes of the things substantiated by faith ([link]Rom. 8:24-25[/link]). Love enjoys the things received and substantiated by faith and partaken of by hope, for nourishing ourselves, building up others ([link]8:1[/link]), and expressing God, thus fulfilling the entire law ([link]Rom. 13:8-10[/link]). Such love causes us to grow in life for the development and use of the spiritual gifts, and it is the most excellent way to have the greater gifts. Hence, it is the greatest of the three abiding virtues. So we must pursue it ([link]14:1[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Pursue [xref]b[/xref]love, and [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]desire earnestly [xref]d[/xref]spiritual [i]gifts,[/i] but especially that you may [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]prophesy.
verse.note: This charge is based on the revelation in [link]12:31-13:13[/link]. To pursue love is to seek after growth in life for the development of the gifts in life. Hence, it must be matched with an earnest desire for the most profitable gift, the gift of prophecy.
See note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link] (so also in [link]14:39[/link]).

Since to prophesy is to speak for the Lord and speak forth the Lord, that is, to minister Christ to people, which is the main element in the church meeting, prophesying requires the divine life to fill it as its content. Love is the most excellent way to experience the divine life and make it the content of the gift of prophecy for the building up of the church. Hence, we must pursue love and desire earnestly this greater gift.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For he who speaks in a [xref]a[/xref]tongue does not speak to men but to God; for no one hears, but in [i]his[/i] [xref]b[/xref]spirit he speaks [xref]c[/xref]mysteries.
verse.note: The apostle's word in [link]vv. 2-6[/link] gives a clear and definite view that speaking in tongues is much less important than prophesying. The apostle strongly belittled the gift of tongues and exalted the gift of prophecy because his main concern was the church, not the individual believers. Speaking in tongues, even if it is genuine and proper, edifies only the speaker himself, but prophesying builds up the church. To prophesy in revelation or to teach in knowledge with clear, understandable words is more profitable to the church than to speak in tongues with unknown words ([link]v. 19[/link]).

verse.text: But he who prophesies speaks [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]building up and encouragement and consolation to men.
verse.note: Or, edification. Since prophesying, speaking forth the Lord, ministers Christ to people, it builds up people and gives them encouragement and consolation.

verse.text: He who speaks in a tongue builds up himself, but he who prophesies [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]builds up the [xref]b[/xref]church.
verse.note: Prophesying, speaking forth the Lord, builds up not only the individual saints but also the church.

verse.text: I desire that you all speak in tongues, but especially that you would [xref]a[/xref]prophesy; and [xref]b[/xref]greater is he who prophesies than he who speaks in tongues, unless he [xref]c[/xref]interprets, that the church may receive building up.

But now, brothers, if I come to you speaking in [xref]a[/xref]tongues, what will I [xref]b[/xref]profit you, unless I speak to you either in [xref]c[/xref]revelation or in [xref]d[/xref]knowledge or in [xref]e[/xref]prophecy or in [xref]f[/xref]teaching?

Yet [i]even[/i] [note]1[/note]lifeless things, whether flute or harp, in giving a sound, if they give [note]2[/note]no distinction in the tones, how will what is played on the flute or on the harp be known?
verse.note: Lit., without soul.

The apostle's illustrations in [link]vv. 7-11[/link] indicate that the Corinthian believers abused speaking in tongues by doing it in a nonsensical way, uttering sounds with no distinction in the tones ([link]v. 7[/link]) and giving forth uncertain sounds ([link]v. 8[/link]). They also overused it by practicing it in any place, in any way, and in any situation. Hence, the apostle corrected them and restricted them from abusing and using excessively such a small gift of the least profit, that they might seek the greater gifts and abound in the edifying of the saints and the building up of the church.

verse.text: For also if the [xref]a[/xref]trumpet gives an uncertain sound, who will prepare himself for [xref]b[/xref]battle?
So also you, unless you give with the tongue a word easy to understand, how will what is being said be known? For you will be speaking into the [xref]a[/xref]air.
There are perhaps many kinds of [note]1[/note]voices in the world, and not one is [note]2[/note]without significance.
verse.note: In Greek the same as [i]sound[/i] in [link]vv. 7-8[/link]. Here it denotes voices, that is, languages (so also in [link]v. 11[/link]).
Lit., voiceless.

verse.text: If then I do not know the [note]1[/note]meaning of the voice, I will be to him who is speaking a [note]2[/note]barbarian, and he who is speaking a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]barbarian to me.
verse.note: Lit., effect. The same Greek word as for [i]power.[/i]

The Greek word means [i]a foreigner,[/i] i.e., a non-Greek, one who does not speak Greek. "Supposed to be originally a descriptive word of those who uttered harsh, rude accents....Later, the word took the sense of outlandish or rude" (Vincent).

verse.text: So also you, since you are zealous of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirits, seek that you may [note]2[/note]excel for the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]building up of the church.
verse.note: Here the apostle said, "So also you, since you are zealous of spirits." This shows that in their spiritual pursuings in those days, because of their background the Corinthian believers, who were Gentiles by birth, confused the unique Holy Spirit with the various evil spirits; they were not clear about nor did they adequately hold the uniqueness of the Holy Spirit. This is proved by the words [i]but the same Spirit[/i] in [link]12:4[/link]. The apostle's word here did not sanction their confused pursuings; rather, based on the fact of their confusion, he exhorted them to seek to transcend and thereby to excel in the midst of their confusion.

The Greek word denotes [i]to become full, to abound, to overflow;[/i] it also denotes [i]to excel.[/i] See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]. According to the context of this verse, the word here does not denote [i]to abound, to increase,[/i] but [i]to excel and be extraordinary.[/i] The words [i]since you are zealous of spirits[/i] in the first part of this verse indicate already that in their pursuing of spiritual gifts, the Corinthian believers were confusing the Holy Spirit with the evil spirits. The apostle considered that kind of confused pursuing very demeaning, to the extent that the Corinthian believers might even have been considered barbarians. Therefore, the apostle exhorted them not to pursue some indiscernible, intermixed spiritual things for their own enjoyment and display, but to pursue so as to excel, that is, go beyond the low pursuing, for the building up of the church.

The apostle was fully occupied with the consideration of building up the church. He was fully church-conscious and church-centered, altogether different from the self-centered Corinthians. Their problem with spiritual gifts was due to their self-seeking, their not caring for the building up of the church. In dealing with the first six problems, which were in the realm of human life, the apostle stressed Christ as God's unique portion to us; in dealing with the last five problems, which were in the realm of the divine administration, he emphasized the church as God's unique goal for us. The Corinthians were not only void of Christ but also ignorant of the church. The apostle's completing ministry ([link]Col. 1:25[/link]) is composed of Christ as the mystery of God ([link]Col. 2:2[/link]) and the church as the mystery of Christ ([link]Eph. 3:4[/link]). However, the Corinthians missed both, even though they were under the apostle's ministry. They were pitifully in themselves, blind and ignorant.

verse.text: Therefore let him who speaks in a tongue pray that he may [xref]a[/xref]interpret.
For if I pray in a tongue, my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit prays, but my [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]mind is unfruitful.
verse.note: For our spirit to be used and exercised in prayer is surely healthy for our spiritual life. But for our mind to be unfruitful and unused is absolutely unhealthy. In praying to the Lord, we must exercise our regenerated spirit and our renewed mind. Our mind should be set on our spirit ([link]Rom. 8:6[/link]) and should never be detached from it, even in our daily walk, needless to say in our prayer. Our prayer must be from our God-contacted and God-contacting spirit and through our sober and understanding mind, with clear and understandable words, that our prayer may touch God, nourish and strengthen ourselves, and build up others.

verse.text: What then? I will pray with the [xref]a[/xref]spirit, and I will pray [note]1[/note]also [note]2[/note]with the mind; I will [xref]b[/xref]sing with the spirit, and I will [xref]c[/xref]sing [note]1[/note]also [note]2[/note]with the mind.
verse.note: This implies that the apostle encouraged the receivers of his letter to pray not only in an unknown tongue but also with clear and understandable words.

This does not mean to pray with the mind only and not at all with the spirit. In [link]Eph. 6:18[/link] the apostle charged us to pray at every time in spirit. Prayer is worship, which should be in spirit ([link]John 4:24[/link]). When we pray with the spirit, not in an unknown tongue but in understandable words, our mind is automatically used to interpret and express the thought of the spirit. What the apostle meant here is that in the church meeting, for the profit of all the attendants, we should pray with our mind in intelligible words ([link]v. 19[/link]) to express the burden in our spirit. In a church meeting our prayer not only should be heard by the Lord for His answer but also should be intelligible to all the attendants for their profit. For this purpose we should learn to use our mind in public prayer just as we use our spirit, training our mind to cooperate with our spirit, even to be one with our spirit, that the spirit may become the spirit of our mind ([link]Eph. 4:23[/link]).

verse.text: Otherwise if you [xref]a[/xref]bless with the spirit, how shall he who fills the place of the [note]1[/note]unlearned [i]in tongues[/i] say the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Amen at your giving of [xref]c[/xref]thanks, since he does not know what you are saying?
verse.note: Lit., layman; i.e., one who is brought into a certain matter untaught, uninstructed (so also in [link]vv. 23-24[/link]).
This reveals that in the church meetings during the apostle's time, when one prayed, all the others said Amen, even "the Amen" with emphasis.

verse.text: For you give thanks well, but the other is not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]built up.
verse.note: This indicates that not only our prophesying and teaching in the church meetings but also our prayers and thanks to the Lord should build up others. This shows how much the apostle was concerned with the building up of the church and the saints. His word in this verse is not only a correction but a charge.

verse.text: I thank God, I speak in tongues more than all of you,
But in the church I would rather [xref]a[/xref]speak [note]1[/note]five words [note]2[/note]with my mind, that I might instruct others also, than [note]1[/note]ten thousand words in a tongue.
verse.note: This shows how much speaking in intelligible words is needed in the church meeting for the building up of the church, and that speaking in tongues is not needed at all.
See note [link]15[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Brothers, do not be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]children in your [note]2[/note]understanding, but in [xref]b[/xref]malice be [xref]c[/xref]babes and in [i]your[/i] [note]2[/note]understanding be [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]full-grown.
verse.note: The Corinthian believers were not only infants in life ([link]3:1[/link]) but also children in understanding. They needed to grow both in life and in their mind's understanding. All the apostle's efforts to deal with their problems were for this purpose, that they might mature in every way.

Or, thinking, reasoning, mind. In Greek the word is different from the word for [i]mind[/i] in [link]vv. 15[/link] and [link]19[/link], which "emphasizes the distinction from ecstasy" (Vincent). This is in regard to the Corinthian believers' understanding and thinking concerning speaking in tongues. They were ecstatic in this practice and thus were childish in their understanding concerning it, not using their mind properly as a mature believer should. The apostle advised them to grow and become full-grown in their understanding, that is, in the proper use of their mind, as he had done ([link]v. 19[/link]), in the matter of tongue-speaking.
The childish Corinthian believers needed to become full-grown in their understanding that they might be able to know the things that are mentioned in [link]vv. 21-25[/link].

verse.text: In the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]law it is written, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]"By those of other tongues and with the lips of others I will speak to this people; even so they will not listen to Me, says the Lord."
verse.note: Referring to the Old Testament. See note [link]34[sup]3[/sup][/link].

This word in [link]Isa. 28:9-13[/link] indicates that the speaking in strange tongues was a chastisement to the children of Israel because they did not believe the intelligible word of God. Hence, the apostle's quoting of this word implies that the Corinthians had not properly received the intelligible revelation of God through the apostles.

verse.text: So then tongues are for a [note]1[/note]sign, not to those who believe but to the unbelievers; but prophecy [i]is for a sign[/i] not to the unbelievers but to those who believe.
verse.note: [i]So then[/i] at the beginning of this verse indicates that according to the word in [link]v. 21[/link] quoted from [link]Isa. 28[/link], tongues are for a negative sign to the unbelievers, signifying their poor condition of unbelief. It implies that wherever a strange tongue is spoken, people's unbelief is there. The apostle's intention here was to hold the Corinthians back from their excessive practice of speaking in tongues. But prophecy is for a positive sign to those who believe, signifying their proper condition of belief. This is an encouragement to the practice of prophesying.

verse.text: If therefore the whole church [xref]a[/xref]comes together in one place, and [note]1[/note]all speak in tongues, and some unlearned [i]in tongues[/i] or unbelievers enter, will they not say that you are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]insane?
verse.note: If in a meeting of the whole church all speak in tongues, an observer might consider that all the attendants are insane. Hence, to encourage all to speak in tongues in the church meeting is not right; it is against the apostle Paul's word.
Or, mad, raving mad. This word is a strong discouragement to the excessive speaking in tongues.

verse.text: But if [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]all prophesy and some unbeliever or unlearned person enters, he is [note]2[/note]convicted by all, he is [note]2[/note]examined by all;
verse.note: This implies that all the attendants have not only the obligation but also the capacity to prophesy. If all prophesy in the church meeting, people will be convicted. This kind of prophesying must not be mainly to predict but to speak for the Lord and speak forth the Lord.

This would not result from the prophecy of prediction but from the prophecy of speaking for the Lord and speaking forth the Lord. This latter kind of prophecy requires some amount of growth in life. This word also is an encouragement to the practice of prophesying.

verse.text: The secrets of his [xref]a[/xref]heart become manifest; and so [xref]b[/xref]falling on [i]his[/i] face, he will worship [note]1[/note]God, declaring that indeed [note]1[/note]God is [xref]c[/xref]among you.
verse.note: This implies that prophesying, speaking for God and speaking forth God with God as the content, ministers God to the hearers and brings them to God. This also indicates that the church meeting should be filled with God, and that all its activities should convey and transmit God to people that they may be infused with God.

verse.text: What then, brothers? Whenever you [xref]a[/xref]come together, each one [note]1[/note]has a [xref]b[/xref]psalm, has a [xref]c[/xref]teaching, has a [xref]d[/xref]revelation, has a [xref]e[/xref]tongue, has an [xref]f[/xref]interpretation. Let all things be done for [note]2[/note][xref]g[/xref]building up.
verse.note: [i]Has,[/i] occurring five times in this verse, is a widely used Greek word, a word with many meanings, of which the following three are the main ones: (1) [i]to hold, to possess, to keep (a certain thing);[/i] (2) [i]to have (a certain thing) for enjoyment;[/i] (3) [i]to have the means or power to do a certain thing.[/i] The first two meanings should be applied to the first three of the five items listed in this verse, and the third to the last two — a tongue and an interpretation of a tongue. This indicates that when we come to the church meeting, we should have something of the Lord to share with others, whether a psalm to praise the Lord, a teaching (of the teacher) to minister the riches of Christ to edify and nourish others, a revelation (of the prophet, [link]v. 30[/link]) to give visions of God's eternal purpose concerning Christ as God's mystery and the church as Christ's mystery, a tongue for a sign to the unbelievers ([link]v. 22[/link]) that they may know and accept Christ, or an interpretation to make a tongue concerning Christ and His Body understandable. Before coming to the meeting, we should prepare ourselves for the meeting with such things from the Lord and of the Lord, either through our experience of Him or through our enjoyment of His word and fellowship with Him in prayer. After coming into the meeting, we need not wait, and should not wait, for inspiration; we should exercise our spirit and use our trained mind to function in presenting what we have prepared to the Lord for His glory and satisfaction and to the attendants for their benefit — their enlightenment, nourishment, and building up.[br][br]This is like the Feast of Tabernacles in ancient times. The children of Israel brought the produce of the good land, which they had reaped from their labor on the land, to the feast and offered it to the Lord for His enjoyment and for their mutual participation in fellowship with the Lord and with one another. We must labor on Christ, our good land, that we may reap some produce of His riches to bring to the church meeting and offer. Thus the meeting will be an exhibition of Christ in His riches and will be a mutual enjoyment of Christ shared by all the attendants before God and with God for the building up of the saints and the church.[br][br]According to the stress and emphasis of this Epistle, all five items listed in this verse should focus on Christ as God's center for our portion and the church as God's goal for our aim. The psalm should be the praise to God for giving Christ as wisdom and power to us for our daily life and church life. The teaching from a teacher and the revelation from a prophet should teach and minister Christ and the church, which is the Body of Christ, to people. A tongue and its interpretation also should have Christ and the church as their center and content. Any stress on things other than Christ and the church will bring confusion to the church and distract it from the central lane of God's New Testament economy, making it like the church in Corinth.

Or, edification. Whatever we do in the church meeting must be for the building up of the saints and the church. To exhibit Christ and enjoy Him in the meetings for the building up of His Body must be our unique purpose and goal.

verse.text: If anyone speaks in a tongue, [i]it should be[/i] by [xref]a[/xref]two, or at the most three, and in turn, and one should interpret;
But if there is no interpreter, he should be silent [xref]a[/xref]in the [note]1[/note]church, and speak to himself and to God.
verse.note: This indicates that the church meeting is the church itself.

verse.text: And as to prophets, [xref]a[/xref]two or three should speak, and the others [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]discern.
verse.note: Or, judge. Lit., discriminate. This is to judge or discern whether what is prophesied is of God or not, discriminating the right from the wrong. This indicates that some prophesying may not be of God.

verse.text: But if [i]something[/i] is revealed to another sitting by, the first should be silent.
For [note]1[/note]you can [xref]a[/xref]all prophesy one by one that all may learn and all may be [note]2[/note]encouraged.
verse.note: God desires that each of the believers prophesy, that is, speak for and speak forth Him ([link]v. 1b[/link]; cf. [link]Num. 11:29[/link]).
Or, comforted.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirits of prophets are [xref]b[/xref]subject to prophets;
verse.note: This means that the prophets are not under the control of their spirits, but their spirits are under their direction. Thus, they can determine when to prophesy and when to cease prophesying, to maintain good order in the church meeting. Their spirits are not their master but their means to function. They should learn how to exercise and use their spirits at their discretion.

verse.text: For God is not [i]a God[/i] of [xref]a[/xref]confusion but of [note]1[/note]peace.[separator][note]2[/note]As in [xref]b[/xref]all the [note]3[/note]churches of the [xref]c[/xref]saints,
verse.note: The principle of the charges in [link]vv. 26-32[/link], mainly concerning speaking in tongues and prophesying, is that a peaceful and becoming order, according to what God Himself is, should be kept.
This indicates that all the local churches should be the same in practice.

Verses [link]1:2[/link] and [link]10:32[/link] use the term [i]the church of God.[/i] But here we read [i]the churches of the saints. The church of God[/i] points to the element that constitutes the church: the church is constituted with the element of God. [i]The churches of the saints[/i] points to the components of the churches: the churches are composed of the saints.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]women should be silent [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]in the churches, for they are not permitted to [note]2[/note]speak; but they should be [xref]c[/xref]subject, even as the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]law also says.
verse.note: This means in the church meetings. See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup][/link]. So also in [link]14:35[/link].

According to [link]11:5[/link], women may prophesy (of course, in public) with their head covered, and [link]Acts 2:17-18[/link] and [link]21:9[/link] confirm that women did prophesy. But [link]1 Tim. 2:12[/link] says that women are not permitted to teach, that is, teach as authorities (there, teaching is related to the exercising of authority), so as to define doctrine. Hence, according to the New Testament principle, for women not to be permitted to speak in the church meetings means that women are not permitted to teach with authority in relation to the defining of doctrine. In this sense they should be silent in the church meetings. They are not permitted to speak, because they should be subject to men. This is related to the matter of authority ordained by God in His government. In God's governmental ordination, women are not permitted to speak with authority over men. They may pray and prophesy, that is, (mainly) speak for the Lord and speak forth the Lord. However, they must do this under the covering of the brothers, because they are charged here to be subject.

Referring to the books written by Moses ([link]Matt. 5:17[/link]; [link]7:12[/link]; [link]11:13[/link]). In Moses' writings, [link]Gen. 3:16[/link] charges the woman to be subject to man's rule. This is God's ordination.

verse.text: But if they desire to learn anything, they should ask their own husbands at home; for it is a shame for a woman to speak in the church.
Or [i]was it[/i] from you [i]that[/i] the word of God went forth? Or [note]1[/note]did it reach only to you?
verse.note: This too indicates that a local church should follow the other churches in its practice. All the local churches should submit to the universal order of the Spirit according to the word of the apostles, from whom the word of God goes forth.

verse.text: If anyone thinks he is a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prophet or [xref]b[/xref]spiritual, let him fully know the things which I write to you, that they are the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]commandment of the Lord.
verse.note: This too indicates that to be a prophet or to be a spiritual person is highly esteemed in the church for the carrying out of God's New Testament economy. A prophet is second to an apostle in God's administration in the church ([link]12:28[/link]). He is one who speaks for God and speaks forth God, and who has received revelation of the mysteries concerning Christ and the church ([link]Eph. 3:5[/link]), which revelation is the foundation for the building of the church ([link]Eph. 2:20[/link]). A spiritual person is one who lives according to his spirit, which is mingled with God's Spirit, and who is able to discern all the spiritual things ([link]3:1[/link] and notes; [link]2:15[/link] and note). Such spiritually knowledgeable persons should fully know that the apostle Paul's teachings are the commandment of the Lord, and their speaking should correspond with his teachings. Paul's spirit was strong and his word was frank in dealing with the disorderly Corinthians. He charged them to know definitely that his teachings were a commandment of the Lord, having the authentic authority of the Lord.
Since the apostle's teachings are according to God's ordination ([link]v. 34[/link]), they are the commandment of the Lord.

verse.text: But if anyone [xref]a[/xref]ignores [i]this,[/i] let him ignore [i]it.[/i]
So then, my brothers, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]desire earnestly the [xref]b[/xref]prophesying, and [note]1[/note]do not forbid the speaking in tongues.
verse.note: Actually, this entire chapter deals with prophesying and speaking in tongues. Since prophesying is the most profitable gift for building up both the saints and the church with the rich ministry of Christ, it was highly esteemed and promoted by the apostle. Since speaking in tongues affords no profit for building up, the apostle was faithful to expose its lesser value. Both the apostle's esteeming and his exposing were according to his concern for the fulfilling of God's purpose in building up the church with the riches of Christ. At the conclusion of this chapter he still charged us to desire earnestly to prophesy for God's building. However, in order to keep the all-inclusiveness and oneness of the church, he also charged us not to forbid speaking in tongues.

verse.text: But all things must be done [note]1[/note]becomingly and in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]order.
verse.note: The apostle's concern for the church was that Christ as God's center and the church as God's goal might be carried on and carried out, with all things done becomingly and in good order before men and the angels ([link]4:9[/link]; [link]11:10[/link]). Our natural life is useless in fulfilling such a high purpose. The experience of Christ crucified ([link]1:23[/link]; [link]2:2[/link]) for the termination of our self and the experience of Christ in resurrection as our daily sanctification and redemption ([link]1:30[/link]) are needed for a proper church life.

verse.text: Now I make known to you, brothers, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gospel which I announced to you, which also you received, in which also you [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]stand,
verse.note: The full gospel, including the teachings concerning Christ and the church, as fully disclosed in the book of Romans ([link]Rom. 1:1[/link]; [link]16:25[/link]).
We should stand in the full gospel, that is, in the entire New Testament, not just in certain teachings or doctrines.

verse.text: Through which also you are [note]1[/note]being [xref]a[/xref]saved, if you [xref]b[/xref]hold fast the word which I announced to you as the gospel, unless you have believed [xref]c[/xref]in vain.
verse.note: Or, in the way of salvation (Conybeare). Having been justified in Christ and regenerated by the Spirit, we are in the process of being saved in the life of Christ ([link]Rom. 5:10[/link]), and will be until we are mature and conformed to Him in full ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]).

verse.text: For I delivered to you, first of all, that which also I [xref]a[/xref]received, that [note]1[/note]Christ [xref]b[/xref]died for our [xref]c[/xref]sins according to the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]Scriptures;
verse.note: Christ's death for our sins, His burial for our termination, and His resurrection for our germination with life, which were according to the prophecies of the Old Testament ([link]Isa. 53:5-8[/link], [link]10-12[/link]; [link]Psa. 22:14-18[/link]; [link]Dan. 9:26[/link]; [link]Isa. 53:9[/link]; [link]Psa. 16:9-10[/link]; [link]Hosea 6:2[/link]), are the basic items among the first things of the gospel. The last of these items is the most vital in the gospel, for it is the positive aspect of the gospel in that it imparts life to us that we may obtain life and live Christ.
The Old Testament, that is, the Law and the Prophets.

verse.text: And that He was [xref]a[/xref]buried, and that He has been [xref]b[/xref]raised on the [xref]c[/xref]third day according to the [xref]d[/xref]Scriptures;
And that He [note]1[/note]appeared to [xref]a[/xref]Cephas, then to the [xref]b[/xref]twelve;
verse.note: Or, was seen by. The earlier apostles and disciples were eyewitnesses of Christ's resurrection ([link]Acts 1:22[/link]), and their preaching stressed their testimony to this ([link]Acts 2:32[/link]; [link]4:33[/link]). They witnessed to the resurrected Christ not only by their teaching but also by their living. They lived with Him by His living in resurrection ([link]John 14:19[/link]).

verse.text: Then He appeared to over five hundred brothers at one time, of whom the majority remain until now, but some have fallen asleep;
Then He appeared to James, then to all the apostles;
And last of all He appeared to [xref]a[/xref]me also, as it were to one born prematurely.
For I am the [xref]a[/xref]least of the apostles, who am not fit to be called an apostle, because I [xref]b[/xref]persecuted the [xref]c[/xref]church of God.

But by the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of God I am what I am; and His [xref]b[/xref]grace unto me did not turn out to be [xref]c[/xref]in vain, but, on the contrary, I [xref]d[/xref]labored more abundantly than all of them, yet [note]2[/note]not I but the grace of God which is with me.
verse.note: Grace, mentioned three times in this verse, is the resurrected Christ becoming the life-giving Spirit ([link]v. 45[/link]) to bring the processed Triune God in resurrection into us to be our life and life supply that we may live in resurrection. Thus, grace is the Triune God becoming life and everything to us. (See notes [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in John 1[/link] and [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 2[/link].) It is by this grace that Saul of Tarsus, the foremost of sinners ([link]1 Tim. 1:15-16[/link]), became the foremost apostle, laboring more abundantly than all the apostles. His ministry and living by this grace are an undeniable testimony to Christ's resurrection.

[i]Not I but the grace of God[/i] equals [i]no longer I[/i]...but...Christ in [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]. The grace that motivated the apostle and operated in him was not some matter or some thing but a living person, the resurrected Christ, the embodiment of God the Father who became the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit, who dwelt in the apostle as his everything.

verse.text: Therefore whether it is I or they, so we preach and so you have believed.
But if Christ is proclaimed that He has been [xref]a[/xref]raised from the dead, how [i]is it that[/i] some among you say that there is [note]1[/note]no resurrection of the dead?
verse.note: In this chapter the apostle dealt with the Corinthians' heretical saying that there is no resurrection of the dead. The Corinthians were like the Sadducees ([link]Matt. 22:23[/link]; [link]Acts 23:8[/link]). This was the tenth problem among them. It is the most damaging and destructive to God's New Testament economy, worse than the heresy of Hymenaeus and Philetus concerning resurrection ([link]2 Tim. 2:17-18[/link]). Resurrection is the life pulse and lifeline of the divine economy. If there were no resurrection, God would be the God of the dead, not of the living ([link]Matt. 22:32[/link]). If there were no resurrection, Christ would not have been raised from the dead. He would be a dead Savior, not a living One who lives forever ([link]Rev. 1:18[/link]) and is able to save to the uttermost ([link]Heb. 7:25[/link]). If there were no resurrection, there would be no living proof of our being justified by His death ([link]Rom. 4:25[/link] and note), no imparting of life ([link]John 12:24[/link]), no regeneration ([link]John 3:5[/link]), no renewing ([link]Titus 3:5[/link]), no transformation ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]), and no conformity to the image of Christ ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]). If there were no resurrection, there would be no members of Christ ([link]Rom. 12:5[/link]), no Body of Christ as His fullness ([link]Eph. 1:20-23[/link]), and no church as Christ's bride ([link]John 3:29[/link]), and therefore no new man ([link]Eph. 2:15[/link]; [link]4:24[/link]; [link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]). If there were no resurrection, God's New Testament economy would altogether collapse and God's eternal purpose would be nullified.

verse.text: But if there is no resurrection of the dead, neither has Christ been raised.
And if Christ has not been raised, then our proclamation is [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vain; your faith is [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]vain also.
verse.note: I.e., empty, void. Without the living Christ in resurrection, both the proclamation of the gospel and our faith in the gospel would be empty and void, having no reality.

verse.text: And also we are found to be false witnesses of God because we have testified concerning God that He [xref]a[/xref]raised Christ, whom He did not raise, if indeed the dead are not raised.
For if the dead are not raised, neither has Christ been raised.
And if Christ has not been raised, your faith is [note]1[/note]futile; you are [note]2[/note]still in your [xref]a[/xref]sins.
verse.note: I.e., fruitless, worthless. If Christ had not been resurrected to live in us as our life and everything, our faith in Him would be fruitless, worthless, and without any issue, such as the impartation of life, freedom from sin, victory over Satan, and growth in life.

Christ's death saves us from being condemned because of our sins, not from the power of sin. It is His resurrection life that delivers us from the power of sin ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]). If Christ had not been resurrected, we would still remain in sins and under the power of sin.

verse.text: Then also those who have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fallen asleep in Christ have [note]2[/note]perished.
verse.note: I.e., died ([link]1 Thes. 4:13-16[/link]).
I.e., not to be resurrected but to remain in death forever.

verse.text: If [i]it is[/i] [note]1[/note]only [i]that[/i] we have [xref]a[/xref]hoped in Christ in this life, we are of all men most miserable.
verse.note: If there were no resurrection, we would have no future and no hope for the future, such as Christ as our hope of glory ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]), the lot of our eternal blessing ([link]Dan. 12:13[/link]), the reign with Christ in the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]), and the reward of the resurrection of the just ([link]Luke 14:14[/link]). All these hopes are connected to our resurrection.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But now Christ has been [xref]a[/xref]raised from the dead, the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep.
verse.note: [link]Verses 20-28[/link] are a parenthetical word verifying the truth of resurrection by setting forth Christ as the firstfruits of resurrection.

Christ was the first One raised from among the dead, becoming the firstfruits of resurrection. This was typified by the firstfruits (a sheaf of the firstfruits, including Christ with some of the dead Old Testament saints, was raised at the Lord's resurrection — [link]Matt. 27:52-53[/link]) in [link]Lev. 23:10-11[/link], which were offered to God on the day after the Sabbath, the day of resurrection ([link]Matt. 28:1[/link]). Christ as the firstfruits of resurrection is the Firstborn from among the dead that He might be the Head of the Body ([link]Col. 1:18[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:20-23[/link]). Since He, the Head of the Body, has been resurrected, we, the Body, also will be resurrected.

verse.text: For since through [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]man [i]came[/i] death, through [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]man also [i]came[/i] the [xref]c[/xref]resurrection of the dead.
verse.note: I.e., Adam, the first man ([link]v. 45[/link]).

I.e., Christ, the second man ([link]v. 47[/link]). Adam brought in death through sin ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]); Christ brought in the life of resurrection through righteousness ([link]Rom. 5:17-18[/link]). The death brought in by Adam works in us from our birth by our parents until the death of our body. The life of resurrection brought in by Christ operates in us, as signified by baptism ([link]Rom. 6:4[/link]), from our regeneration by the Spirit of God ([link]John 3:5[/link]) until the transfiguration of our body ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]).

verse.text: For just as in [xref]a[/xref]Adam all [note]1[/note]die, so also in [xref]b[/xref]Christ all will be [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]made alive.
verse.note: In Adam we were born in death and were born to die; we are dead in him ([link]Eph. 2:1[/link], [link]5[/link]).
In Christ we have been reborn in life and resurrected to live; we have been enlivened, made alive, in Him ([link]Eph. 2:5-6[/link]).

verse.text: But each one in his own order: the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]firstfruits, Christ; then [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]those who are Christ's at His [xref]c[/xref]coming;
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]2[/sup][/link]. Christ as the firstfruits is first in order in the resurrection from the dead.

The believers in Christ, the righteous, who will be resurrected unto life at the Lord's coming back before the millennium ([link]John 5:29[/link]; [link]Luke 14:14[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:52[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link]). They will be second in order in the resurrection from the dead.

verse.text: Then the [note]1[/note]end, [note]2[/note]when He [note]3[/note]delivers up the [xref]a[/xref]kingdom to His God and Father, [note]2[/note]once He has abolished all [xref]b[/xref]rule and all authority and power.
verse.note: In the preceding verse the order of resurrection is mentioned: the first, Christ; then those who are Christ's. Accordingly, in this verse, after [i]then,[/i] one would expect a group of people to be named. However, here it does not tell us who, but it says "the end," because those who will be resurrected at the end in their own order are not in Christ.[br][br]The end here is the end of all the ages and dispensations of the old creation. It is also the end of the millennium before the new heaven and new earth ([link]Rev. 21:1[/link]). In all the ages and dispensations God, on one hand, has been dealing with His enemy Satan and all the negative things in the universe; on the other hand, He has been accomplishing all things for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose. The last of the ages and dispensations will be the millennium, the kingdom age, after which all God's dealings and accomplishments will be fully completed. That completion will be the end, the conclusion, of all God's work. At this end all the dead unbelievers, the unrighteous, will be resurrected unto judgment for eternal perdition ([link]John 5:29[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:5[/link], [link]11-15[/link]). They will be third in order in the resurrection.

When Christ annuls the satanic authority, subdues all His enemies ([link]v. 25[/link]), abolishes death ([link]v. 26[/link]), and delivers up the kingdom to God the Father, that is, when all the negative things are done away with and the entire purpose of God is fulfilled, the old creation will be concluded.

After accomplishing redemption, Christ went to receive the kingdom from the Father ([link]Luke 19:12[/link], [link]15[/link]). Before the millennium He as the Son of Man will have received the kingdom from God, the Ancient of Days, to rule all the nations for one thousand years ([link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). At the end of the millennium, after He has defeated Satan, the devil, and his evil angels (as all rule, authority, and power), and even death and Hades, putting all His enemies under His feet ([link]vv. 25-26[/link]) and casting all of them, including death and Hades, into the lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:7-10[/link], [link]14[/link]), He will deliver the kingdom back to God the Father.

verse.text: For He must [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reign until [i]God[/i] [xref]b[/xref]puts all His enemies under His feet.
verse.note: In the millennium, the last age of the old creation.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Death, the last enemy, is [note]1[/note]being abolished.
verse.note: Immediately after the fall of man, God began His work to abolish sin and death. This work has been progressing through the Old and New Testament ages and is still in progress today. When sin is done away with at the end of the old creation, and when its source, Satan, is cast into the lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:7-10[/link]), death will be abolished. It will be cast into the lake of fire with Hades, its power, after the final judgment at the white throne ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]).

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]He has [xref]a[/xref]subjected all things under [note]2[/note]His feet. But when [note]1[/note]He says that all things are subjected, it is evident that [i]all things are[/i] except [note]1[/note]Him who has subjected all things to [note]2[/note]Him.
verse.note: Referring to God, who has subjected all things under Christ's feet. This is a reference to [link]Psa. 8:6-8[/link] concerning Christ as the man whom God caused to have dominion over all things. This will be fulfilled when all the things mentioned in [link]vv. 24-26[/link] have taken place. [i]For[/i] at the beginning of the verse indicates this.

Referring to Christ as the man prophesied in [link]Psa. 8:4-8[/link]. To Him — the resurrected, glorified, and exalted man — God has subjected all things ([link]Heb. 2:7-9[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:20-22[/link]).

verse.text: And when all things have been [xref]a[/xref]subjected to [note]1[/note]Him, then the [note]2[/note]Son Himself also will be subjected to [note]3[/note]Him who has subjected all things to [note]1[/note]Him, that [xref]b[/xref]God may be [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]all in all.
verse.note: Christ, according to [link]v. 27[/link], to whom God has subjected all things.

Christ, the Son of God, as the head of mankind in His humanity, is under the headship of God the Father ([link]11:3[/link]). This is for the government of God's kingdom. After God the Father has subjected all things under the feet of Christ as a resurrected man in glory ([link]Eph. 1:22[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:7-8[/link]), and after Christ as such a resurrected man has put all enemies under His feet to execute God the Father's subjection of all things to Him, He as the Son of God, along with His delivering of the kingdom back to God the Father ([link]v. 24[/link]), will also subject Himself in His divinity to God, who has subjected all things to Him, the Son in His humanity. This indicates the Son's absolute subjection and subordination to the Father, which exalts the Father that God the Father may be all in all.
God, according to [link]v. 27[/link], who has subjected all things to Christ.
The same Greek word as for [i]all things[/i] at the beginning of this verse.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Otherwise what shall they who are [note]2[/note]baptized for the dead do? If the dead are actually [xref]a[/xref]not raised, why then are they baptized for them?
verse.note: Considering [link]vv. 20-28[/link] a parenthesis, this verse should be connected with [link]v. 18[/link], and [link]vv. 30-32[/link] with [link]v. 19[/link].

This should not have been an official matter generally practiced by the early churches but a personal activity of some individual believers on behalf of dead persons for whom they were concerned, who might have believed in the Lord but not been baptized before they died. They did this in hope of the dead ones' being resurrected from the dead at the Lord's coming back ([link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]), since in baptism resurrection is strongly signified ([link]Col. 2:12[/link]). The apostle used what they did to confirm the truth of resurrection. This does not mean, however, that he sanctioned some believers' being baptized for the dead.

verse.text: Why also do we brave [xref]a[/xref]danger every hour?
I protest by the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]boasting in you, brothers, which I have [note]2[/note]in Christ Jesus our Lord, I [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]die daily.
verse.note: The Corinthian believers were the fruit of the apostle's labor, a labor in which he risked his life. In them the apostle could boast of this. By this boasting he protested that daily he died, that is, daily he risked death, faced death, and died to self ([link]2 Cor. 11:23[/link]; [link]4:11[/link]; [link]1:8-9[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:36[/link]).

At this point, in his word concerning resurrection the apostle used his experience in the Lord's work to confirm the matter of resurrection, especially the effect of Christ's resurrection on him. The apostle's boasting in the Corinthians, who were the fruit of his risking of his life, was in the resurrected Christ, not in himself, because his risking of death in his labor for them was not by himself but by the resurrected Christ.

verse.text: If [note]1[/note]after the manner of men I fought with [note]2[/note]wild beasts at [xref]a[/xref]Ephesus, what does it profit me? If the dead are [xref]b[/xref]not raised, [note]3[/note]let us [xref]c[/xref]eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.
verse.note: In those days men fought against evil persons or matters in order to receive a temporal reward. But the apostle did not fight after that manner when he fought with evil persons and matters for the gospel's sake. Rather, he fought according to a higher hope in order to be rewarded at the resurrection in the future ([link]Luke 14:14[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:8[/link]).
A figure of speech denoting evil persons or matters ([link]2 Tim. 4:17[/link]).

This appears to be a quotation of a saying of that day, a maxim of the Epicureans. If there is no resurrection, we believers have no hope for the future and have become the most miserable of all men ([link]v. 19[/link]). If so, we had better enjoy our life today, forgetting the future, as the Epicureans did.

verse.text: Do not be [xref]a[/xref]deceived: [note]1[/note]Evil [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]companionships [xref]c[/xref]corrupt good morals.
verse.note: This appears to be a quotation of a saying of that day, a fragment of a Greek poem. By this word the apostle warned the Corinthian believers not to have any companionship with those heretics who said that there is no resurrection. Such evil companionship would corrupt their faith and their Christian virtues.
Or, company.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Awake from the drunken stupor righteously and do not sin, for some [i]of you[/i] [note]2[/note]are [xref]b[/xref]ignorant of God. I speak to your [xref]c[/xref]shame.
verse.note: Or, Cease, righteously, to be drunken. [i]Righteously[/i] means being right with God and with man. To say that there is no resurrection offends God and man. This is to commit sin and thereby be unrighteous. Hence, the apostle advised the misled Corinthians to awake soberly from this sin and restore a right relationship with God and man. They were drunken unrighteously in the stupor of the no-resurrection heresy. They needed to cease being in that stupor.
To be heretical in saying that there is no resurrection is to be ignorant of God, not knowing God's power and economy ([link]Matt. 22:29-32[/link]). This is a shame to the believers.

verse.text: But someone will say, How are the dead raised? And with what kind of body do they come?
Foolish man, [note]1[/note]what you sow is not made alive unless it [xref]a[/xref]dies;
verse.note: The reality of resurrection is contained and concealed in nature, especially in the plant life. A seed sown into the earth dies and is made alive. This is resurrection. This answered the foolish Corinthians' first question, "How are the dead raised?" ([link]v. 35[/link]).

verse.text: And what you sow, you do not sow the body that will be, but a bare grain, perhaps of wheat or of some [i]other[/i] of the rest.
But God gives it a [note]1[/note]body even as He willed, and to each of the seeds its own [note]1[/note]body.
verse.note: Not the body sown to die ([link]v. 37[/link]) but the resurrected body given by God, in a different shape and on a higher level. This answered the Corinthians' foolish question, "With what kind of body do they come?" ([link]v. 35[/link]).
