verse.text: [note]1[/note]All [xref]a[/xref]flesh is not the same flesh, but one is of [xref]b[/xref]men, and another flesh is of [xref]c[/xref]cattle, and another is of [xref]d[/xref]birds, and another is of fish.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 39-41[/link] the apostle proved to the foolish Corinthians that God is able to give a body to all resurrected lives, just as He gave a body to all created things: to men and animals on the earth, to birds in the air, and to fish in the water — the earthly bodies with their different glories; and to the sun, the moon, and the stars — heavenly bodies with heavenly glory in varying degrees.

verse.text: There are also heavenly bodies and earthly bodies; but the glory of the heavenly is one thing, and that of the earthly is another.
There is another glory of the [xref]a[/xref]sun, and another glory of the [xref]b[/xref]moon, and another glory of the [xref]c[/xref]stars; for star differs from star in glory.
So [xref]a[/xref]also is the [xref]b[/xref]resurrection of the dead. It is sown in [xref]c[/xref]corruption, it is [xref]d[/xref]raised in incorruption;
It is sown in dishonor, it is raised in [xref]a[/xref]glory; it is sown in weakness, it is raised in power;
It is sown a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]soulish body, it is raised a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]spiritual [xref]c[/xref]body. If there is a soulish body, there is also a spiritual one.
verse.note: A soulish body is a natural body animated by the soul, a body in which the soul predominates. A spiritual body is a resurrected body saturated by the spirit, a body in which the spirit predominates. When we die, our natural body, being soulish, will be sown, i.e., buried, in corruption, in dishonor, and in weakness. When it is resurrected, it will become spiritual in incorruption, in glory, and in power ([link]vv. 42-43[/link]).

verse.text: So also it is written, "The first man, [xref]a[/xref]Adam, became a [xref]b[/xref]living [note]1[/note]soul"; the last Adam [i]became[/i] a [xref]c[/xref]life-giving [note]1[/note]Spirit.
verse.note: Through creation Adam became a living soul with a soulish body. Through resurrection Christ became a life-giving Spirit with a spiritual body. Adam as a living soul is natural; Christ as a life-giving Spirit is resurrected. First, in incarnation He became flesh for redemption ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]29[/link]); then, in resurrection He became a life-giving Spirit for the imparting of life ([link]John 10:10b[/link]). Through incarnation He had a soulish body, as Adam had; through resurrection He has a spiritual body. His soulish body has become a spiritual one through resurrection. Now He is a life-giving Spirit in resurrection, with a spiritual body, ready to be received by His believers. When we believe into Him, He enters our spirit, and we are joined to Him as the life-giving Spirit. Hence, we become one spirit with Him ([link]6:17[/link]). Our spirit is made alive and is resurrected with Him. Eventually, our present soulish body will become a spiritual body in resurrection, just like His ([link]vv. 52-54[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:21[/link]).

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]the spiritual is not first but [note]2[/note]the soulish, then the spiritual:
verse.note: Christ, the second man ([link]v. 47[/link]).
Adam, the first man ([link]v. 47[/link]).

verse.text: The first man is [note]1[/note]out of the [xref]a[/xref]earth, earthy; the [note]2[/note]second man [i]is[/i] [note]3[/note]out of [xref]b[/xref]heaven.
verse.note: [i]Out of the earth[/i] denotes the origin of the first man, Adam, and [i]earthy,[/i] his nature.

Christ is not only the last Adam ([link]v. 45[/link]) but also the second man. The first Adam ([link]v. 45[/link]) is the beginning of mankind; the last Adam is the ending. As the first man, Adam is the head of the old creation, representing it in creation. As the second man, Christ is the Head of the new creation, representing it in resurrection. In the entire universe there are only two men: the first man, Adam, including all his descendants, and the second man, Christ, comprising all His believers. We believers were included in the first man by birth and became a part of the second man by regeneration. Our believing has transferred us out of the first man into the second. In regard to our being part of the first man, our origin is the earth and our nature is earthy. In regard to our being part of the second man, our origin is God and our nature is heavenly.
[i]Out of[/i] heaven denotes both the divine origin and the heavenly nature of the second man, Christ.

verse.text: As [note]1[/note]the earthy is, such are [note]2[/note]they also that are earthy; and as [note]3[/note]the heavenly is, such are [note]4[/note]they also that are [xref]a[/xref]heavenly.
verse.note: The first man, Adam, who is earthy.
All of Adam's descendants, who are earthy, like Adam.
The second man, Christ, who is heavenly.
All the believers in Christ, who are heavenly, like Christ.

verse.text: And even as we have borne the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]image of the earthy, we will also bear the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]image of the heavenly.
verse.note: As a part of Adam, we have borne the earthy man's image through birth; as a part of Christ, we will bear the heavenly man's image in resurrection. This indicates that just as in Adam we have been born as those who are earthy, so in Christ we will be resurrected as those who are heavenly. Such a resurrection is our destiny. It is as sure as our birth and should never be questioned.

verse.text: Now this I say, brothers, that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]flesh and blood cannot inherit the [xref]b[/xref]kingdom of God, neither does [xref]c[/xref]corruption inherit [xref]d[/xref]incorruption.
verse.note: Flesh and blood are the components of the soulish body, which is corruptible and is not qualified to inherit the kingdom of God, which is incorruptible. Corruption cannot inherit incorruption. Our corruptible body must be resurrected into an incorruptible one that we may be able to inherit the incorruptible kingdom of God in resurrection.

verse.text: Behold, I tell you [xref]a[/xref]a [note]1[/note]mystery: We will not all [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sleep, but we will all be [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]changed,
verse.note: The transfiguration, including the resurrection, of our corruptible body into an incorruptible one ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]). This is mysterious to human understanding.
I.e., die ([link]11:30[/link]; [link]John 11:11-13[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:13-16[/link]).

I.e., transfigured from corruption, dishonor, and weakness to incorruption, glory, and power ([link]vv. 42-43[/link]). This is to have the body of our humiliation conformed to the body of Christ's glory ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]).

verse.text: In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the [note]1[/note]last [xref]a[/xref]trumpet; for the trumpet will sound, and the [note]2[/note]dead will be [xref]b[/xref]raised incorruptible, and [note]3[/note]we will be changed.
verse.note: The seventh trumpet ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]), the trumpet of God ([link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]).
The dead in Christ, the dead believers ([link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]).
We believers who are living at the time of the Lord's return. The dead saints will be resurrected first; then the living ones will be changed, transfigured, in rapture ([link]1 Thes. 4:15-17[/link]).

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]this [xref]a[/xref]corruptible must put on incorruption, and [note]1[/note]this [xref]b[/xref]mortal [i]must[/i] put on immortality.
verse.note: Referring to our corruptible and mortal body, which must put on incorruption and immortality either through our being resurrected from the dead or through our being transfigured while still alive. This is mysterious and incomprehensible to the natural sight.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]when this corruptible will put on incorruption and this mortal will put on immortality, then the word which is written will come to pass, [xref]a[/xref]"Death has been [xref]b[/xref]swallowed up [note]2[/note]unto [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]victory."
verse.note: I.e., when our corrupted and mortal body is resurrected or transfigured from corruption and death into glory and life. Then death will be swallowed up unto victory. This is the consummation of the resurrection we share in God's economy through the redemption and salvation in Christ. This resurrection begins with the enlivening of our dead spirit and is completed with the transfiguration of our corruptible body. Between these two ends is the process in which our fallen soul is metabolically transformed by the life-giving Spirit, who is the reality of resurrection ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]).
Death is a defeat to man. Through Christ's salvation in the resurrection life, death will be swallowed up unto victory to us, the beneficiaries of Christ's resurrection life.

This chapter is on resurrection. Christ's resurrection was His victory over Satan, God's enemy, over the world, over sin, and over death. After His triumphal ascension to the height ([link]Eph. 4:8[/link]) in His resurrection, God subdued all the enemies for Him ([link]v. 25[/link]). Then, as One who is in resurrection, He will come to the earth with the kingdom of God ([link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]) to exercise God's power and subdue everything on earth. This will continue for a thousand years ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). The last enemy to be abolished is death. The swallowing up of death will result in the ultimate victory of the Lord's resurrection, that is, in the ultimate and complete victory that He has accomplished in resurrection for us who believe in Him and participate in His resurrection. This is the ultimate issue of His resurrection for His and God's eternal kingdom and for the eternal enjoyment of His resurrection life in eternity by those who believe in Him.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Where, [xref]a[/xref]O death, is your victory? Where, O death, is your [xref]b[/xref]sting?
verse.note: This is the apostle's triumphant exclamation concerning the victory of resurrection life over death.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]sting of [xref]a[/xref]death is sin, and the [note]2[/note]power of [xref]b[/xref]sin is the [xref]c[/xref]law.
verse.note: Death is of the devil ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]), and through sin it stings us to death ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]). In God's redemption Christ was made sin for us ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]) in order that God might condemn sin through Christ's death ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]), thus abolishing the sting of death. Then, through Christ's resurrection death is swallowed up by the resurrection life.

Sin brings to us a curse and condemnation, both in our conscience and before God, through the law ([link]Rom. 4:15[/link]; [link]5:13[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]7:7-8[/link]). Hence, the law becomes the power of sin to kill us ([link]Rom. 7:10-11[/link]). Since Christ's death has fulfilled the law's requirements on us ([link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link]; [link]2:24[/link]), the power of sin has been annulled. Through the death of Christ sin has been condemned and the law has been annulled, and through His resurrection death has been swallowed up. Therefore, we must give thanks to God, who gives us such a victory over sin and death through the death and resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ ([link]v. 57[/link]).

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]thanks be to God who gives us the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
verse.note: This victory over sin and death through Christ's death and resurrection should not be merely an accomplished fact for our acceptance; it must become our daily experience in life through the resurrected Christ as the life-giving Spirit ([link]v. 45[/link]), who is one with our spirit ([link]6:17[/link]). Hence, we should live by and walk according to this mingled spirit. Thus thanks will be given continuously to God, who gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.

verse.text: Therefore, my beloved brothers, be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]steadfast, immovable, always abounding in the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]work of the Lord, knowing that your [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]labor is not [xref]d[/xref]in vain in the Lord.
verse.note: To question the truth of resurrection is to be shaken. To be assured and remain in the reality of resurrection is to be steadfast, immovable.

Not believing in the truth of resurrection causes us to be disappointed concerning our future, thus making us discouraged in the work of the Lord. Faith gives us a strong aspiration to abound in the work of the Lord with the expectation of pleasing the Lord in resurrection at His coming back.

Not by our natural life and natural ability but by the Lord's resurrection life and power. Our labor for the Lord in His resurrection life with His resurrection power will never be in vain, but will result in the fulfilling of God's eternal purpose through the preaching of Christ to sinners, the ministering of life to the saints, and the building up of the church with the experiences of the processed Triune God as gold, silver, and precious stones ([link]3:12[/link]). This labor will be rewarded by the returning Lord in the day of the resurrection of the righteous ([link]3:14[/link]; [link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]Luke 14:14[/link]).

verse.text: Now concerning the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]collection for the saints, [note]2[/note]just as I [xref]b[/xref]directed the [xref]c[/xref]churches of Galatia, so you also do.
verse.note: This is the eleventh matter dealt with by the apostle in this Epistle, a matter concerned with money, mammon, and material possessions. All of fallen mankind is under the domination of mammon and material possessions ([link]Matt. 6:19-21[/link], [link]24-25[/link], [link]30[/link]; [link]19:21-22[/link]; [link]Luke 12:13-19[/link]). On the day of Pentecost, under the power of the Holy Spirit, all the believers overthrew this domination and had all their possessions in common for distribution to the needy ones ([link]Acts 2:44-45[/link]; [link]4:32[/link], [link]34-37[/link]). Because of the weakness of the believers' fallen nature (cf. [link]Acts 5:1-11[/link]; [link]6:1[/link]), that practice did not last long. It had already ended by the apostle Paul's time. Hence, the believers needed grace to overcome the power of mammon and material things and to release these things from Satan's domination that they might be offered to the Lord for the fulfillment of His purpose. Resurrection life is the supply for the believers to live such a life, a life trusting in God, not in material possessions, a life not for today but for the future, not for this age but for the coming age ([link]Luke 12:16-21[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 6:17-19[/link]), a life that overthrows the usurpation of temporal and uncertain riches. This may be the reason that the dealing with this matter comes after the dealing concerning the reality of resurrection life. In any case, this dealing is related to God's administration among the churches.
Again, this strongly indicates that all the local churches should be the same in their practice ([link]7:17[/link]; [link]11:16[/link]; [link]14:33[/link]).

verse.text: On the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]first day of the week each one of you should lay aside in store to himself whatever he may have been prospered, that no collections be made when I come.
verse.note: The seventh day of the week, the Sabbath, was a memorial of God's creation ([link]Gen. 2:1-3[/link]; [link]Exo. 20:8[/link], [link]11[/link]). The first day of the week is a symbol of the Lord's resurrection; it is the day on which the Lord resurrected from the dead ([link]John 20:1[/link] and note 1) and is called "the Lord's Day" ([link]Rev. 1:10[/link]). The New Testament saints meet and offer their possessions on this day ([link]Acts 20:7[/link]), the day of the Lord's resurrection, signifying that they have been resurrected with the Lord ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]) through His resurrection ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) and that they meet in resurrection by the resurrection life, not by their natural life, to remember the Lord and worship God with their offerings.

verse.text: And when I arrive, whomever you approve, I will [xref]a[/xref]send them with letters to carry your [note]1[/note]gift to [xref]b[/xref]Jerusalem;
verse.note: Lit., grace. This was a kind of fellowship, under the apostle's direction, of the churches in the Gentile world with the church in Jerusalem ([link]2 Cor. 8:1-2[/link]; [link]Rom. 15:25-27[/link]).

verse.text: And if it is fitting for me also to go, they will go with me.
Now I will [xref]a[/xref]come to you when I pass through [xref]b[/xref]Macedonia, for I will pass through Macedonia.
And perhaps I will stay with you, or even spend the [xref]a[/xref]winter, that you may [xref]b[/xref]send me forward wherever I may go.
For I do not wish to see you now [i]just[/i] in [xref]a[/xref]passing, for I am hoping to remain with you for some time, if the Lord [xref]b[/xref]permits.
But I will remain in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ephesus until [xref]b[/xref]Pentecost,
verse.note: This Epistle was written in Ephesus, where the apostle stayed for three years on the third journey of his ministry ([link]Acts 19:21-22[/link]; [link]20:1[/link], [link]31[/link]).

verse.text: For a [xref]a[/xref]door is opened to me, great and efficacious, and there are many [xref]b[/xref]opposers.
Now if [xref]a[/xref]Timothy comes, see that he is with you without fear; for he is working the [xref]b[/xref]work of the Lord, even as I am.
Let no one therefore [xref]a[/xref]despise him, but [xref]b[/xref]send him forward in [xref]c[/xref]peace that he may come to me; for I am awaiting him with the brothers.

And [note]1[/note]concerning our brother [xref]a[/xref]Apollos, [note]2[/note]I urged him many times to come to you with the brothers; yet it was [note]2[/note]not at all [i]his[/i] desire to come now, but he [xref]b[/xref]will come when he has opportunity.
verse.note: By this the Corinthians should have realized that Paul's attitude toward Apollos and his relationship with him were in sharp contrast to their preferences ([link]1:11-12[/link]). His attitude and relationship kept the oneness; their preferences caused division.

Both Paul and Apollos were persons living in the Spirit. Yet, one urged the other to visit the church, but the other did not have the desire to do so. This shows that both had freedom in the Spirit and that the Spirit had freedom in them. This shows also that no one exercised any control over the work of the Lord.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Watch, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]stand firm in the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]faith, be [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]full-grown men, be [xref]e[/xref]strong.
verse.note: I.e., do not be shaken by any heresy, especially the one that says there is no resurrection.
The objective faith; referring to what we believe.

I.e., those who are strong in the faith and firm in their standing, not like a child in understanding ([link]14:20[/link]) or like little children tossed by waves and carried about by the winds of teaching ([link]Eph. 4:14[/link]). To be such men, growth in life is needed ([link]3:1[/link], [link]6[/link]). The Corinthian believers neglected the growth in life and were short of it.

verse.text: Let all your matters be done in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love.
verse.note: As defined in [link]ch. 13[/link].

verse.text: Now I exhort you, brothers: You know the household of [xref]a[/xref]Stephanas, that it is the [xref]b[/xref]firstfruits of [xref]c[/xref]Achaia, and they have set themselves to minister to the [xref]d[/xref]saints;
You also be [xref]a[/xref]subject to such ones, and to everyone co-working and [xref]b[/xref]laboring.
Now I rejoice at the coming of Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus, because these have [xref]a[/xref]filled up the lack caused by your absence;
For they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]refreshed my [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]spirit and yours. [xref]c[/xref]Acknowledge therefore such ones.
verse.note: This must have been by the riches of Christ ministered by one's spirit, which can touch others' spirits.
Our contact and relationship with the saints must be in and by our spirit, not our soulish emotion.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]churches of [xref]b[/xref]Asia greet you. [xref]c[/xref]Aquila and Prisca greet you much in the Lord, with the [note]1[/note]church, which is in their [xref]d[/xref]house.
verse.note: This means that when Aquila and Prisca lived in Ephesus, the church there met in their home ([link]Acts 18:18-19[/link], [link]26[/link]). When they lived in Rome, the church in Rome met in their home ([link]Rom. 16:5[/link]; cf. [link]Col. 4:15-16[/link]; [link]Philem. 2[/link]).

verse.text: All the brothers greet you. Greet one another with a holy [xref]a[/xref]kiss.
[note]1[/note]The greeting in my own [xref]a[/xref]hand — Paul.
verse.note: [link]Verses 10-21[/link] present a picture of the actual practice of the Body life in a beautiful harmony, not only among the apostle and his co-workers but also between them and the churches for the building up of the Body, which is so strongly stressed in [link]chs. 12-14[/link].

verse.text: If anyone does not [xref]a[/xref]love the Lord, let him be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]accursed! [note]2[/note]The [xref]c[/xref]Lord comes!
verse.note: Gk. [i]anathema,[/i] meaning [i]a thing or person accursed;[/i] i.e., [i]set apart, devoted, to woe.[/i] Our loving God makes us those who are blessed of God to share the divine blessings that He has ordained and prepared for us, which are beyond our apprehension ([link]2:9[/link]). Our not loving the Lord makes us those who are accursed, set apart to a curse. What a warning!
[i]Maranatha,[/i] from Aramaic, meaning [i]The Lord comes![/i] or [i]Our Lord come![/i] It is an exclamation reminding us that the Lord's second coming is with judgment.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

verse.text: My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love in Christ Jesus be with you [i]all.[/i]
verse.note: Not a natural love but love in Christ, love in resurrection ([link]4:21[/link]), the love of God that becomes ours through the grace of Christ and the fellowship of the Spirit ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]). Of Paul's fourteen Epistles, only this one ends with such a word of the assurance of love. This is because the apostle had been dealing with them with strong rebukes ([link]1:13[/link]; [link]3:3[/link]; [link]4:7-8[/link]; [link]5:2[/link], [link]5[/link]; [link]6:5-8[/link]; [link]11:17[/link]). He was faithful, honest, and frank toward them in the love of God in Christ ([link]2 Cor. 2:4[/link]), without being political. Hence, the Lord honored his dealings, and the Corinthians accepted his rebukes and repented, resulting in their being benefited ([link]2 Cor. 7:8-13[/link]).
